That afternoon, Daniel Penny left City Tech in Downtown Brooklyn, where he was studying architecture, and headed into Manhattan via the F train to the Flatiron branch of Life Time, the elite gym and wellness merchant. A few stops in, at Second Avenue, an unhinged Jordan Neely got on and threw his jacket to the floor.

title: The Glorious, Behind-the-Scenes Mess That Is Cookie Week
description: During Cookie Week, New York Times Cooking unveils seven new cookie recipes to sweeten the holiday season. This year’s roundup includes matcha-black sesame shortbreads, holiday rocky road and even boozy almond bites.

title: Syrians Celebrate as Rebels Force Bashar al-Assad Out of Power
description: Gunfire and cheering erupted across Syria after rebels took control of Damascus, the capital, and ended President Bashar al-Assad’s authoritarian regime.

title: Israel Enters Demilitarized Buffer Zone in the Golan Heights
description: Israel said Sunday that it had entered a demilitarized buffer zone in the Golan Heights, abutting Syrian-held territory, amid a lightning fast rebel offensive that swept across Syria and drove President Bashar al-Assad from power.

title: 8 Great Thrillers About Bad Marriages
description: What is it about marriages that makes them enduringly fertile material for the thriller treatment? Is it that we’re all incurably curious about the lives of others? Is it the schadenfreude of learning that an outwardly perfect union is anything but? Perhaps it’s the fascinating, unnerving suggestion that there may be secrets — terrible, life-upending secrets — even within the sanctuary of a person’s home and at the heart of this most intimate of relationships.

title: The Best Poetry Books of 2024
description: A friend asked me recently what poetry is for. A somewhat difficult question! Another day, I may have answered differently, but on that occasion, I surprised myself by using the word religion. I was thinking of structure and practice — of dailiness and weekliness, of ritual, tradition, the way that returning again and again to foundational texts or the writing desk makes a certain order of experience more possible. The ritual, importantly, removes the burden of decision for some length of time as to where you’ll put your body, what you’ll do with it. This frees up room in the mind.

title: Top-Gun Navy Pilots Fly at the Extremes. Their Brains May Suffer.
description: To produce the best of the best, the Navy’s elite TOPGUN flying school puts fighter pilots through a crucible of intense, aerial dogfighting maneuvers under crushing G forces. But behind the high-speed Hollywood heroics that the school is famous for, the Navy has grown concerned that the extreme flying may also be producing something else: brain injuries.

title: A Mural, and the Heroic Efforts to Save It
description: For 63 years, a modernist sculptural mural in the lobby of Pfizer’s world headquarters on East 42nd Street in Manhattan celebrated a millennia-long parade of medical pioneers like Hippocrates and Louis Pasteur.

title: Did Trump Drain Democrats’ Energy? These Races Will Be the First Test.
description: Even as the exhausted nation recovers from its two-year presidential campaign, candidates in a pocket of Northern Virginia are gearing up for a pair of special elections that may serve as barometers of partisan enthusiasm in the Trump 2.0 era.

title: Inside the Four-Day Workweek Experiment
description: On a recent Wednesday morning, Matt Kimber did not sign into his job as a senior engineer at a software company. Instead, he went for a walk around his London neighborhood, picked up lunch at a cafe, and played with his two greyhounds.

title: He Was Shot in the Face. Now Ukraine Wants to Draft Him.
description: Early in Russia’s war against Ukraine, Mykola Kulichenko endured an ordeal. He was abducted as a civilian, survived a Russian execution attempt by a stroke of luck and then climbed out of his own grave by pushing through the dirt heaped above him.

title: They Love France. So When Notre-Dame Burned, They Wanted to Help.
description: Like many of the millions of tourists who visit Paris, Nick and Suzie Trivisonno, of Charlotte, N.C., would usually catch at least a glimpse of Notre-Dame on their frequent visits to town. Often, the Trivisonnos, who are Catholics, would go to the cathedral and pray — for family, friends and peace.

title: Nick Cave Will Take a Selfie With You, if You Insist
description: On a bright and chilly fall afternoon in Dublin, the Australian musician Nick Cave strode down a wide street across from St. Stephen’s Green on his way to a knitwear shop.

title: What Alice Munro Knew
description: “My life has gone rosy, again,” Alice Munro told a friend in a buoyant letter of March 1975. For Munro, who was then emerging as one of her generation’s leading writers, the previous few years were blighted by heartbreak and upheaval: a painful separation from her husband of two decades; a retreat from British Columbia back to her native Ontario; a series of brief but bruising love affairs, in which, it seems, Munro could never quite make out the writing on the wall. “This time it’s real,” she wrote, speaking of a new romantic partner, the emphasis acknowledging that her friend had heard these words before. “He’s 50, free, a good man if I ever saw one, tough and gentle like in the old tire ads, and this is the big thing — grown-up.”

title: From Tarot Cards to Streamlined Design, We Can’t Stop Predicting the Future
description: God bless Donald Fagen for cursing out the “Yacht Rock” “dock”-umentarians. And God bless Fagen for writing the best song about the past’s vision of the future and how it all went sour: “I.G.Y. (What a Beautiful World),” named after the international geophysical year 1957-58, when scientists around the world collaborated on ambitious discovery projects.

title: Scrubbing Up for a Peek at the Resuscitated Notre-Dame Cathedral
description: When Michael Kimmelman, the architecture critic for The New York Times, stepped inside the storied Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris last summer he was amazed. Awe-inspired, even. He was also in a head-to-toe white scrub suit, with rubber boots and a hard hat.

title: How I Aged Into the Bad Christmas Movie
description: When I first discovered the existence of made-for-television Christmas movies, maybe 15 years ago, they struck me as sentimental and anti-feminist. Also, they seemed to be made for older people. The leads were always floundering in midlife until their romantic and professional lives were reformed through the magic of Christmas. Then, one December morning, I awoke to find that I had transformed into the target demographic. I am older now, and the movies are made just for me.

title: For Taylor Swift, It’s the End of the ‘Eras’
description: Anyone with an ear tuned to the world of pop music knew the Eras Tour was going to be a big one.

title: How Will Donald Trump’s Comeback Look on the Wall?
description: Outside the boardroom at The New York Times’s headquarters is a portrait gallery with every United States president since Theodore Roosevelt. Each picture is autographed or personalized in some way. The 45th president signed his photo to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr., who was then the publisher: “Arthur — Great being with you — MAGA!” The 46th president signed his portrait: “NYT — A free press is the rock upon which democracy is built. Keep the faith!”

title: Commerce Dept. Is on the Front Lines of China Policy
description: The Commerce Department has traditionally focused on promoting the interests of American business and increasing U.S. exports abroad. But in recent years, it has taken on a national security role, working to defend the country by restricting exports of America’s most powerful computer chips.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,269
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Climate Activists Need to Radically Change Their Approach Under Trump
description: Donald Trump’s return to Washington might seem like a terrifying moment for the fight against climate change. The incoming administration is not just hostile to the energy transition; it’s also expected to pull the United States out of the Paris climate agreement, roll back a wide range of pollution regulations and promote domestic fossil fuel production — decisions likely to worsen global warming.

title: A New Movie Dares to Suggest that Motherhood Might Be (Gasp) Fun
description: Motherhood has a branding problem. According to a recent Pew Research Center study, a growing share of adults under 50 say they probably won’t have children, and women are even less interested than men. There are plenty of practical reasons — the cost of living and concerns about the environment top the list — but the collective cultural drumbeat about just how much motherhood stinks is no doubt playing a part.

title: The Tennessee Trans Treatment Case Is About Age, Not Sex
description: I cannot begin to imagine the pain of feeling that your body does not match your gender. I cannot imagine the pain of parenting a child in such distress. Americans should feel immense sympathy for individuals in those circumstances, and we should feel an urgent necessity to treat children’s pain in the safest and most effective way possible.

title: What Doctors Like Me Know About Americans’ Health Care Anger
description: I rushed around the patient as he lay motionless with his eyes closed in the emergency room. He was pale and sweaty, his T-shirt stained with vomit. You didn’t have to be a health-care worker to know that he was in a dire state. The beeps on the monitor told me his heart rate was dangerously slow. I told the man that he was going to be admitted to the hospital overnight.

title: A President Rejected by Voters Eight Years Ago Wins Election Again in Ghana
description: John Dramani Mahama, a former president of Ghana who was voted out of office eight years ago, staged a dramatic political comeback on Sunday after his main opponent conceded defeat in the West African country’s presidential election.

title: After Failed Martial Law, South Koreans Ask: Who’s in Charge?
description: South Korea’s government was paralyzed Sunday, mired in a new constitutional crisis after President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea clung to his office, but his own party’s leader suggested that he had already been ousted from power.

title: Assad’s Rule Ends
description: President Bashar al-Assad’s long and brutal reign in Syria has ended. After 13 years of civil war, Syria’s rebel fighters have stormed the capital, Damascus, and claimed victory.

title: Bill Clinton on the Election, D.E.I. and One of His Regrets
description: A month after losing the presidential election, Democrats are still unpacking what went wrong. Speaking at the DealBook Summit on Wednesday, former President Bill Clinton blamed a lack of time.

title: Who Is the Leader of Syria’s Rebel Offensive?
description: After attracting little notice for years, Abu Mohammad al-Jolani spearheaded a stunning lightning offensive that led to the fall over the weekend of the regime of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria after over 13 years of brutal civil war.

title: S.N.L. Resurrects Church Lady: Isn’t That Special!
description: A quick primer for the younger readers of this recap: The late 1980s were a creatively fruitful time for “Saturday Night Live” where for some reason every third sketch was a fake talk show. Among the most popular of these recurring bits was a segment called “Church Chat,” in which a piously persnickety host known simply as the Church Lady (played by Dana Carvey) would roast celebrities of the day and accuse pretty much everyone of working in the service of Satan.

title: As Syrian Government Loses Control, the Skies Above Go Quiet
description: For more than a decade of civil war, Syrians in rebel-held areas craned their necks to look at the sky — listening and fearing the sounds of an airplane engine or the whirring blades of a helicopter.

title: The Streets of My Country Are Full of Fury
description: Acts of disobedience are exploding in the streets of Georgia.

title: Art and A.I.: Parallel Worlds, Bound Together
description: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

title: Trump Says He Does Not Have Plans to Replace Fed Chair
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump said he had no plans to fire the chair of the Federal Reserve, Jerome H. Powell, addressing an uncertainty that has been hanging over the politically independent central bank.

title: Chiung Yao, Top Romance Novelist in Chinese-Speaking World, Dies at 86
description: Chiung Yao, a romance writer who published best-selling novels in the Chinese-speaking world and who helped shape the idea of romantic love there for generations, died on Wednesday at her home in New Taipei City, Taiwan. She was 86.

title: Biden and Family of Austin Tice, Journalist Long Missing in Syria, Believe He Is Alive
description: President Biden and the family of Austin Tice, an American journalist who disappeared in Syria in 2012, said on Sunday that they believe that he is alive and could be returned to the United States after rebels groups toppled the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Apple Sued for Failing to Curtail Child Sexual Abuse Material on iCloud
description: The abuse began when she was still an infant. A relative molested her, took photographs and swapped the images with others online. He allowed another man to spend time with her, multiplying the abuse.

title: 43,000 Ukrainian Soldiers Killed Since Russia Invaded, Zelensky Says
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Sunday that 43,000 Ukrainian soldiers had been killed and 370,000 wounded since Russia’s full-scale invasion began nearly three years ago. It was the first time in months that he had disclosed military casualty figures, a highly sensitive topic in Ukraine, particularly as Kyiv’s forces lose more ground to Russian troops.

title: Trump Signals an Aggressive Opening, Threatening ‘Jail’ for Cheney and Others
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump outlined an aggressive plan for opening his second term in an interview that aired on Sunday, vowing to move immediately to crack down on immigration and pardon his most violent supporters while threatening to lock up political foes like Liz Cheney.

title: Cacio e Pepe, Then Cacio e Pepe Again
description: Good morning. You could spend a lifetime perfecting cacio e pepe, the classic Roman pasta dish of cheese and black pepper mixed with spaghetti.

title: Will We Ever Elect a Woman as President?
description: To the Editor:

title: Angela Alvarez, Great-Grandmother Who Won a Latin Grammy, Dies at 97
description: Angela Alvarez, a Cuban-born singer and songwriter who, at age 95, became the oldest performer to win the Latin Grammy Award for best new artist, died on Friday in Baton Rouge, La., where she had settled after immigrating to the United States in the early 1960s. She was 97.

title: As Syrian Rebels Take Charge, Freeing Prisoners of Assad Is a Priority
description: For many Syrians, the fall of President Bashar al-Assad provides an opportunity — at last — to try to discover the fates of loved ones who disappeared into a notorious military prison that has become a symbol of human rights abuses under his rule.

title: Records Seized by Israel Show Hamas Presence in U.N. Schools
description: To his students, Ahmad al-Khatib was a deputy principal at an elementary school in Gaza run by the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees. To Hamas’s military wing, documents say, he was something else entirely: an infantryman operating out of the southern Gaza city of Khan Younis.

title: With Assad’s Fall, Iran’s ‘Axis of Resistance’ Unravels
description: Over the past four decades, Iran devoted its best military minds, billions of dollars and sophisticated weapons to a grand project — countering U.S. and Israeli power in the Middle East through what it called the “axis of resistance.”

title: New Image Shows Suspect in C.E.O. Shooting in Back of Taxi
description: The New York Police Department has released two new images of the man it believes fatally shot the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, including one showing him in the back seat of a taxi on the day of the shooting.

title: Nations and Leaders React to Toppling of Syria Regime
description: Global leaders reacted to the toppling of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria with cautious optimism and support for the Syrian people on Sunday.

title: Fact-Checking Trump on ‘Meet the Press’: Tariffs, Immigration and More
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump, in his first sit-down broadcast interview since his re-election last month, repeated several false and inaccurate claims on a range of topics that were staples of his 2024 campaign.

title: Bogged Down in Ukraine, Russia Pays a Price in Syria
description: Lines of Russian troops in desert khaki greeted President Vladimir V. Putin in Syria in 2017. Declaring that Moscow had accomplished its mission in Syria’s civil war, Mr. Putin pledged that Russia was there to stay.

title: The Campaign by Syrian Rebels to Topple Assad Was Swift
description: The government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, which had kept rebel forces at bay for more than a decade with Iranian and Russian military support, collapsed with astonishing speed on Sunday morning after an advance by opposition forces on the capital, Damascus.

title: The Winners and Losers Following the Fall of al-Assad
description: The stunning collapse of the brutal Assad regime in Syria, a family business since the 1970s, is a geopolitical earthquake creating winners and losers around the world. First, the losers:

title: What’s Next for Syria After the Collapse of Assad’s Government?
description: The collapse of the government of President Bashar al-Assad has sparked jubilation inside Syria and beyond, but it has also plunged the country into deep uncertainty.

title: Trump Suggests Kennedy Will Examine Debunked Link Between Vaccines and Autism
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump, who has promoted the debunked theory that vaccines cause autism for more than a decade, suggested on Sunday that he would have his choice for health secretary, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., look into the issue.

title: Space Age Blues and the ‘Dancing Spirit’ of Judith Jamison
description: When the curtain rises on “Al-Andalus Blues,” Jamar Roberts’s new work for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, it does so deliberately and unwaveringly, as if building drama before a big reveal. In this mysterious tableau, a group is planted on and around a glowing rock formation. (It looked like a lumpy mattress.) One figure draws the eye: Hannah Alissa Richardson, a dancer and a warrior rolled into one. Her arms serpentine around her. She looks like a flame.

title: Syrians in Lebanon Start to Head Home, With Both Joy and Worry
description: They poured by the thousands into the street outside Lebanon’s main border crossing with Syria, celebrating the toppling of the Assad regime — and their long-awaited return home.

title: Biden Weighs Approach to Rebels in Syria Amid Secret Message Exchange
description: For President Biden, the fall of Syria’s tyrant on Sunday was a moment to cheer what he called a “fundamental act of justice” and to claim a measure of credit for his own policy.

title: The Assad Family’s Legacy Is One of Savage Oppression
description: Over decades, ghastly, chilling images from Syria have cemented the Assad family’s legacy of savagely oppressing the country’s population.

title: Syria’s Army Was Hollowing Out Long Before Rebels’ Advance
description: For years, Syrian soldiers have been complaining on Facebook about their bosses. Commanders who took bribes in exchange for leave. Leaders who ordered soldiers to loot. Officers who stole their troops’ food or got drunk on the job.

title: The Connections Companion No. 547
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Five Quick Takes on Regime Change in Syria
description: For the past few weeks, I have been arguing that Israel has inflicted the equivalent of a Six Day War-level defeat on Iran and its resistance network, and this would have vast consequences. Well, irony of ironies, the Assad family in Syria took power in 1971, in part because of Syria’s devastating defeat in the 1967 war. What goes around comes around.

title: Marvin Laird, Musical Presence on and Off Broadway, Dies at 85
description: Marvin Laird, a conductor for Broadway musicals and for performers like Bernadette Peters and the composer of the music for “Ruthless!,” the campy, award-winning Off Broadway show about a girl who will do anything — including kill — to star in a school play, died on Dec. 2 in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 85.

title: Judge Pauses Sexual Abuse Lawsuit Against Trump’s Education Secretary Pick
description: A federal judge in Maryland has paused a lawsuit against Linda McMahon, the former World Wrestling Entertainment executive whom President-elect Trump chose for education secretary, while another court weighs a recent state law involving such cases.

title: With Assad Gone, a Brutal Dictatorship Ends. But the New Risks Are Huge.
description: For years, the American strategic map of the Middle East was dominated by Iran at the center of power of a “Shia crescent,” with Syria as the funnel for the Iranian arms used by terrorism groups to attack Israel, and as the home to Russia’s naval and air presence in the region.

title: Threatened With Jail, Cheney Condemns Trump’s ‘Assault on the Rule of Law’
description: Former Representative Liz Cheney on Sunday called President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threat to imprison her and other members of a congressional committee that investigated the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol an “assault on the rule of law and the foundations of our republic.”

title: Monday Briefing: Al-Assad Flees Syria as Rebels Claim Power
description: President Bashar al-Assad has resigned and fled Syria for Russia, according to Russian state news media outlets, a stunning fall for a longtime dictator who had kept rebel forces at bay for years with the help of Moscow and Tehran. Follow for live updates here.

title: Israeli Ground Forces Cross into Syria, Officials Say
description: Israeli ground forces advanced beyond the demilitarized zone on the Israel-Syria border over the weekend, marking their first overt entry into Syrian territory since the 1973 October War, according to two Israeli officials speaking anonymously to discuss sensitive developments.

title: Humdrum Routines
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Notre-Dame Holds First Public Mass in Years: ‘Fire Has Not Conquered Stone’
description: Many Parisians can tell you exactly what they were doing when they heard that Notre-Dame was burning five years ago.

title: Steve Mensch, President of Tyler Perry Studios, Dies at 62
description: Steve Mensch, a film executive in Georgia who pushed for state policies to support the industry and who was the president of Tyler Perry Studios, died in a plane crash in Florida on Friday. He was 62.

title: Syrians in New York City Celebrate the Fall of Assad
description: Around 100 people gathered in Washington Square Park in Lower Manhattan on Sunday afternoon to celebrate the fall of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, who fled his country after rebel forces stormed the capital earlier in the day.

title: Stunned Iranian Officials Try to Distance Their Country From Assad
description: Iranians watched in astonishment over the weekend as the reign of their nation’s longtime political and military ally, Bashar al-Assad, came to a crashing end. By Sunday, the reckoning had arrived as officials and pundits recognized that Iran was taken by surprise, and they hurried to distance Iran from a tyrant the country had supported in maintaining power.

title: With Syria in Flux, Turkish Forces Attack U.S.-Backed Forces
description: The Turkish military fired on U.S.-backed Kurdish forces in northern Syria this weekend, a war monitoring group and a spokesman for the Kurdish group said on Sunday, illuminating the tangle of competing interests and alliances in Syria in the wake of the government’s collapse.

title: The Call
description: On This Week’s Episode:

title: Trump Picks Former Ambassador to Mexico for Deputy Secretary of State
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump announced on Sunday that he had picked Christopher Landau, a lawyer and former ambassador to Mexico, to be the deputy secretary of state.

title: Jay-Z, Accused in Suit of Raping Minor With Sean Combs, Calls It Blackmail
description: Jay-Z was accused of raping a 13-year-old girl with Sean Combs in a lawsuit filed Sunday by an unnamed plaintiff. He vehemently denied the allegation and accused the lawyer who brought the suit of trying to blackmail him with false claims.

title: Quotation of the Day: Flying at Extremes May Hurt Navy Pilots’ Brains
description: “Those turns look graceful from the ground, but inside the cockpit you are vibrating like crazy and fighting to stay conscious.”

title: ‘Dune: Prophecy’ Season 1, Episode 4 Recap: Ol’ Blue Eyes
description: Two blue lights shine in the darkness, like the eyes of an insectoid machine. Guttural sounds, like speech in a language not yet invented, accompany them, but only for a second.

title: ‘Dune: Prophecy’: Travis Fimmel on His Character’s Fiery Rise to the Top
description: This interview contains mild spoilers for Season 1, Episode 4 of “Dune: Prophecy.”

title: Minnesota Vikings Find Unlikely Muse for Celebration Dance: ‘White Chicks’
description: If you don’t remember, “White Chicks” was a 2004 comedy in which the Black actors Marlon and Shawn Wayans donned heavy makeup to disguise themselves as white women.

title: Massacre in Haiti’s Capital Leaves Nearly 200 Dead, U.N. Says
description: More than 180 people were killed in a massacre over the weekend in one of the poorest neighborhoods of Haiti’s capital, the United Nations’ human rights chief said on Monday.

title: The Art of the Gift: Kristen Arnett
description: Kristen Arnett, 43, is the New York Times best-selling author of “Mostly Dead Things” and “With Teeth.” Her next novel, “Stop Me If You’ve Heard This One,” is due to publish in March. She lives in Orlando, Fla. This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.

title: Britain’s Flawed Jobs Reports Leave Economists ‘Second-Guessing’
description: An essential ingredient in economic policymaking, from interest rates to government spending, is reliable data. But government officials, economists and other number crunchers in Britain are expressing deepening concern over a long-running issue with a data set used to understand a crucial area: the country’s jobs market.

title: India’s Luxury Property Market Is a Boon to Trump’s Business
description: When Donald J. Trump started his first campaign for the presidency, two Trump-branded buildings were going up in India, one in the financial capital of Mumbai and the other nearby in Pune. Before he won in 2016, the Trump Organization expanded its business in India, signing deals in two more big cities.

title: Revolutions Swept the Middle East in 2011. Will Syria’s End Differently?
description: When protesters started trying in 2011 to overthrow President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, they were part of a cascade of revolutions, known as the Arab Spring, that aimed to oust authoritarian leaders across the Middle East.

title: Monday Briefing
description: In a stunning fall, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has fled to Russia, state media there and two Iranian officials said yesterday, after he lost his hold on power to a lightning fast offensive by rebels. Here’s the latest.

title: She Won Over Italy. Now She’s Bringing Trumpism to Europe.
description: Unless Donald Trump decides to communicate with European allies solely in the acerbic language of tariffs, he will have to address the famous question usually attributed to Henry Kissinger: Whom do I call when I want to talk to Europe?

title: ‘The Creep Tapes’ Finale, Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV This Week
description: Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that are broadcast live or available for streaming this week, Dec. 9 to Dec. 15. Details and times are subject to change.

title: Al-Assad’s Syria Was Brutal. Will What Comes Next Be Better?
description: It is hard not to rejoice while watching images of ecstatic Syrians toppling statues from the regime of the deposed dictator Bashar al-Assad and hearing the shouts of joy of prisoners, many of whom may have been tortured and starved, released from his dungeons. Mr. al-Assad’s Syria was brutal for the regime’s opponents, and 13 years of civil war and a kleptocratic regime made life dangerous and miserable for ordinary Syrians. In addition to striking a blow for human freedom, Mr. al-Assad’s fall also removes an Iranian-backed, anti-American and anti-Israel dictator from the Middle East chessboard.

title: South Korea Bars President From Traveling Abroad
description: South Korea’s political dysfunction deepened Monday as its Ministry of Justice barred President Yoon Suk Yeol from leaving the country while officials investigate whether his brief declaration of martial law last week amounted to leading an insurrection.

title: Word of the Day: permafrost
description: The word permafrost has appeared in 32 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 30 in “The Right Kind of Tipping Point” by David Gelles:

title: How a Criminal With Close Ties to China Became a New York Power Broker
description: On a Monday in March, in the heart of China’s capital, more than 2,000 delegates of a rubber-stamp advisory body to the authoritarian government of President Xi Jinping gathered for their annual meeting.

title: An Elite School and the Criminal It Hired to Teach Math
description: Less than a month into Winston Nguyen’s teaching career at Saint Ann’s, an elite private school in Brooklyn, his eighth-grade students discovered that he was a felon.

title: Three-Quarters of Earth’s Land Got Drier in Recent Decades, U.N. Says
description: From the American West to eastern China, more than three-quarters of Earth’s land became persistently drier in recent decades, according to a new United Nations report that called the shift a “global, existential peril.”

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

title: Road to Damascus Littered With Relics of Fallen Assad Government
description: We arrived in Damascus early Monday, after passing surreal scenes on the highway leading into the city from Lebanon. Scattered across the main highway to the Syrian capital are newfound relics of the government of Bashar al-Assad whose oppressive rule has defined the country for decades.

title: ‘We Came Here Gloating’: Syrians Loot Assad’s Palace
description: Thrilled by the fall of President Bashar al-Assad, Syrians took furniture and appliances from his official residence. Some posed for photos.

title: What Kind of Cat Litter Is Best for the Planet?
description: House training cats is easy. Most will use a litter box instinctively before they’re a month old. But what’s the environmental cost of the litter they’ll need over the years?

title: How to Multiply the Power of Women and Girls in Africa
description: I got my start in journalism in Kenya. Before I became a reporter, I spent more than a year as a volunteer teacher in a classroom for children who couldn’t afford real school. I had arrived in the town of Machakos, an hour outside Nairobi, determined to teach the kids who spent their days begging outside the supermarket. I realized that there was a Kenyan teacher, Alex Zakayo Mutiso, who was already doing that, so I became his unpaid intern. Every morning, I walked the dusty red roads to his classroom at the top of a hill, where the children came for the bowls of githeri, a dish made with corn and beans, but stayed to learn how to read and write.

title: How to Avoid Pickpockets and Street Scams
description: Street theft isn’t petty to a victim. Having your pocket picked or bags stolen can ruin your trip and your finances.

title: Spying on Student Devices, Schools Aim to Intercept Self-Harm Before It Happens
description: Dawn was still hours away when Angel Cholka was awakened by the beams of a police flashlight through the window. At the door was an officer, who asked if someone named Madi lived there. He said he needed to check on her. Ms. Cholka ran to her 16-year-old’s bedroom, confused and, suddenly, terrified.

title: 3-D Mammograms Are Overtaking Traditional Scans. But Are They Better?
description: Women going in for routine mammograms are increasingly being screened with a new type of imaging tool: digital breast tomosynthesis.

title: Curbside Composting: What to Do and What Not to Do
description: This fall, New York City expanded its curbside composting program to all five boroughs, good news for New Yorkers looking to lessen their environmental footprint. As part of the program, residents must now separate their food scraps and yard waste from other garbage and place them in a bin for pickup.

title: Ukraine Asks if Telegram, Its Favorite App, Is a Sleeper Agent
description: In the nearly three years since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the messaging app Telegram has been a lifeline for millions of Ukrainians. It provides information about coming attacks and helps communities organize food, medical aid and other support.

title: Best Theater of 2024
description: Broadway always looks its healthiest around the holidays, and indeed, right now, most of its 41 theaters are lit, with the rest soon set to load in new tenants. Box office grosses, if not quite back to prepandemic levels, seem likely to meet or exceed last year’s $1.6 billion. But the real health of the commercial theater, for me, is demonstrated by how much it offers its audiences, not its investors. That’s why, most years, my list of best shows is top-heavy with the provocative work being brewed Off Broadway. If my latest list tilts the other way, perhaps that reflects Broadway’s liberal borrowings from the noncommercial sector — borrowings and often improvements. My Top 10, listed chronologically and covering the period from December 2023 through the end of November, are therefore mostly shows that, wherever they started and wherever they wind up, put a premium on provocation, sure, but also entertainment. That’s what I call healthy.

title: 9 Best Theater Moments of 2024
description: Climate protesters disrupting a performance of “An Enemy of the People,” the outdoor walking scene in “Sunset Boulevard” and the giggles prompted by a character’s reaction to a hunky celebrity’s glutes in “Hold On to Me Darling”: The rewards of live theater were aplenty this year. Here, nine other stage moments that especially stood out, listed chronologically.

title: How Some Voters Moved From Bernie Sanders to Donald Trump
description: They feel frustrated by the status quo, and they’re fed up with the system. They don’t trust politicians, and they want revolutionary change.

title: Desperate Haitians Who Fled to the Dominican Republic Are Being Sent Back in Cages
description: Cage-like trucks fitted with iron bars that appear designed to carry livestock line up every morning at the border between Haiti and the Dominican Republic.

title: Stephanie Koenig and Her Three Rings
description: In the car on the way to her first proposal, Stephanie Koenig, who stars in “English Teacher” on Hulu, asked her soon-to-be fiancé, Chris Riggi, “You’re not proposing, are you?”

title: Chinese Carmakers Are Taking Mexico by Storm While Eyeing U.S.
description: Behind a crumbling brick wall in a working-class neighborhood of Mexico City lurks a seemingly innocuous car lot. But it could be a sign of a potentially grave threat to the North American auto industry.

title: Best Songs of 2024
description: Here’s a dipperful of worthwhile tracks from the ocean of music released this year. The top of my list is big-statement songs, ones that had repercussions beyond how they sound. Below those, it’s not a ranking but a playlist, a more-or-less guided cruise through what 2024 sounded like for one avid listener. I didn’t include any songs from my list of top albums, which are worth hearing from start to finish. But in the multiverse of streaming music, there are plenty of other possibilities.

title: The Most Popular Recipes of 2024
description: Well, that was fast: It was January, we blinked and now it’s December. Quite a bit has happened in the last 300 or so days, and the team at New York Times Cooking created, tested and published about 1,000 delicious recipes to help you eat well through it all. Your favorites — the dishes you added to your rotation, the meals your kids actually (OK, mostly) ate, the dinners you were excited to cook — are below. Once again, the three Cs (comfort, convenience and chicken) were king. You can view the complete list of our 50 most popular recipes here. Find one you haven’t cooked yet, and try it tonight. Happy cooking and Happy New Year.

title: Running Spies Is Not a Game for Amateurs
description: President-elect Donald Trump’s promises to destroy what he calls the “deep state” predate his first term in the White House. The sentiment raises fears in the intelligence community that there will be purges of career professionals, and that intelligence designed to protect American lives will be twisted to fit Mr. Trump’s personal interests.

title: $3 Million Homes in California
description: This four-bedroom, three-and-a-half bathroom house, made of steel, concrete and walls of glass, is in the Brickyard Cove neighborhood, once home to the Richmond Brick Company. Directly on the San Francisco Bay, the house has a large private dock and a smaller one for guests, and both the nearby Brickyard Marina and the Richmond Yacht Club are easily reachable by boat. A brewery is a five-minute drive, as are a handful of convenience stores, while downtown Berkeley takes 25 minutes.

title: Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour Grand Total: A Record $2 Billion
description: For the last 21 months, Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour has been the biggest thing in music — a phenomenon that has engulfed pop culture, dominated news coverage and boosted local economies around the world.

title: One of Japan’s Great Sushi Masters Is Working, Quietly, in Manhattan
description: An iron law of sushi holds that the more impressive the restaurant, the smaller the sign.

title: A Comedian’s Path From Small-Town Tennessee to Breakout Fame
description: On many insomniac nights, when I’m trying to quiet the voices in my head, I listen to stand-up comics. I’ve been back and forth through Netflix’s roster: the blue-collar and the big city, the clean and the crude, the capital-W woke and the close-to-canceled, the ironists and the oafs, the oldies and the mere pups.

title: The Power Struggle Behind Trans Youth Health Care
description: In this episode of “The Opinions,” the New York Times Opinion columnists Lydia Polgreen and M. Gessen discuss the historic Supreme Court case United States v. Skrmetti, its implications for gender-affirming care for minors in Tennessee and what it could mean for how the federal government interprets “equal rights” moving forward.

title: The Killings of Young Mothers
description: For women under 25, getting pregnant more than doubles their risk of homicide.

title: Pardon You
description: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. Do you think it would be a good idea if Joe Biden gave presidential pardons to us in advance — as well as anyone else Donald Trump might go after once he’s back in office?

title: Should Lessons Based on the Bible Be Taught in Public Schools?
description: In June, Louisiana passed a mandate that the Ten Commandments be displayed in every public classroom. Days later, Oklahoma’s state superintendent directed every public school to teach the Bible. And last month, Texas education officials approved a new elementary school curriculum that includes lessons based on the Bible.

title: How Can I Make Corduroy Look Cool?
description: Corduroy is one of those materials that have been with us for so long that it has acquired a whole encyclopedia’s worth of cultural references.

title: How to Keep Your Own Soul Safe in the Dark
description: A few days before Thanksgiving, my husband and I finally moved our indoor plants back indoors. In years past we brought them inside in late September, just to be safe, because in those days frost often fell in early October, and a killing freeze inevitably came by the end of the month. This year, the first killing freeze finally came on Nov. 30, our latest first freeze in history. My indoor plants have become outdoor plants for all but four months of the year.

title: E.P.A. Bans Cancer-Causing Chemicals Used in Dry Cleaning
description: The Environmental Protection Agency on Monday banned two solvents found in everyday products that can cause cancer and other serious diseases. It was a move long sought by environmental and health advocates, even as they braced for what could be a wave of deregulation by the incoming Trump administration.

title: A Century-Old Law’s Aftershocks Are Still Felt at the Supreme Court
description: Almost exactly a century ago, in February 1925, Chief Justice William Howard Taft persuaded Congress to grant the Supreme Court an extraordinary power: to pick which cases it would decide.

title: Why Street Vendors Are Upset About a Ballot Measure
description: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at some concerns from street vendors about Proposition 2, one of the ballot measures approved by New York City voters last month.

title: China Eases Overall Monetary Policy Stance for First Time in 14 Years
description: China’s ruling Politburo loosened the country’s overall monetary policy on Monday for the first time in 14 years, the latest in a series of measures aimed at recharging economic growth and stopping a broad decline in prices.

title: France’s First Big #MeToo Case Goes to Trial
description: She accused him of isolating her during rehearsals and filming. Of grooming her for three years, when on Saturday afternoons he would touch her sexually. When it began, he was 36. She was 12.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,270
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Syria’s New Reality, and Trump Lays Out Aggressive Agenda
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: Inside the Fall of Syria’s Brutal Dictator
description: Syria has been controlled by one family for more than half a century. It ruled by repression, devastation and violence.

title: Iran’s Very Bad Year
description: Most questions about Syria’s future don’t have clear answers. Will the Islamist rebels who have taken over the country create a harsh Taliban-style government? Or do the rebels’ recent hints of moderation point toward something gentler? The situation remains uncertain.

title: Israel Claims Credit for al-Assad’s Ouster, but Sees Risk in His Absence
description: For the past year, Israel’s allies and enemies pressed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to limit his attacks on Iran and its partners in Lebanon and Syria, hoping to avoid a regional escalation.

title: Syrians Displaced by War Rush to Return Home
description: When Abdo Bakri returned to his hometown in northwestern Syria on Saturday after more than five years roaming the area in search of safe shelter for his family during the country’s civil war, he did not know what he would find.

title: Dries Van Noten Names a New Dries Van Noten
description: A new creative power structure in fashion is beginning to emerge. On Monday, five months after Dries Van Noten (the man) shocked the style world by retiring, Dries Van Noten (the brand) named Julian Klausner as its new creative director, elevating a longtime member of the design team to the top post.

title: China Opens Investigation Into Nvidia Over Potential Antitrust Violations
description: China’s antimonopoly regulator announced on Monday that it was investigating potential violations of antitrust law by Nvidia, the American company that makes a vast majority of the computer chips that power artificial intelligence systems.

title: Two Major Ad Agencies to Merge, Creating Global Giant
description: Omnicom Group, one of the world’s largest advertising agencies, said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Interpublic Group, a large rival.

title: Golden Globes 2025: The Full List of Nominees
description: The nominations for the 82nd Golden Globes were announced Monday, and “Emilia Pérez” and “The Brutalist” are the top nominees.

title: Trump Gives Powell a Reprieve, but Pledges Big Moves Elsewhere
description: President-elect Donald Trump used his first broadcast interview since the election to promise a fast-moving and disruptive administration that could shake up American and global business, including raising tariffs and cutting immigration.

title: A Surprise Advance to Damascus, Captured on Video
description: A brazen nighttime prison release. Presidential posters set on fire. Children playing in the halls of a palace once controlled by the former regime.

title: No Corrections: Dec. 9, 2024
description: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

title: Matea Gold Named Washington Editor of The New York Times
description: Matea Gold, a managing editor at The Washington Post who until recently was a contender for the newspaper’s top editing role, is joining The New York Times as a senior editor in its Washington bureau.

title: Explosion at Fuel Depot Near Florence Kills at Least Two
description: At least two people were killed and another 26 injured Monday in an explosion at a fuel depot on the outskirts of Florence, according to city officials and the company that ran the facility. The cause of the explosion had not yet been determined, the company said.

title: Crowds Throng to Prison in Syria, Desperate to Find Relatives and Friends
description: Crowds descended on a prison on the outskirts of Damascus, the Syrian capital, on Monday, desperate to learn the fate of friends and relatives detained at a place that symbolized terror and death under the regime of President Bashar al-Assad.

title: New York City Council Sues Adams for Blocking Solitary Confinement Ban
description: The New York City Council filed a lawsuit on Monday seeking to force Mayor Eric Adams to carry out a law banning solitary confinement in city jails.

title: ‘Emilia Pérez’ Tops Golden Globe Nominations
description: The point of the Golden Globes has become clearer in recent years: It’s a cash register masquerading as an awards show — an opportunity to sell advertising, promote winter movies and flog designer gowns.

title: Nobody Is Coming to Save Us
description: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

title: Do You Know These Winter Holidays and Popular Books of the Season?
description: Celebrate the literature of this festive month with with a five-question quiz that comes with its own reading list.

title: This Race Was Decided by 734 Votes. The G.O.P. Wants to Disqualify 60,000 Ballots.
description: From voter ID laws to district map-drawing to judges redeciding cases, North Carolina has long been a laboratory of sorts in ways to amass political power. In recent years, Republicans in particular have changed both state laws and election rules to hamstring Democrats’ influence.

title: 24 Things That Happened for the First Time in 2024
description: This feature is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

title: A Quick Arab Pivot: From Welcoming al-Assad to Managing the Chaos
description: Only weeks ago, Sunni Arab nations, led by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, were trying to bring President Bashar al-Assad of Syria back into the fold, urging him to break with a weakened Iran.

title: Golden Globes 2025 Snubs and Surprises: Danielle Deadwyler, ‘The Substance’ and More
description: The 82nd Golden Globes nominations were announced Monday morning and the unconventional musical “Emilia Pérez” had plenty to sing about: The Netflix film topped all movies with 10 nominations, followed by “The Brutalist” and “Conclave.” Here are some of the most notable takeaways from this year’s field.

title: Lara Trump to Step Down as R.N.C. Co-Chair Amid Florida Senate Speculation
description: Lara Trump, whose name has been floated to fill a possible Senate vacancy in Florida, is stepping down as co-chair of the Republican National Committee.

title: Your Running Form Matters Less Than You Think
description: Want to get better at tennis? Fine-tune your serve. Swimming? Perfect your stroke. But what about running? If you improve your form — from your posture to the way your foot hits the ground — will that make you faster and more efficient?

title: Give Your Salmon an Anchovy Butter Boost
description: Of all the ways to add oomph to weeknight cooking, the one I turn to most is anchovies. Honestly, I add them to pretty much everything short of ice cream, and I’ll go double if fish is on the menu. Tossing a couple of salty, saline anchovies into a pan of salmon or hake fillets is an easy move to bring out a deep umami funk that’s earthy rather than fishy.

title: Quantum Computing Inches Closer to Reality After Another Google Breakthrough
description: In 2019, a team of Google researchers said they had built a machine capable of performing tasks that were not possible with traditional supercomputers. They described this machine, called a quantum computer, as a turning point in the evolution of information technology.

title: How to Apply Makeup That Lasts
description: In this season of back-to-back parties, there’s an extra premium on makeup that stays put. That need for longevity is something that stage performers — who must contend with sweat, bright lights and hurried costume changes — understand well. We asked three people familiar with those challenges about the products and techniques they rely on. Below, tips from Valentino Beauty’s global makeup artist, Yadim; the cabaret artist Justin Vivian Bond, whose show “Flakes” opens Dec. 12 at Joe’s Pub in New York; and the musician Tinashe, now on tour with her latest album, “Quantum Baby.”

title: China’s Critical Minerals Embargo Is Even Tougher Than Expected
description: Alarm is rising among multinational companies doing business with China about Beijing’s decision last week to order a trade embargo on the export of four critical minerals to the United States. The central subject of concern is a provision extending the ban to companies in other countries that transfer minerals to American firms after acquiring them from China.

title: At the Kennedy Center, a Send-Off to Biden and Questions About the Future
description: The arrival of the president to the center box is typically a pro forma affair each year at the Kennedy Center Honors. But President Biden’s arrival on Sunday night carried the tinge of a Washington on the verge of change.

title: Expanding the Laws on Assisted Dying
description: To the Editor:

title: What Syria Needs in Order to Rebuild
description: After more than a decade of war, everything about Syria’s political landscape has changed in the space of 72 hours. Now U.S. sanctions policy must change with it.

title: In Syria, an Image of Rebellion Embodied in a Hoodie
description: The rebels appeared on Syrian state television over the weekend in puffer jackets and sweatshirts. One wore what appeared to be a trucker hat. A man in the center — the group’s appointed spokesman — wore a black hoodie as he addressed the Syrian people.

title: Daniel Penny Is Acquitted in Death of Jordan Neely on Subway
description: Daniel Penny, a former Marine who choked a fellow subway rider on an uptown F train last year, was acquitted on a charge of criminally negligent homicide on Monday, ending a case that had come to exemplify New York City’s post-pandemic struggles.

title: Who Is Alina Habba, the Lawyer Trump Picked to Serve as Counselor to the President?
description: Alina Habba, who President-elect Donald J. Trump said would serve as a counselor to the president in the White House during his second term, has advised him on legal matters since he left office in 2021.

title: How a Realtors’ Nonprofit Quietly Funds Conservative Advocacy Groups
description: The National Association of Realtors — the largest trade organization in the United States — wields substantial influence over the American housing industry. To help hold on to that power, it also runs one of the biggest political action committees, routinely outspending even major companies like Amazon.

title: U.S. Investigating Child Labor Claim at HelloFresh Subsidiary
description: The U.S. Labor Department is investigating allegations that migrant children have worked at a meal preparation delivery facility in Illinois that is a subsidiary of the popular meal kit company HelloFresh, the company and federal regulators said.

title: Activists Call on Biden to Clear Death Row Before Trump Takes Office
description: A group of human rights activists, former corrections officials and families of crime victims asked President Biden on Monday to use his clemency power to take all 40 inmates off federal death row before he hands over power to President-elect Donald J. Trump.

title: After N.R.A.’s Supreme Court Win, a Dispute Over Key Facts
description: Earlier this year, the sharply divided Supreme Court came together to decide unanimously in favor of the National Rifle Association. The N.R.A., the justices ruled, could pursue its claim that a New York State regulator had infringed on its First Amendment rights when she sought to discourage insurers and banks from doing business with the gun group after the 2018 school massacre in Parkland, Fla.

title: Elaine May Makes a Rare Appearance to Talk About ‘Mikey and Nicky’
description: At Metrograph theater on Friday, a crowd of around 175 people was treated to the cinephile’s equivalent of a Bigfoot sighting on the Lower East Side: A rare public appearance by the 92-year-old writer, director and actress Elaine May.

title: A Contemporary Music Festival Trolls for Aesthetics’ Sake
description: Recently, the London Contemporary Music Festival released a limited run of merchandise. There was a graphic T-shirt featuring the names of musicians whose creations have appeared at past festivals, plotted on a graph with two axes: the Y labeled “twee” to “brutal,” and the X “top” to “bottom.” Brian Ferneyhough was a brutal top, Cornelius Cardew a twee bottom, and Laurie Anderson was somewhere in between.

title: Arts Patron Aims to Help Underrepresented Museum Professionals
description: In the fall of 2020, the arts patron Allison Berg listened to the book “From Generosity to Justice: A New Gospel of Wealth” by the Ford Foundation president Darren Walker. She had what she called a lightbulb moment, “hearing Darren speak to the difference between band-aiding a problem and actually taking action to influence systemic change toward equity and justice.”

title: Judge Denies Nadine Menendez’s Request to Postpone Trial Further
description: Nadine Menendez arrived at federal court in Manhattan on Monday without her husband, New Jersey’s disgraced former U.S. senator, her right arm in a sling and her face largely covered by a pink surgical mask.

title: TikTok Asks Court to Temporarily Freeze Sale-or-Ban Law
description: TikTok asked a federal court on Monday to temporarily freeze a law that requires its Chinese parent company to sell the app or face a ban in the United States, as it looked to the Supreme Court and the incoming Trump administration to rescue it.

title: Supreme Court Turns Down Cases on Admissions, Gender Identity and Guns
description: The Supreme Court on Monday turned away cases on admissions policies, gender identity and gun control, eliciting objections from conservative justices that suggested rifts on the court about whether and when to address major questions left open by recent decisions.

title: How Old Is Too Old to Be President? Democrats Still Don’t Want to Say.
description: Voters long believed that President Biden was too old to seek a second term. The issue torpedoed his campaign and saddled his vice president with an extraordinarily short political runway.

title: Easy-to-Assemble Ghost Guns Have Been a Major Issue in Gun Control
description: The man held in the killing of a health care executive, arrested on firearms charges in Pennsylvania on Monday, possessed what investigators believe was a so-called ghost gun, said Joseph Kenny, the chief of detectives for the New York police.

title: Southern California Braces for Another ‘Particularly Dangerous’ Fire Forecast
description: Strong Santa Ana winds are expected to intensify the wildfire threat in Southern California early this week and create a “particularly dangerous situation” in Ventura and Los Angeles Counties, similar to circumstances in early November that helped fuel a significant wildfire, forecasters warned on Monday.

title: Trump Says He Would Let ‘Dreamers’ Stay. But He Once Tried to Gut the Program.
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has said he would look for ways to spare immigrants who were brought to the country illegally as children, known as Dreamers, from deportation.

title: New York Taxpayers Could Get Refunds of Up to $500 Under Hochul Plan
description: Looking ahead to next year’s state budget and, perhaps, her re-election race the following year, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York on Monday proposed sending $3 billion in “inflation refund” checks to most taxpayers.

title: Why I Still Send Holiday Cards — and You Should, Too
description: With every Christmas card I write, I’m dreaming of a white Christmas, but I’m also pondering “The Strength of Weak Ties,” a seminal 1973 paper by the sociologist Mark Granovetter, then of Johns Hopkins University, now of Stanford.

title: Rupert Murdoch Fails in Bid to Change Family Trust
description: A Nevada commissioner ruled resoundingly against Rupert Murdoch’s attempt to change his family’s trust to consolidate his eldest son Lachlan’s control of his media empire and lock in Fox News’s right-wing editorial slant, according to a sealed court document obtained by The New York Times.

title: Syria’s President Had Stocks of Chemical Weapons. What Happens to Them Now?
description: Rebels seized control of Syria’s capital on Sunday, ending the reign of Bashar al-Assad, who infamously used chemical weapons to kill thousands of his own citizens during the country’s 13-year-long civil war.

title: ‘Strong Person of Interest’ Is Arrested in Health Care C.E.O.’s Shooting
description: Luigi Mangione, 26, was arrested on gun charges and for questioning in connection with last week’s killing of a health insurance executive in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Events to Shake, or Gently Rattle, the World in 2025
description: This feature is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

title: Suspect in C.E.O. Shooting Had a Manifesto, Police Say
description: The man who was arrested on Monday in connection with the killing of the health care executive Brian Thompson was found with a handwritten document that spoke to his “motivation and mind-set,” Jessica Tisch, the commissioner of the New York Police Department, said at a news conference.

title: Suspect in C.E.O. Killing Showed Interest on Social Media in Self-Improvement
description: The social media accounts that appear to belong to Luigi Mangione, the man the police have identified as the suspect in the killing of Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, seemed to show an interest in self-improvement, clean eating and critiques of contemporary technology.

title: Review: Resistance and Struggle in a Dance of Private Rites
description: When I asked the man if the seat next to him was taken, he didn’t even open his eyes. That’s when I first wondered whether he might not be just another member of the audience.

title: The Most Memorable Things We Saw at Miami Art Week
description: The art fair Art Basel Miami Beach, and the satellite events that have emerged around it, collectively known as Miami Art Week, have been held the first week of December every year since 2002, except in 2020 because of the pandemic. But even that year, Libbie Mugrabi, the ex-wife of the art dealer David Mugrabi, riding high from an enormous divorce settlement, threw a lavish dinner at the Faena Hotel. (“I can do whatever I want with it,” she told The New York Times of the payout. “And this is what I want to do.”) Last week, one gallery owner from New York summed up the purpose of the fair to me succinctly: “I need to make money,” he said. Miami is especially good for gauging the mood of the art business, and the direction it might be heading in. Prices at art auctions have been declining over the past two years, but a lot of people did indeed make money. And there was some evocative art on view, too. Below are a few takeaways.

title: Why Chinese Americans Have Shifted Rightward
description: For the three decades after she became an American citizen, Annie Tan tried to stay out of the fray. Politics, she thought, was for politicians, not for “regular people” like her, a 71-year-old Chinese American immigrant from Taiwan living in Southern California.

title: Crowds Go to Syria’s Sednaya Prison In Search of Loved Ones
description: Rebel forces released many detainees from the notorious Sednaya military prison in Damascus. The government complex has a long history of human rights abuses under the rule of fallen President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Tuesday Briefing: Syrian Rebels Rush to Establish Order
description: The rebels who took over Damascus announced yesterday that a new government would begin work immediately, as millions of Syrians and the wider world struggled to process the stunning end to the Assad family’s decades-long reign. Rebel fighters took up positions outside public buildings and directed traffic in a show of their newly claimed authority. Here’s the latest.

title: Cease-Fire Talks Between Israel and Hamas Gain Momentum, Officials Say
description: Cease-fire talks between Israel and Hamas to end the war in Gaza and free the remaining hostages are quietly advancing behind the scenes, mediators and officials say, after the Israel-Hezbollah truce in Lebanon and pressure from President-elect Donald J. Trump.

title: U.S. Scrambles to Navigate Perils of a New Syria
description: The Biden administration is scrambling to find ways to engage with groups in Syria and around the Middle East as victorious militias begin shaping the nation’s future after the toppling of President Bashar al-Assad, the longtime autocrat.

title: Nobel Laureates Urge Senate to Turn Down Kennedy’s Nomination
description: More than 75 Nobel Prize winners have signed a letter urging senators not to confirm Robert F. Kennedy Jr., President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: 58 Jazz Luminaries Assembled for This Photo. Only One Remains.
description: Art Kane’s “Harlem 1958” gathered giants of the music. Sonny Rollins, 94, looks back at the historic picture.

title: Luigi Mangione, Suspect in C.E.O.’s Killing, Attended Elite Institutions
description: Luigi Mangione, 26, the man who was taken into custody Monday morning in Altoona, Pa., and identified as a suspect in the killing of the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare in Midtown Manhattan last Wednesday, appears to have been a well-educated and well-traveled enthusiast of computer programming and gaming with an interest in self-improvement.

title: The Mets Stole Juan Soto From the Yankees. Who’s the Big Spender Now?
description: Did you feel the ground shake Sunday night? Did New York suddenly tilt from the Bronx down to Queens?

title: Suspect Is Charged in C.E.O.’s Murder After Arrest in Pennsylvania
description: The tipster’s call to the local police came in shortly after 9 a.m. Monday from a McDonald’s in western Pennsylvania.

title: Read the Letter From Nobel Laureates Urging That Mr. Kennedy Not Be Confirmed
description: More than 75 laureates have written an open letter describing Mr. Kennedy’s selection for H.H.S. secretary as detrimental to public health.

title: Jay-Z Sued Lawyer as a ‘Celebrity’ John Doe Before Assault Accusation
description: Several weeks before Jay-Z was accused in a lawsuit of raping a minor with Sean Combs, he received a letter from a plaintiff’s lawyer threatening to “immediately file” a “public lawsuit” against him unless he agreed to resolve the matter through mediation for money, his lawyers said.

title: How Netflix Made Magic Look Real in ‘One Hundred Years of Solitude’
description: The first-ever screen adaptation will be released this week — a feat even the author didn’t think possible. We traveled to the set in Colombia to see how it was done.

title: Can Trump End Birthright Citizenship? Not Easily.
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has revived talk of abolishing birthright citizenship — the guarantee, rooted in common law and enshrined in the Constitution for more than 150 years, that anyone born in the United States is automatically an American citizen.

title: My Last Column: Finding Hope in an Age of Resentment
description: This is my final column for The New York Times, where I began publishing my opinions in January 2000. I’m retiring from The Times, not the world, so I’ll still be expressing my views in other places. But this does seem like a good occasion to reflect on what has changed over these past 25 years.

title: Trump Tests Ethical Boundaries With Branded Merch. (And All Sales Are Final.)
description: Donald J. Trump learned a long time ago that photo opportunities could get him attention and that slapping his name on everything from skyscrapers to steaks could make him money.

title: Suspect in C.E.O. Shooting Has Background in Games Industry
description: The digital footprint of Luigi Mangione, the suspect in the killing of a UnitedHealthcare executive last week, indicates that he has a background in the technology and video games industry.

title: Ernst, Under MAGA Pressure, Signals Backing for Hegseth’s Pentagon Bid
description: Senator Joni Ernst, Republican of Iowa, signaled on Monday that she would not oppose Pete Hegseth’s bid for defense secretary, hinting at a turnabout after days of hectoring and threats by President-elect Donald J. Trump’s hard-right supporters who threatened political retribution if she failed to fall into line.

title: Police Arrested a ‘Strong Person of Interest’ in Killing of C.E.O.
description: After a five-day manhunt, police arrested a man today in connection with the brazen killing of a health insurance executive last week in Midtown Manhattan. Here’s the latest.

title: Syrian Military Officials Charged With War Crimes as Government Falls
description: The Justice Department has charged two top Syrian military officials with war crimes committed against Americans and others at a notorious prison in Damascus during the Syrian civil war, according to an indictment unsealed on Monday.

title: A Test for the System
description: When the makers of “Schoolhouse Rock” set out in the 1970s to explain how the federal government works, they likened it to a three-ring circus. It was more than just a comment on the chaos of Washington — it was a metaphor for the three coequal branches of government that make our democracy what it is.

title: Shock, Glee and Unease as Syrians Celebrate the Unthinkable
description: Syrian security checkpoints sat empty on Monday across Damascus. Abandoned tanks were scattered across the roads, along with stray pieces of military uniforms stripped off by soldiers when opposition forces stormed into the city a day earlier.

title: Eyes, Not Tech, Led Police to Suspect in C.E.O. Killing
description: In the end, it was the simple act of distributing photos — not sophisticated facial recognition technology — that led the police to the man who has been charged in the fatal shooting of a health care executive in Midtown Manhattan last week.

title: Moderate Earthquake Rattles Reno and Lake Tahoe
description: Residents of Northern Nevada and the Lake Tahoe basin were rattled on Monday afternoon by an earthquake that struck southeast of Reno, Nev. Preliminary estimates showed that the quake had a magnitude of 5.8, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

title: Map: 5.7-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Nevada
description: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.

title: Leader of Polygamist Sect in Arizona Gets 50 Years in Child Sex Ring Case
description: The self-proclaimed leader of a polygamist sect in Arizona who amassed more than 20 “wives,” including 10 “brides” under 18, was sentenced on Monday to 50 years in prison in connection with what prosecutors described as an interstate child sexual abuse ring, according to the U.S. Attorney’s Office in Arizona.

title: Trump Has a New Favorite Foreign Leader. He’s Known as the Madman.
description: Javier Milei, the wild-haired Argentine president known by his supporters as the Madman, has lately edged out Hungary’s Viktor Orban as the MAGA movement’s chief international inspiration.

title: Trump Picks Strident Supporter for Civil Rights Post at Justice Dept.
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Monday that he would nominate Harmeet K. Dhillon, a California lawyer who has long championed Mr. Trump in public, in court cases and on social media, to run the Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division.

title: Corrections: Dec. 10, 2024
description: An article on Saturday about Lebanon and Jordan closing border crossings with Syria misidentified the source of a warning given to Americans to leave Syria promptly. It came from the U.S. State Department, not from the U.S. Embassy in Damascus.

title: That Manhunt Photo Looks Like a Loved One. Do You Have to Tell?
description: If someone you know is the subject of a nationwide manhunt and the authorities are desperately trying to learn the person’s name, are you under any legal obligation to come forward with it?

title: Suspect in C.E.O. Killing Withdrew From a Life of Privilege and Promise
description: Luigi Mangione, the online version of him, was an Ivy League tech enthusiast who flaunted his tanned, chiseled looks in beach photos and party pictures with blue-blazered frat buddies.

title: Trunk of the Body
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Nikki Giovanni, Poet Who Wrote of Black Joy, Dies at 81
description: Nikki Giovanni, the charismatic and iconoclastic poet, activist, children’s book author and professor who wrote, irresistibly and sensuously, about race, politics, gender, sex and love, died on Monday in Blacksburg, Va. She was 81.

title: Quote of the Day: Quantum Computing Inches Closer
description: “What has happened over the last year shows that it is no longer science fiction.”

title: Tuesday Briefing
description: A day after the regime of President Bashar al-Assad fell, civilians poured into the streets of Damascus, Syria, some weeping in disbelief. Many sought word of relatives held in a notorious prison on the outskirts of the city. Others clambered on top of cars and screamed curses at the Assad family, words that days ago could have meant a death sentence. Here’s the latest.

title: The Netanyahu Corruption Trial, Explained
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel took the stand on Tuesday in his corruption trial for the first time since it began in 2020, raising the stakes in a divisive case that has disrupted Israel’s political life for years.

title: In France, Marine Le Pen Takes Aim at the Top
description: The one-on-one duel that has shaped French political life for nearly a decade ratcheted up a notch last week, with the far-right leader Marine Le Pen claiming one big scalp, and giving notice of going after a bigger one, President Emmanuel Macron.

title: What to Know About the Countries Still Dropping Bombs in Syria
description: Great powers have fought for centuries for influence in the territory known today as Syria, each seeing a prize in its strategic position, stretching from the Mediterranean Sea to the Euphrates River and beyond. That struggle continues today.

title: How to Understand the Armed Factions Operating in Syria
description: Rebel forces earlier this month swept through Syria and forced former President Bashar al-Assad out of the country where his family had ruled with an iron fist since the early 1970s.

title: 12 Days That Changed Syria: The Rebel Offensive in Visuals
description: In just two weeks, rebel forces tore across Syria, shattering the stalemate left by more than a decade of civil war and bringing an end to more than five decades of brutal rule by the Assad dynasty.

title: These 14 Voters Think Trump Has One Mandate Above All, and It’s Not About the Economy
description: The group discusses abortion, immigration and what Trump should focus on in his second term.

title: Putin Just Suffered a Huge Defeat
description: This time, when Bashar al-Assad started to fall, Russia was not there to catch him.

title: The Plight of the Palestinian Scientist
description: Pursuing a scientific career in the Palestinian territories has been fraught for decades. Then Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, 2023, igniting a war in the Gaza Strip that has lasted for more than a year.

title: Volcanic Eruption Forces Mass Evacuation in the Philippines
description: The Philippine authorities ordered nearly 90,000 people to evacuate after a volcano on the central island of Negros erupted, spewing a two-mile-high plume of deadly ash, lava and large rocks.

title: Word of the Day: connotation
description: The word connotation has appeared in 37 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 28 in “Peridot Is the ‘Brat’ Green of Gems” by Victoria Gomelsky:

title: Late Night Turns Up Its Nose at Trump’s Cologne Ad
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: With an Eye on China, Australia Strikes a Deal With Nauru
description: Australia has signed a treaty with the Pacific island nation of Nauru to provide aid, banking and other infrastructure support, the latest maneuvering for influence in the region between China and countries allied with the United States.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

title: Mayor Adams’s Stance on Migrants Has Evolved, in Trump’s Direction
description: Over the past two years, Mayor Eric Adams has made no secret of his frustrations with New York City’s migrant crisis. But after President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victory, the mayor’s criticism has taken a sharper turn to the right.

title: Notre Dame Reopens
description: Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris reopened this weekend, more than five years after a devastating fire.

title: In Penny Verdict, a Flashpoint in the Debate Over Crime and Mental Illness
description: Outside the Manhattan criminal courthouse on Monday, a scuffle broke out among demonstrators, their chants amplified over bullhorns.

title: Taiwan Says China Has Deployed Largest Fleet of Ships in Decades
description: Taiwan said on Tuesday that China was conducting its largest maritime operations in nearly three decades, sending nearly 90 naval and coast guard vessels into waters stretching from the southern Japanese islands to the South China Sea.

title: Lula Recovering From Emergency Surgery for Bleeding in Skull
description: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil was in stable condition on Tuesday and recovering in an intensive care unit after emergency surgery to ease bleeding in his skull that doctors believe is connected to a fall he suffered at home in October, the doctors treating him said.

title: Sarah Jessica Parker Lands Her Dream Gig: Booker Prize Judge
description: On New Year’s Eve 2022, Sarah Jessica Parker was scrolling on Instagram when she saw a video by the Booker Prize, the prestigious British literary award, in which three judges talked about the craziness of reading 170 novels in seven months to pick that year’s nominees.

title: Christmas, Every Day
description: Two preteen girls market fashion and beauty products to thousands of online fans from their Alabama home.

title: How Being an Influencer Became a New American Dream
description: Whenever I browse social media, I see advice and products for self-improvement — a deluge of elusive promises tethered to consumer goods. How to look more angular or more toned, feel more energized, age backward. Capitalism and modern technology have mixed to create an internet world where users are transformed into brands. As a filmmaker, I’m drawn to document this culture.

title: These Nuns Were Excommunicated but Won’t Leave Their Convents
description: One afternoon this past summer, a car sped out of the gates of a convent on the outskirts of a sleepy village in northern Spain and kept going until it reached another convent 85 miles away.

title: Netflix’s Surprising Selection of Free Video Games
description: Three years ago, Netflix introduced a perk in an attempt to stand out from the cord-cutting fray: video games. Subscribers can pick from a variety of smartphone games and play them for no additional charge, each free of advertisements, microtransactions and other typical nuisances.

title: Winter Workout Tips, From Scientists Who Study Extreme Cold
description: With cold weather, icy streets and shorter days, it’s easy to find an excuse to stay inside during the winter months. That’s presumably why Americans on average get about half an hour less daily physical activity at this time of year.

title: A Novel Inspired by Images of a Young Prisoner at Auschwitz
description: Lily Tuck has range. She has written historical fiction set in South America — her novel “The News From Paraguay” won the National Book Award in 2004 — and low-key realist short stories about contemporary life.
