description: There’s a moment in “Theater of Thought” (in theaters) when Darío Gil, the director of research at IBM, is explaining quantum computing to Werner Herzog, the movie’s director. Standing before a whiteboard, Gil draws some points on spheres to illustrate how qubits work, then proceeds to define the Schrödinger equation. As he talks and writes, the audio grows quieter, and Herzog’s distinctive resonant German accent takes over. “I admit that I literally understand nothing of this, and I assume most of you don’t either,” he intones in voice-over. “But I found it fascinating that this mathematical formula explains the law that draws the subatomic world.”

title: At the Piano With Jon Batiste
description: Jon Batiste, the Grammy Award-winning composer, television personality and jazz and R&B artist recently released “Beethoven Blues,” his first classical album. Batiste blends Beethoven’s most familiar compositions, like “Für Elise” and the Fifth Symphony, with improvised jazz, blues and funk, finding “soul” in the composer’s work. Javier Hernández, a classical music reporter, sits down at the piano with Batiste for an interview and a music lesson at Electric Lady Studios in Manhattan.

title: For Wild Animals, the Bird Flu Disaster Is Already Here
description: Every spring, more than 200,000 northern gannets — stocky seabirds with dazzling white feathers — journey to the coast of eastern Canada. There, they blanket oceanside cliffs and rocky outcroppings, breeding in enormous colonies before flying back south for the winter.

title: Gas Could Mean Billions for Indigenous People in Canada. Some Fear a Cost.
description: With her hair pulled back into a tight ponytail, her arms and legs covered with 20 tattoos, and her compact frame fitted out in athleisure, Crystal Smith, the elected chief of the Haisla people, looked more like the hometown basketball star she once was than the fossil fuel exporter she’s about to become.

title: I Traded My News Apps for Rumble, the Right-Wing YouTube. Here’s What I Saw.
description: After watching 47 hours of video, I found an alternate reality curated for Trump supporters.

title: Kennedy’s Lawyer Has Asked the F.D.A. to Revoke Approval of the Polio Vaccine
description: The lawyer helping Robert F. Kennedy Jr. pick federal health officials for the incoming Trump administration has petitioned the government to revoke its approval of the polio vaccine, which for decades has protected millions of people from a virus that can cause paralysis or death.

title: In New York and Paris, Church Organs Return to Life
description: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll find out about the return of pipe organs that went silent for five years after fires broke out at their cathedrals. We’ll also look at a mayoral candidate’s proposal for city-owned grocery stores.

title: Where Opera Is Still the Center of the Universe
description: Television reporters stood shoulder to shoulder delivering breathless, minute-by-minute commentary, part of a pack of more than 120 journalists from 10 countries.

title: 10 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
description: Angelina Jolie stars as the opera star Maria Callas during her tumultuous final days in this biopic directed by Pablo Larraín.

title: How Christian Slater Went From Bad Boy to Good Dad
description: On a July morning, the actor Christian Slater sat on a bench at the Long Beach marina, grimacing in the California sunshine. Slater sighed, he scowled, he groaned. He looked like a man facing some terrible moral quandary. Or like a man with severe indigestion.

title: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
description: One of the joys of parenthood is introducing your child to classic films that you once loved. It thrills me that my 7-year-old son adores “E.T.” and the original “Star Wars” and “Indiana Jones” films. Watching him mimic the “Banana Boat (Day-O)” dance in Tim Burton’s 1988 goth horror comedy “Beetlejuice” has been one of the highlights of my year. For older children that love scary-ish movies, Burton’s long-awaited follow-up film is a kooky medley of wacky scares and outrageous scenarios. Winona Ryder returns as a grown-up Lydia. She’s now a widow who hosts a ghost show on TV, and her goth teenage daughter, Astrid (Jenna Ortega), is every bit as brooding as her mother was at her age.

title: $3 Million Homes in the Caribbean
description: Situated in the private island resort of Kamalame Cay, which occupies a 96-acre cay off the northeast coast of the Bahamas’ largest island, this three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath home features vaulted ceilings and an indoor-outdoor layout. Andros Island is home to the Andros Barrier Reef, which stretches 124 miles. This house sits on a split of land — a cay is a low-elevation island on the surface of a reef. One side faces a white-sand beach and the Atlantic Ocean, and on the other side faces salt marshes and the mainland. The resort community is 14 miles from Andros Town, the island’s capital and home to Andros Town International Airport.

title: The Smithsonian Looks at How the Slave Trade Shaped the World
description: “In Slavery’s Wake,” a new exhibition at the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington, deals in huge themes and vast numbers. Over four centuries, an estimated 12 million Africans were transported across the ocean on more than 36,000 voyages, an epochal forced migration that reshaped societies on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: A Broken System Is No Excuse
description: When Brian Thompson was shot to death, something strange — and disturbing — happened: The gunman was lauded. Why? Because his victim was the C.E.O. of one of the largest health insurance companies in the country. And so the shooter, observers assumed, must be a victim of those companies.

title: How Hegseth Salvaged His Secretary of Defense Nomination
description: The president-elect became convinced that letting Pete Hegseth fail would set off a feeding frenzy among senators. What followed was a MAGA swarm that helped salvage his bid, at least for now.

title: Should You Be Able to Copyright a Vibe?
description: Have you ever scrolled through Instagram or TikTok and seen two creators whose content looks nearly identical? They have the same look, are wearing the same outfit, are striking the same pose. In short, they have the same vibe.

title: What ‘Wicked’ Has to Say About Our Current Political Moment
description: In the big-screen adaptation of “Wicked,” Elphaba (Cynthia Erivo) uses magic to defend her sister and unwittingly destroys a courtyard mural of the Wizard at Shiz University. When her outburst shatters the wall, it also unearths an image that has been intentionally covered up: the school’s original founders, animal professors whose ability to speak, teach humans, and organize politically posed a threat to the Wizard’s autocratic reign.

title: Timothée Chalamet Joins a Rarified Club of Actors Singing in Musical Biopics
description: In one trailer for the upcoming Bob Dylan biopic, “A Complete Unknown,” a fan pleads with the musician, played by Timothée Chalamet, saying that she can’t hear the music at his sold-out concert.

title: I Don’t Want a Pardon From Biden. None of Us Should.
description: In his 2023 book, “Government Gangsters,” Kash Patel, whom Donald Trump says he intends to nominate as the next director of the F.B.I., named 60 people whom he classified as “members of the executive branch deep state” — a “cabal of unelected tyrants” who posed “the most dangerous threat to our democracy.” Mr. Patel has since said that the incoming Trump administration must deal with the “deep state,” be it “criminally or civilly.”

title: The Syrian Upheaval Has Iranian Leaders Reeling, Too
description: In the days since the abrupt and unexpected obliteration of Iran as a dominant presence in Syria, the government has faced a fierce public backlash over the billions of dollars spent and the Iranian blood shed to back the Assad regime.

title: Tell Us What Brought You Joy in 2024
description: Is there a movie, a book, a meme, a memory, a hobby you took up or a vice you quit that stayed with you this year, or helped you unwind and forget about everything else? Times Opinion wants to hear about it.

title: Media Moguls Set the Stage for Deal Mania
description: The people in charge of the world’s biggest media companies are setting the stage for a flurry of deal making.

title: The New York Times News Quiz, Dec. 13, 2024
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: Waiting for a Test Result Can Be Brutal. Here’s How to Deal.
description: Jancee Dunn is out this week. I’m Maxwell Strachan, an editor on the Well desk, filling in today.

title: UnitedHealth Group C.E.O.: The Health Care System Is Flawed. Let’s Fix It.
description: As Brian Thompson’s family, friends and colleagues mourn his killing, we are bearing a grief and sadness we will carry for the rest of our lives. Grief for the family he leaves behind. And grief for a brilliant, kind man who was working to make health care better for everyone.

title: The Fall of al-Assad Quickly Infuses Europe’s Debate Over Asylum
description: Just hours after President Bashar al-Assad boarded a plane for Russia on Sunday, thousands of Syrians who had fled to escape his rule and the civil war to unseat him celebrated in the streets across Germany.

title: Syrian Rebels Seize Large Captagon Factory
description: Rebel fighters found stockpiles of addictive pills, some hidden in fruit or furniture and ready for export as part of the Assad regime’s illegal drug operation.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,274
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion No. 552
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: A Turning Point for Ultraprocessed Foods
description: A new study has found that nearly three-quarters of American adults are now obese or overweight, and there’s growing concern — among politicians, scientists and consumers — about one potential culprit: ultraprocessed foods.Alice Callahan, a nutrition and health reporter for The New York Times, discusses how these foods came to be such a big part of what we eat, and why that’s so hard to change.

title: A Profile of the C.E.O. Killing Suspect, and Tech Giants Give to Trump Fund
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: Prince Andrew’s Links to Chinese Spy Suspect Are Revealed by U.K. Court
description: Prince Andrew, the younger brother of King Charles III, has been caught up in a suspected case of Chinese spying, after a British court upheld a decision to bar from the country a Chinese man who was a “close confidant” of his on national security grounds.

title: Emmanuel Macron Appoints Key Ally as France’s New Prime Minister
description: President Emmanuel Macron on Friday tapped François Bayrou, a veteran centrist politician and one of his top allies, as the new prime minister,  a move that few expect would stabilize France’s roiling politics.

title: The End Game in Ukraine
description: No matter who won the presidential election, the war in Ukraine was likely to end next year. Both Ukraine and Russia are running out of troops and struggling to call up more young men for the front lines. That reality always meant that 2025 would be a year of negotiations.

title: TikTok’s Last Stand, Google’s Quantum Breakthrough and the Cult of Claude
description: Last Friday, a panel of federal judges denied TikTok’s petition to overturn the law that could force the ban of the app in the United States. We walk through the judges reasoning and explain why TikTok’s First Amendment argument was unsuccessful. Then, Julian Kelly, the director of quantum hardware at Google Quantum AI, explains how close we are to quantum computers that can solve practical problems. Finally, we talk about a new sentiment sweeping Silicon Valley: affection for the chatbot Claude.

title: Turkey Emerges as a Big Winner in the Wake of al-Assad’s Ouster
description: In the messy aftermath of the fall of the Assad regime in Syria, many questions remain about the country’s future, but one thing is clear: Turkey has emerged as a winner, with more influence than ever over the rebels who now control most of Syria.

title: Breaking the Cycle of Childhood Poverty in New York
description: New York State has one of the worst child poverty rates in the country. In New York City, one in every four children lives in poverty. Tens of thousands of children are not getting enough food to eat, and their families are struggling to make rent.

title: Health Protections for Migrant Children in Custody Are Set to Expire
description: A court-ordered system for protecting the health of children detained at the southern border, put in place two years ago after several children died in  custody, is set to expire nine days after Donald J. Trump takes office with plans to intensify the deportation of migrants.

title: With al-Assad Gone, Syrians Seek Answers in an Underground Jail
description: Her brother was pulled from his car at a military checkpoint nearly a decade ago, her brother-in-law dragged from his house by the police. Two of her cousins were arrested near the airport in the Syrian capital, Damascus. She said she never had heard from any of them again.

title: Russia Hits Ukraine’s Energy Infrastructure in a Renewed Assault
description: Russia launched a missile attack on Ukraine’s energy infrastructure early Friday, in an assault that President Volodymyr Zelensky described as “one of the largest strikes” on his country’s power facilities.

title: Elon Musk and DOGE vs. Regulators
description: Elon Musk remains perhaps the most consequential figure in President-elect Donald Trump’s orbit, with a commission for cutting government spending headed by him and Vivek Ramaswamy — widely known by its acronym, DOGE — promising huge reductions.

title: The Fed Is Stuck Fighting the Last War
description: The battle against inflation during the Biden years is almost behind us. But we’re in danger of learning the wrong lessons from it.

title: A New Frontier in Paleontology for Profit: Selling Shares in a Stegosaurus
description: With dinosaur fossils fetching millions of dollars at recent auctions, it was perhaps inevitable: A private company said Friday that it had set the date for a public offering that will allow investors to buy shares in a stegosaurus fossil.

title: Tired of Tipping? Holidays May Be the Exception.
description: The tradition of holiday tips to thank service workers endures, even as Americans have gotten tired of the regular requests for tips the rest of the year.

title: How Claude Became Tech Insiders’ Chatbot of Choice
description: His fans rave about his sensitivity and wit. Some talk to him dozens of times a day — asking for advice about their jobs, their health, their relationships. They entrust him with their secrets, and consult him before making important decisions. Some refer to him as their best friend.

title: 10 Great Thrillers Set in Remote, Hard-to-Reach Places
description: As anyone who’s read one of my novels knows, I adore a Setting with a capital S: a tropical island, a super yacht in the North Sea, a glass cabin in the woods, a cell in a high-security women’s prison — the more remote the better. Because what could be more fun than confining your characters somewhere they cannot escape, and then slowly tormenting them as the plot unfolds?

title: Democrats Argue That the 2024 Election Actually Had Its Bright Spots
description: For most Democrats, losing to Donald J. Trump was a devastating gut punch that sent them hurtling into the political abyss.

title: Celebrate the Holidays Like You’re Frank Costanza
description: Let’s make a Festivus pole.

title: What to Know About ‘The Lord of the Rings: The War of the Rohirrim’
description: If you would like to know who the Helm of Helm’s Deep is, you are in the right place.

title: Mapo Ragù Is an Ideal Wintertime Feast
description: Good morning. We hit Del Fiore in Rocky Point for late-morning sandwiches, Italian subs from the northeastern reaches of Brookhaven on Long Island, then pushed west along the Washington Spy Trail toward Port Jefferson, Setauket, Nissequogue, thinking about cooking all the way.

title: ‘Tune Back In. Our Democracy Depends on It.’
description: To the Editor:

title: The Under-the-Radar Philippine Island That Evokes 1970s Bali
description: Spend a few days in Siargao, the fig-shaped Philippine island in the country’s southeast, and locals will tell you, with a mix of anxiety and excitement, that the coconut tree-covered enclave is what Bali was in the 1970s. Or they might say, as the documentarian and trans-rights activist Queenmelo Esguerra told me last month, that laid-back hotels and cafes that’ve opened this decade (like Siago), “feel inspired by Tulum, no?”

title: Critics Complain That Italy’s Government Is Interfering in the Arts
description: Earlier this month, hundreds thronged to Rome’s National Gallery of Modern and Contemporary Art for the highly anticipated opening of a major exhibition on Futurism, arguably Italy’s most notable contribution to 20th-century art. Coming on the heels of cubism, Futurist art broke with the past to capture the movement and dynamism of the modern age. Yet with its nationalistic and warmongering rhetoric, Futurism is also intertwined, in part, with Mussolini’s Fascist regime.

title: How to Turn Up the Heat on Your Mulled Cocktails
description: Cold weather makes a near universal case for hot drinks. Add in a festive season and mulled wine quickly enters the chat.

title: Daniel Penny, Newly Acquitted, Will Join Vance and Trump at Army-Navy Game
description: Vice President-elect JD Vance on Friday said that he had invited Daniel Penny, a former Marine who was acquitted this week on a charge of criminally negligent homicide after putting a man in a chokehold in a New York subway car, to attend the Army-Navy football game on Saturday with him.

title: What the Polio Vaccine Has Meant for Public Health
description: On the day in 1955 that Jonas Salk’s polio vaccine was pronounced “80 to 90 percent effective” against the form of the disease that caused paralysis, 500 medical scientists and 150 reporters jammed into an auditorium at the University of Michigan for the announcement. Pots clanged, horns honked and factory whistles blew around the country.

title: Louis Nelson, Designer of Korean War Mural, Dies at 88
description: Louis Nelson, an industrial designer who conceived a central element of the Korean War Veterans Memorial in Washington, drawing on his experiences as a peacetime Army officer and art student when he encountered veterans of the Korean conflict, died on Dec. 4 in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: What Is Captagon, the Illegal Stimulant That Made al-Assad’s Syria a Narcostate?
description: Rebel fighters in Syria said on Friday that they had found vast stockpiles of an illegal amphetamine called captagon in a Damascus warehouse.

title: Elon Musk’s Playbook for DOGE Has a Precedent: X
description: Since President-elect Donald J. Trump last month named Elon Musk to help lead a new Department of Government Efficiency, the tech billionaire has turned to X to trumpet his plans.

title: How the Wackiest, Most ‘Annoying’ Christmas Song Became a Hit
description: On a cold and snowy night in November 1978, the members of Randy Brooks’s country band, Young Country, found themselves stranded after a gig at the Hyatt Hotel on the Nevada side of Lake Tahoe. The brakes on their van were frozen. With nowhere to go, Mr. Brooks and his bandmates went back inside to watch the next act, a bluegrass group fronted by the husband-and-wife duo of Elmo Shropshire and Patsy Trigg.

title: Trump’s Treasury Pick Is Poised to Test ‘Three Arrows’ Economic Strategy
description: When Prime Minister Shinzo Abe set out to rejuvenate Japan’s economy more than a decade ago, he laid out a strategy known as the “Three Arrows,” which aimed to banish deflation by easing monetary policy, increasing government spending and restructuring the economy so that it was poised for growth.

title: OpenAI’s Sam Altman to Donate $1 Million to Trump’s Inaugural Fund
description: OpenAI said on Friday that its chief executive, Sam Altman, was planning to donate $1 million to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inaugural fund, joining a number of tech companies and executives who are working to improve their relationships with Mr. Trump.

title: Harris to Deliver Speech Urging Young People to Stay Civically Engaged
description: Vice President Kamala Harris, who has kept a low profile since she lost the presidential election, will give a speech in Maryland next week urging young people to stay civically engaged, the White House announced on Friday.

title: Blinken Discusses Syria’s Future on Unannounced Visit to Iraq
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said he talked with Iraq’s prime minister about the situation in Syria, including efforts to encourage Syria to transition to an inclusive, non-sectarian government.

title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: Shot on 16 mm and drenched in aquamarine hues, the new film by Donal Foreman is a lovely and unclassifiable thing. Two women — an American filmmaker, Maire (Dale Dickey) and an Irish scholar, Cait (Judith Roddy) — go to a remote Irish island to make a film about a 16th-century pirate-queen, and are drawn into the shifting sands of reality and fiction, myth and history.

title: Fortnite Players Get Millions in Refunds for Unwanted Purchases
description: Fortnite players who were charged for unwanted purchases in the game where cartoony characters battle on a virtual island are starting to receive what could be $245 million in refunds from Epic Games for what the federal government called manipulative online practices.

title: Gillibrand Presses Biden to Amend the Constitution to Enshrine Sex Equality
description: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York is on a mission in President Biden’s final days in office. She wants to convince him that he can rescue his legacy by adding the century-old Equal Rights Amendment, which would explicitly guarantee sex equality, to the Constitution as a way to protect abortion rights in post-Roe America.

title: McKinsey to Pay $650 Million in Opioid Settlement With Justice Department
description: McKinsey & Company has agreed to pay $650 million to settle a Justice Department investigation of its work with the opioid maker Purdue Pharma. A former senior partner has also agreed to plead guilty to obstruction of justice for destroying internal company records in connection with that work.

title: Bank of America Flagged Suspicious Payments to Epstein Only After He Died
description: When Bank of America alerted financial regulators in 2020 to potentially suspicious payments from Leon Black, the billionaire investor, to Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced financier, the bank was following a routine practice.The bank filed two “suspicious activity reports,” or SARs, which are meant to alert law enforcement to potential criminal activities like money laundering, terrorism financing or sex trafficking. One was filed in February 2020 and the other eight months later, according to a congressional memorandum reviewed by The New York Times.

title: Can Berlin Really Afford 3 ‘Magic Flutes’ in a Single Week?
description: Opera has always tended toward grandeur. Berlin, home to three world-class opera houses, regularly takes things to the next level.

title: Pelosi Hospitalized in Luxembourg After Falling
description: Former Speaker Nancy Pelosi was hospitalized on Friday after being injured while traveling abroad on a bipartisan congressional delegation to Luxembourg, a spokesman said on Friday.

title: Most Americans Say They Have Good Health Insurance, Polls Show
description: Americans voted last month in an election that polls showed was largely about the economy. Less than 1 percent of likely voters ranked health care as their top issue.

title: Review: Reveling in a Wry Storybook, Full of Characters
description: Tess Dworman is rarely just Tess Dworman. This choreographer and dancer is a shape-shifter with a biting wit. She inhabits other people as if she were flipping through sketches and bringing them to life. You grasp who they are through Dworman’s delivery, an endearing mix of sharp and guileless.

title: Avant Gardner, Troubled Brooklyn Venue, Promises Security Changes in Major Renovation
description: The new chief executive of Avant Gardner, one of Brooklyn’s largest event venues, said the company was overhauling the space and making sweeping security changes. The overhaul comes during a fraught period for the venue, including the deaths of two patrons found nearby last year.

title: A Stunning Year in Sports: Caitlin Clark, Shohei Ohtani and Record Viewership
description: In sports this year, everything was richer, brighter, bigger.

title: Martial Solal, French Jazz Piano Virtuoso, Is Dead at 97
description: Martial Solal, Europe’s pre-eminent jazz pianist, who recorded dozens of startlingly original albums in a career of almost three quarters of a century and who wrote scores for numerous films, including Jean-Luc Godard’s masterpiece “Breathless,” died on Thursday in Versailles, France. He was 97.

title: F.B.I. Passed Tip About Mangione to New York Police After C.E.O. Killing
description: Investigators received a tip from the San Francisco Police Department identifying Luigi Mangione as a suspect before he was arrested in the killing of an insurance executive in Midtown Manhattan, the New York F.B.I. field office said Friday.

title: A Very Senatorial Goodbye: Nostalgia, Legacy and Gratitude, Live on C-SPAN
description: The way Senator Joe Manchin III tells it, the senatorial bashes he hosted on his beloved houseboat Almost Heaven were so good they could inspire the most liberal of Democrats and the most conservative of Republicans to start writing bills together.

title: What Song Did You Discover, or Rediscover, in 2024?
description: In a recent edition of The Amplifier newsletter, Lindsay Zoladz shared the music that shaped her year. She rediscovered a classic from the Smiths thanks to a karaoke party, dug into Neil Young’s back catalog after seeing him in concert, and revisited a Frank Sinatra standard because it reminded her of a cherished trip to Vermont.

title: U.S. Considered Border Buoys Months Before Texas Put Them In
description: On the U.S.-Mexico border, they are perhaps the most visible symbol of Gov. Greg Abbott’s effort to deter migrants from entering Texas: giant, orange buoys floating in the Rio Grande, designed to make it harder to cross.

title: The Messy Modern Music Business, According to Larry Jackson
description: The music executive Larry Jackson, a founder of the entertainment company Gamma, has seen several sea changes in the recording business from different vantages over different eras of disruption.

title: 10 Songs That Explain My Year
description: Earlier this week, I shared a massive playlist of some of the best music released in 2024 — over 100 tracks, selected by Times music critics, from our lists of the year’s greatest albums and songs. Today, it’s time for another end-of-year Amplifier tradition: my playlist of older songs that defined my year.

title: Hochul Launches Investigation Into Drone Sightings in New York
description: As reports of drone sightings continued to spread across New Jersey and New York, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York on Friday said she was investigating the matter with federal law enforcement agencies.

title: Patel Distorts Justice Dept. Benghazi Inquiry, Inflating His Role
description: Kash Patel, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to be F.B.I. director, often burnishes his credentials as a former prosecutor even as he portrays law enforcement agencies as an inept and politicized “deep state.” A critical piece of that narrative is the investigation into the 2012 attack on a diplomatic compound and a C.I.A. annex in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four Americans.

title: Do I Have to Tell My Boyfriend I’ve Been Paid for Sex?
description: Years ago, when I was struggling with addiction, I would occasionally (once a month or less) engage in sex work to help make ends meet. This was voluntary — no one made me do anything I didn’t want to do — but it’s still uncomfortable for me to think about sometimes. I always used protection during these encounters and continue to get screened for S.T.D.s regularly. If anything, I think I’m slightly less likely than the general population is to pass anything on.

title: America’s Health Care System Needs Better Economics, Not Bullets
description: I can predict when one of my newsletters is going to divide a lot of readers. This is one of them. I’m going to argue that the problem with health insurance and the health care system overall is misaligned incentives. It is, in other words, a problem of structure, not any individual’s morality. Evil should not be part of the conversation. Nor — and I hate to have to say this — should killing.

title: A Murder in Midtown Sent the Police Scrambling. Reporters Weren’t Far Behind.
description: The early morning shooting death of Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, on a Manhattan sidewalk last week shocked the nation, and sent law enforcement on a mad scramble to find the killer.

title: Eric Adams’s Advisers Are Trying to Get Him a Trump Inauguration Ticket
description: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City has spent weeks inching closer to President-elect Donald J. Trump, flouting the concerns of many fellow Democrats.

title: Miley Cyrus Gives Showgirl Pathos, and 8 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, Dec. 14, 2024
description: Can you sort 8 historical events?

title: Syrians Celebrate in Damascus During Friday Prayers
description: Joyful chants erupted in and around the historic Umayyad Mosque in Syria’s capital as large crowds gathered to pray and celebrate the country’s newfound sense of liberty.

title: Our Book Critics on What Stuck With Them in 2024
description: “This year’s best books mattered because they offered refuge from the wheels grinding in our heads,” writes Dwight Garner in a piece in which the Book Review’s three staff critics look back on their years in reading. Jennifer Szalai and Alexandra Jacobs joined him in conversation with Book Review editor Gilbert Cruz to reflect on their 2024 reading.

title: Conan O’Brien’s Parents Die 3 Days Apart
description: The parents of Conan O’Brien, the longtime late-night television host and a star in the comedy world, died this week within days of one another.

title: Jerome Kohn, Keeper of Hannah Arendt’s Flame, Dies at 93
description: Jerome Kohn, who devoted his career to decoding, defending and disseminating the work of Hannah Arendt, the provocative philosopher who diagnosed the roots of 20th-century totalitarianism and who controvertibly wrote that the convicted Nazi war criminal Adolf Eichmann embodied “the banality of evil,” died on Nov. 8 in Bay Shore, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 93.

title: This Chef’s Stunning Christmas Spread Is Unexpectedly Effortless
description: A feast is only a feast if both effort and bounty are shared.

title: Bill Belichick Has Stores Cutting the Sleeves Off Sweatshirts
description: As rumors circulated this week that Bill Belichick could become the new football coach at the University of North Carolina, Jamie Mottram knew that his company needed to be prepared.

title: Judge Says Former ByteDance Executive Lied in Suit Against Company
description: A federal judge in San Francisco said on Thursday that a former executive at ByteDance lied in statements to the court and seemed to have fabricated an important witness in a high-profile case against the company.

title: Charles Handy Dies at 92; Philosopher Envisioned Today’s Corporate World
description: Charles Handy, a writer, social philosopher and management theorist who presciently imagined a brave new corporate world where employees worked remotely, jobs were outsourced and workers had “portfolio careers,” working for themselves and contracting their skills to companies, died on Friday at his home in London. He was 92.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to California Tailpipe Emissions Limits
description: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to consider whether business groups may challenge an unusual federal program that lets California set its own limits on tailpipe emissions to combat climate change.

title: Syrians Celebrated a New Chapter
description: Jubilant crowds gathered today in cities across Syria for the first Friday Prayer since rebels toppled President Bashar al-Assad. Elsewhere in the country, Russia’s military appeared to be packing up equipment at a critical base.

title: It’s Going to Be Normal to Have Extreme Beliefs
description: I promise not to make every installment of this newsletter a further elaboration on what it means to live after the post-Cold War liberal order, in a world where a certain kind of neoliberal consensus politics has dissolved without any new consensus sweeping in to take its place. But I’ll go once more to the well for the case of Luigi Mangione, who has been charged with murder in the fatal shooting of the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, Brian Thompson, and who has become a source of general fascination and, to some, a peculiar kind of outlaw hero.

title: McConnell Defends Polio Vaccine, an Apparent Warning to Kennedy
description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader and a survivor of polio, issued a pointed statement in support of the polio vaccine on Friday, hours after The New York Times reported that the lawyer for Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has petitioned federal regulators to withdraw the vaccine from the market.

title: Tim Cook Dines With Trump at Mar-a-Lago
description: Tim Cook held a meeting on Friday with Donald J. Trump at Mar-a-Lago, marking the first time that Apple’s chief executive has met with the president-elect since voters elected him to a second term last month.

title: Texas Attorney General Sues New York Doctor for Mailing Abortion Pills
description: The Texas attorney general opened a new front in the contentious battle over access to abortion this week by suing a New York doctor for sending abortion pills into Texas. It appeared to be among the first attempts to stop the mailing of such medication into states that ban abortion.

title: Tell Us: What’s Your Favorite Movie About Politics?
description: You might be tired of politics after this roller coaster of a presidential election. Maybe you’ve tried escaping to the movies — only to find that some of the season’s marquee releases, like “Gladiator II” or the Ralph Fiennes pope thriller “Conclave,” are themselves about campaigns, conniving and democracy’s viability.

title: Rodney Jenkins, Star of the Show-Jumping Circuit, Dies at 80
description: Rodney Jenkins, an equestrian who dominated shows in the 1970s and ’80s by deftly guiding horses in competition with a rare feel for their abilities and thoughts, died on Dec. 5 at his home in Maryland. He was 80.

title: Trump Ordered to Sit for Deposition in ABC News Defamation Suit
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump was ordered by a federal judge on Friday to sit for a deposition next week in the defamation lawsuit he brought this spring against ABC News and one of its anchors, George Stephanopoulos.

title: Joy Buoys Syria’s First Friday Prayers Since Assad Ouster, but Hardships Loom
description: Jubilant crowds gathered in cities across Syria for the first Friday Prayers since rebels toppled President Bashar al-Assad, including at the historic Umayyad Mosque in the capital, where civilians and fighters worshiped side by side and joyful chants erupted over the collapse of a long authoritarian dynasty.

title: OpenAI Fires Back at Elon Musk’s Lawsuit
description: Earlier this month, Elon Musk asked a federal court to block OpenAI’s efforts to transform itself from a nonprofit into a purely for-profit company.

title: The Texas Millennial Trying to Rebrand the Democrats
description: Ever since they lost big in November, Democrats have talked about how much their party needs to change.

title: U.S. Officials Say Sightings Are Mix of Planes, Stars and Legal Drones
description: Bright lights floating or flying in the night sky above New Jersey are a combination of airplanes, helicopters, stars and drones being flown legally, four federal agencies said in a statement on Monday.

title: Paula Abdul Settles Sexual Assault Lawsuit Against Nigel Lythgoe
description: Paula Abdul and Nigel Lythgoe, a television producer, have settled a lawsuit that Abdul filed accusing him of sexually assaulting her when they worked together on “American Idol” and “So You Think You Can Dance.”

title: Supreme Court to Hear Catholic Charity’s Bid for Tax Exemption
description: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether Wisconsin was free to deny a tax exemption to a Catholic charity on the grounds that its activities were not primarily religious.

title: Gerd Heidemann, Journalist Duped by Fake Hitler Diaries, Dies at 93
description: Gerd Heidemann, a globe-trotting, high-flying German journalist who thought he had landed the scoop of the century — the private diaries of Adolf Hitler — but who came crashing back to earth after they were exposed as crude forgeries, died on Monday at a hospital in Hamburg, Germany. He was 93.

title: U.S. Court Denies TikTok’s Request to Freeze Sale-or-Ban Law
description: A federal court on Friday denied TikTok’s request to temporarily freeze a law that requires its Chinese parent company to sell the app or face a ban in the United States as of Jan. 19, a decision that puts the fate of the app in the Supreme Court’s hands.

title: Biden Administration Is Said to Allow California to Ban New Gas-Powered Cars
description: The Biden administration is expected in the coming days to grant California and 11 other states permission to ban the sale of new gasoline-powered cars by 2035, one of the most ambitious climate policies in the United States and beyond, according to three people briefed on the matter, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss it publicly.

title: Timothée Chalamet Dresses Like Bob Dylan at ‘A Complete Unknown’ New York Premiere
description: “I saw him,” said Charlotte Barbié, 18, who stood outside the SVA Theater on Friday night, shaking from either the cold or the excitement. “He was blond.”

title: Tea Supplier
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is an excellent, sure-footed challenge from Owen Bergstein, a new constructor to The New York Times. There’s a lot of whimsy, but the cuteness is intertwined with tough stuff, too difficult to be saccharine. There are lots of odd expressions in the long entries, yes, but they really work on a Saturday. I have to tip my hat when I don’t know where an entry is going after I have six of 11 letters, for instance, and then find that the right answer is a commonplace reference.

title: C.E.O.’s Killing Poses Early Test for New N.Y.P.D. Commissioner
description: Jessica S. Tisch, New York’s police commissioner, was giving her two sons their morning cereal on Dec. 4 when she got a text from a deputy telling her that the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare had been shot dead on a Manhattan sidewalk.

title: The Message: Impeach South Korea’s President. The Tune: ‘Feliz Navidad.’
description: While calling for President Yoon Suk Yeol’s removal, tens of thousands of South Korean protesters have danced to traditional percussion, sung a pop genre called trot and blasted “Whiplash,” a hit by the girl group Aespa.

title: Quote of the Day: Europeans Eye Giving Syrians A Nudge Home
description: “When I was born, that statue was there, and I’ve been wanting to remove it my entire life.”

title: The Art of the Gift: Julio Torres
description: Known for his surrealist comedy, the El Salvador-born, Brooklyn-based performer Julio Torres, 37, is a former staff writer on “Saturday Night Live” and the co-creator of the HBO series “Los Espookys.” He most recently wrote, directed and starred in the film “Problemista” and the HBO series “Fantasmas.” This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

title: Dancing in the Park: How an M.T.A. Worker Spreads Joy
description: Even in New York City, where more than eight million people are largely accustomed to sticking to themselves and often expect the worst from each other, it’s possible to build a relationship with a stranger.

title: How a Children’s Tennis Instructor Spends Her Sundays
description: Joyce Short, 77, has survived many things.

title: As the Right Lionizes Daniel Penny, His Prosecutor Faces a Familiar Fury
description: Daniel Penny broke into a smile at midmorning Monday, hugging both of his lawyers in a Manhattan courtroom and getting a kiss on the cheek from one. Moments before, a jury forewoman had said Mr. Penny was not guilty of criminally negligent homicide in the death of a homeless subway passenger he had restrained in a chokehold last year.

title: Where It Isn’t Christmas Until the City Shoots Lasers at 20,000 Crows
description: In Rochester, N.Y., there are telltale signs that the holiday season is underway.

title: How the President Alienated South Korea, One Group at a Time
description: Even before Yoon Suk Yeol’s fateful decree, the public had been infuriated with near-constant scandals and unpopular decisions since he took office.

title: Saving England’s Music Oasis From a New Wave of Development
description: Glass towers crowd the skyline in Manchester, encroaching a bit more each year on the legacy of this northern English city with a musical soul.

title: Guggenheim Offers the Poetry of Motion: Sign Language Verses
description: Noah Buchholz, a deaf poet, was standing on a stage on the ground floor of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum on Wednesday night, with a gentle smile.

title: 4 Mysteries Shot Through With Malice and Grief
description: Pek’s debut “The Verifiers” was the book I most wanted to review in 2022, but didn’t. It wasn’t perfect, but I admired the fresh, sweetly sardonic voice of the amateur sleuth and mystery-novel aficionado Claudia Lin, as well as the way Pek raised questions about living, dating and lying online.

title: Here Comes the Bride (Just Not to That Song)
description: When Becky Pedroza began planning her wedding, she imagined a celebration as vibrant and free-spirited as her relationship with Erik Revelli.

title: The Trump Show Is Returning. Will It Be Triumph, Tragedy or Farce?
description: On his last show before Election Day, John Oliver allowed himself to dream a little dream. Mr. Oliver, whose “Last Week Tonight” speaks to a mostly left-of-center crowd, spent most of the episode making the case for Kamala Harris. But also, he asked his audience, wouldn’t it be nice, for the first time since 2015, to have the option of simply ignoring Donald J. Trump’s existence? “I want so badly to live in that world!” he said.

title: To Dial Down Campus Tensions, Colleges Teach the Art of Conversation
description: On a warm November day, a group of Columbia University professors set up “listening tables” near the center of campus and hailed students rushing to class, inviting them to stop and talk.

title: Are Childhood Vaccines ‘Overloading’ the Immune System? No.
description: It’s an idea as popular as it is incorrect: American babies now receive too many vaccines, which overwhelm their immune systems and lead to conditions like autism.

title: Richard Gere Calls ‘Blonde on Blonde’ His All-Time Favorite
description: It has been more than four decades since an Armani-clad Richard Gere slunk around Los Angeles in Paul Schrader’s “American Gigolo.”

title: The Joy of Bundling Up
description: The storybook holiday season in New York brings a certain coziness to Central Park, even as the landscape’s palette fades from autumnal reds, oranges and yellows to muted greens and browns. Stroll around and you are likely to spot telltale signs of wintertime in the city: couples bundled up for a long walk, families dressed to ice-skate, tourists looking for landmarks and tiny nooks featured in films like “Home Alone 2: Lost in New York.”

title: An Art World Satire Invokes a (Literal) Ghost
description: Sabine Rossi is a week out from the opening of her solo art exhibition at a gallery in Melbourne, Australia, at the start of Ella Baxter’s second novel, “Woo Woo.” Each of the show’s 15 photographs depicts the artist in a costume comprising the mask of a female archetype and a sheer “skin” — a “wearable puppet” — that sheathes her body without concealing it.

title: A Surprise Blockbuster in Brazil Stokes Oscar Hopes, and a Reckoning
description: Fernanda Torres still remembers the day her mother, Brazil’s grande dame of film, came within reach of cinema’s most coveted prize: an Oscar.

title: Another New Twitter? Good Luck With That.
description: Recently, while talking to a friend who used to run a large media website, I casually mentioned the rise of Bluesky. More than a million users have deleted their X (formerly Twitter) accounts and moved over to the upstart social media site, which they see as a healthier replacement.

title: A Postal Strike Means Fewer Gifts Under Canadian Christmas Trees
description: Every Christmas season, Elizabeth Teasdale sets aside an entire room in her house on Cape Breton Island in Nova Scotia to store presents for her family’s large holiday gathering. By now, 20 to 30 packages should be stashed away.

title: ‘Home Alone’ Hits the Road, With Macaulay Culkin. ‘Filthy Animals’ Cheer.
description: It has been 34 years since Kevin McAllister paint-canned two sour-faced bandits in “Home Alone.” And every Christmas since, fans have taken self-made tours of suburban Chicago sites in the classic holiday movie, which finds 8-year-old Kevin defending himself against robbers after his family leaves for a vacation without him. The stately residence where exteriors were shot in Winnetka, Ill., is the area’s top tourist attraction, with thousands of visitors annually.

title: A.T.F. Braces for a Likely Rollback of Its Gun-Control Efforts
description: Many federal agencies are bracing for the Trump era — but few are likely to face the powerful backlash that awaits the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, which pursued an aggressive gun control agenda under President Biden.

title: My Apartment Is Way Too Cold! How Do I Make the Landlord Fix It?
description: Q: We live in one of many Manhattan market-rate prewar rental buildings owned by a real estate family. We always had enough heat. Then the family hired a third-party management company. Now, a new heating system provides the legal minimum of 68.2 degrees of heat. At times, the heat rises, but not for very long. We are miserably cold. Many tenants here and elsewhere have complained. What can we do without provoking management retaliation? We fear our lease won’t be renewed if we speak up.

title: In Port Labor Dispute, Trump Backed a Union That Courted Him
description: Leaders of some labor unions tried to establish good relations with Donald J. Trump before the election — and for one of them, that effort may already be paying off.

title: Searching for Syria’s Disappeared
description: Taher al-Zain’s father disappeared 12 years ago at the height of Bashar al-Assad’s regime. Now, like thousands of other Syrians, he is trying to find clues about what happened, and whether or not his father may still be alive.

title: Why Democrats Lost More Seats in Vermont Than Any Other State
description: It was no surprise that most voters in Vermont rejected Donald J. Trump on Election Day, favoring Vice President Kamala Harris by a margin of more than 30 points.

title: An Artist Who Has Something in Common With Her Subjects
description: On the evening in early November when I met the artist Rachel Handlin at White Columns, the prestigious nonprofit gallery in the West Village, she immediately outstretched her arms.

title: Cajole, Plead and Flatter: Ukraine Makes Its Case to Trump
description: From desperate stabs at diplomacy to fanciful expressions of flattery, Ukrainian officials are doing everything they can to bring President-elect Donald J. Trump into their corner as they try to strengthen their position in the war against Russia.

title: Trump’s Transition Business Largely Happens After Night Falls
description: It was past midnight in Florida this week when President-elect Donald J. Trump decided to mock Justin Trudeau on social media, calling the prime minister of America’s neighbor the “governor” of “the Great State of Canada.”

title: In Display of Fealty, Tech Industry Curries Favor With Trump
description: The $1 million donations came gradually — and then all at once.

title: Syria Shudders as Assad’s Prison Atrocities Come Into the Light
description: People came by the thousands the day after the rebels arrived in Damascus, racing down the once desolate stretch of road, up a jagged footpath cut into the limestone hillside and through the towering metal gates of Syria’s most notorious prison. They flooded the halls lined with cells, searching for loved ones who had disappeared into the black hole of torture prisons under Bashar al-Assad’s government.

title: Rick Steves Refuses to Get Cynical About the World
description: The guidebook writer and television personality reflects on his cancer diagnosis, social media’s corrosive effect on tourism and the transformative power of travel.

title: Rick Steves Refuses to Get Cynical About the World
description: In 1994, just after I graduated from college, I put on a backpack and set off to see the world. I climbed the Andes in Ecuador, taught English in Cambodia and spent months visiting monasteries in Tibet. It was the most transformative period of my life.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,275
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion No. 553
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: A Rare Cross-Canada Political Consensus Forms Against Trump’s Border Threat
description: On Monday, Chrystia Freeland, the finance minister and deputy prime minister, will present her much-delayed fall economic statement just in time for the holidays. And the government has promised that it will address the issue that preoccupied politicians this week: how to respond to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threat to impose potentially devastating 25 percent tariffs on exports to the United States from Canada and Mexico unless the two nations tighten their borders.

title: Sweet Season
description: Cookie hive, assemble. Why? Because it’s the most wonderful time of the year.

title: Palestinian Authority Deploys Security Forces Against Militants in West Bank
description: The Palestinian Authority announced an unusually public crackdown on militants in the Israeli-occupied West Bank on Saturday, sending armored vehicles through a city’s streets and engaging in gun battles with armed groups.

title: Moody’s Downgrades France’s Credit Rating, Citing Political Turmoil
description: In a surprise announcement, Moody’s rating agency downgraded France’s debt rating early Saturday, hours after President Emmanuel Macron appointed a new prime minister in a bid to stabilize a government that has been rocked by months of political turmoil.

title: U.S. in Direct Contact With Rebels Who Took Over Syria
description: The United States has been in direct contact with the Syrian rebel group Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, which overthrew the dictatorship of Bashar al-Assad a week ago, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Saturday.

title: Joy and Celebrations in Seoul for Protesters as Yoon Is Impeached
description: Braving the cold, the protesters seeking President Yoon Suk Yeol’s ouster had gathered in the thousands on Saturday outside South Korea’s National Assembly, where lawmakers were to decide whether to impeach the leader. The crowd was boisterous in its insistence: “Impeach Yoon!”

title: Applying Psychotherapy to Heal Our Political Divide
description: To the Editor:

title: The Marketing Hurricane of ‘Wicked’ Says a Lot About Our Culture
description: Even before “Wicked” opened, the movie’s signature green and pink colors were turning up everywhere, from drinks topped with matcha foam at Starbucks to aisles lined with merch at Target. This cultural bludgeoning was, of course, orchestrated. Today, not even large marketing budgets can achieve such ubiquity without help.

title: The Menendez Brothers’ Case Challenges the Limits of Our Understanding of Abuse
description: Recently, a Los Angeles judge delayed a hearing for Erik and Lyle Menendez in their bid to be resentenced for the murder of their parents 35 years ago. Renewed interest in the brothers’ case, fueled by Netflix’s recent docudrama series and documentary on the brothers, has drawn celebrity advocates to call for their release, alongside an army of TikTok accounts. Unfortunately for the brothers, social advocacy rarely corresponds to judicial change.

title: How Sweden Could End Its Epidemic of Gang Violence
description: We used to believe in Sweden that the rights and well-being of children should always come first. But over the past two decades, a surge in gang violence has shaken that commitment. In 2023, 363 shootings took the lives of 53 people; this year, over 100 bombings stemming from gang violence had already been recorded by November. Our country now has one of the highest per capita rates of gun violence in the European Union. One key factor in the phenomenon: Gangs are grooming and recruiting children as young as 11, the police say, as contract killers.

title: The Unabomber’s Influence Is Deeper and More Dangerous Than We Know
description: I published a novel about the Unabomber this year, and during a book tour stop in Seattle, a high school teacher raised his hand and asked me what he could tell his students about Ted Kaczynski, because he was a hero to so many of them. The question stopped me cold, reminding me that Mr. Kaczynski’s influence is deeper and more widespread than most people realize.

title: Is There a Better $600 Investment?
description: One of the most dangerous things a woman can do in much of the world is become pregnant, and the risks caught up with a Kenyan named Alice Wanjiru a decade ago.

title: What Does Rupert Murdoch Do Now?
description: In the final season of “Succession,” the HBO drama about a fictional media clan, the show’s grisly patriarch, Logan Roy, dishes out some characteristically choice words to his privileged children: “I love you, but you are not serious people.”

title: Can We Make Pop Culture Great Again?
description: When “Wicked” and “Gladiator II” debuted together late last month, there was a painful attempt to call their shared box office success “Glicked” — a reference to the portmanteau of “Barbenheimer” that described the joint cultural triumph of “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” in the summer of 2023.

title: Vote For the Best Metropolitan Diary Entry of 2024
description: We will have published 250 Diary entries this year by the end of December. We need your help choosing the best. New York Times editors narrowed the field to five finalists. Now it’s up to you to vote for your favorite.

title: Sam Altman on Microsoft, Trump and Musk
description: Since kicking off the artificial intelligence boom with the launch of ChatGPT in 2022, OpenAI has amassed more than 300 million weekly users and a $157 billion valuation. Its C.E.O., Sam Altman, addressed whether that staggering pace of growth can continue at the DealBook Summit last week.

title: South Korea’s President Is Impeached After Martial Law Crisis
description: Eleven days ago, President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea made a bold power grab, putting the country under military rule for the first time in 45 years, citing frustration at the opposition for obstructing his agenda in Parliament.

title: Georgian Lawmakers Hand Presidency to Far-Right Former Soccer Star
description: Georgia’s governing lawmakers handed the presidency to a former soccer star turned far-right politician on Saturday, setting up a standoff with the sitting president and deepening the country’s political turmoil after weeks of protests and a disputed parliamentary election.

title: It’s Time for Nutella Tres Leches Cake
description: Nutella tres leches cake!

title: Trump Has Little Room for Error
description: The annals of American political history are littered with the remains of once-great presidential mandates.

title: Brazilian Police Arrest Close Ally of Ex-President Bolsonaro, Official Says
description: Brazilian police on Saturday arrested Gen. Walter Braga Netto, a close ally of former President Jair Bolsonaro and his running mate in 2022, according to a police official, accusing him of meddling in their investigation into a plot to stage a coup after Mr. Bolsonaro lost the election.

title: Pelosi Has Hip Replacement Surgery After Fall
description: Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, had hip replacement surgery on Saturday after falling while on an official trip to Luxembourg, her office said in a statement.

title: Argentina’s President Receives Italian Citizenship, Angering Law’s Critics
description: When President Javier Milei of Argentina stepped onto the grounds of Giorgia Meloni’s party festival at Rome’s Circus Maximus, a conservative fair that mixed holiday and Italy-First energy, he found a skating rink, a Christmas tree and an upbeat, anti-woke crowd.

title: Personal Data of Rhode Island Residents Breached in Large Cyberattack
description: The personal and private information of possibly hundreds of thousands of people who applied for government assistance in Rhode Island could be in the hands of hackers after a huge cyberattack, state officials said on Friday.

title: Thanks to a Prank, Sculptures Make Googly Eyes at Oregon Residents
description: If you travel through Bend, Ore., and have the feeling that you’re being watched, it’s not a stroke of paranoia: Googly eyes were affixed to eight public art sculptures around the city, to the chagrin of some local officials but to the delight of many residents.

title: South Korea’s Leadership Crisis, Explained
description: President Yoon Suk Yeol’s short-lived declaration of martial law has created South Korea’s biggest constitutional crisis since the country democratized in the late 1980s.

title: ABC to Pay $15 Million to Settle a Defamation Suit Brought by Trump
description: ABC News is set to pay $15 million to settle a defamation lawsuit brought by Donald J. Trump.

title: Hezbollah Loses Supply Route Through Syria, in Blow to It and Iran
description: The leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah acknowledged on Saturday that its supply route through Syria had been cut off by rebels who toppled the government last weekend, dealing another blow to Hezbollah and its patron, Iran.

title: Trump Brings Hegseth to Watch Army-Navy Game
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump attended the annual Army-Navy football game in Maryland on Saturday with Pete Hegseth, his embattled choice for defense secretary, sending a message of support ahead of Senate confirmation hearings that are likely to take place next month.

title: South Koreans Celebrate the President’s Impeachment in Seoul
description: A dozen members of President Yoon Suk Yeol’s own party helped remove him from office. Lawmakers sought to impeach the president after his declaration of martial law drew public outrage.

title: Robert Fernandez, Who Survived Pearl Harbor as a Teen, Dies at 100
description: Robert Fernandez, one of the last known American survivors of the bombing of Pearl Harbor, died on Wednesday in Lodi, Calif., just days after the 83rd anniversary of the attack. He was 100.

title: No Evidence Drones in Northeast Are a Threat, Officials Say
description: After reviewing thousands of tips, federal law enforcement officials on Saturday reaffirmed that mysterious drones spotted in the Northeast in recent weeks pose no national security threat and in most cases are not even drones.

title: Strong Storm Brings a Rarity in San Francisco: A Tornado Warning
description: Powerful storms swept through parts of Northern California on Saturday, knocking down trees, causing widespread power outages and prompting weather officials to issue what they said was the first-ever tornado warning for San Francisco.

title: Art Heist
description: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

title: Isak Andic, Founder of Mango Fashion Chain, Dies at 71
description: Isak Andic, who built the fashion brand Mango from a Spanish storefront into a global giant with more than 2,000 stores on five continents, died in a fall while hiking near Barcelona on Saturday. He was 71.

title: Trump Says He Supports an End to Daylight Saving Time
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump called daylight saving time “inconvenient, and very costly to our Nation” in a social media post on Friday and said the Republican Party would try to “eliminate” it, in the latest effort to end the twice-yearly time change.

title: Weeks of Drone Sightings Leave New Jersey on Edge
description: The day after Thanksgiving, Susan and Lorelai Woodruff saw approximately 10 brightly lit objects banking and turning quickly in the night sky above their home in Elsinboro, in southern New Jersey.

title: Devin Nunes, Pugnacious Trump Loyalist, to Lead Espionage Advisory Board
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump announced on Saturday that he would appoint Devin Nunes, a former member of Congress who had used his role as chairman of the House Intelligence Committee to try to delegitimize the Trump-Russia investigation, to head an independent advisory board on espionage policy.

title: Corrections: Dec. 14, 2024
description: An article on Friday about an agreement reached by the city of Louisville, Ky., and the Justice Department to address misconduct by Louisville police misstated the circumstances by which the police in Louisville searched the home of Breonna Taylor, who was fatally shot by officers. The police department had approval for a no-knock warrant to enter Ms. Taylor’s apartment, but officers were later instructed to knock and identify themselves. It is not the case that they used no warrant at all.

title: Quote of the Day: In the Land of Christmas Trees, Hope After Helene
description: “There’s such a difference between hurting without hope and hurting with hope.”

title: Corrections: Dec. 15, 2024
description: A picture caption in the table of contents for an article on Dec. 1 about war and superbugs misidentified the type of testing being performed. Test strips were used to identify bacteria, not to test for antibiotic resistance.

title: Trump Names Richard Grenell for ‘Special Missions’ Role
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump named Richard Grenell, his former ambassador to Germany and former acting director of national intelligence, as his “envoy for special missions,” Mr. Trump wrote on his Truth Social platform on Saturday.

title: A Christmas Gnome Tradition, More Than 1,000 Strong
description: First, advent calendars; then gnomes; then the tree; and then Christmas itself. Only as an adult did I discover that one element in this sequence separated us from other New York families. In my early childhood, my mother, awakened to a novel festive touch by a Swiss friend with Swedish tastes, had collected more than a hundred little hand-carved wooden figures — Scandinavian gnomes, dressed in red, mostly with cotton-wool hair.

title: As Ambassador, Rahm Emanuel Says His Impatience Nudged Japan Forward
description: Patience, Rahm Emanuel likes to say, is a waste of time.

title: Security Strategy of Recruiting Cheap Militiamen Backfires in Africa
description: They were falling asleep on a thin mat that they had been sharing since they were married five years ago. Suddenly, the roar of motorcycles woke them up. Armed men then dragged Rainatou Diallo and her husband, Adama Diallo, out of bed and into their courtyard.

title: ‘They Had the Desire to Return’
description: The skies were quiet the other night in the northwestern town of Tel Rifaat, Syria, and relief was palpable among fighters and civilians who have lived for years under the constant threat of bombardment.

title: This Unreadable Russian Novel Is Xi Jinping’s Spiritual Guide
description: In late October, while much of the world was focused on the buildup to the U.S. elections, President Xi Jinping of China was issuing a call for global resistance to the American-led world order.

title: With al-Assad Gone, the Risk of an ISIS Resurgence Grows
description: After more than 53 years of a brutal dictatorship and nearly 14 years of debilitating conflict, the Assad government fell in just under two weeks. The sudden collapse of the regime — which killed, tortured and repressed countless Syrians — has brought a remarkable sense of unity and euphoria across longstanding divides in the country.

title: At Least 11 Dead as Cyclone Devastates Islands in Indian Ocean
description: Tropical Cyclone Chido made landfall in Mozambique on Sunday after causing destruction in Mayotte, a French archipelago of about 300,000 people in the Indian Ocean, where at least 11 people died, France’s interior ministry said on Sunday.

title: Hochul May Face a Challenger She Knows Well: Her Lieutenant Governor
description: In the two months leading up to Election Day, Lt. Gov. Antonio Delgado’s schedule was booked solid, but not with the typical ribbon cuttings associated with the somewhat anonymous job of being New York’s No. 2.

title: An Epidemic of Vicious School Brawls, Fueled by Student Cellphones
description: Ricardo Martinez, an 11th grader, was in his high school lunchroom in April when a mass brawl erupted.

title: Automakers Thrived in the Pandemic. Many Are Now Struggling.
description: A few years ago, automakers were celebrating record profits as the pandemic created shortages of new cars, allowing them to raise prices. Now the hangover is setting in.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

title: ‘At the End of the Bench, a Man Was Leaning Against the Railing’
description: Dear Diary:

title: Walt Disney, Painted Out of the Photo
description: Jeff Roth, the caretaker of the morgue, The New York Times’s clippings and photo archive, was looking through the file of Igor Stravinsky, the Russian composer, this year when he discovered a curious black-and-white photo.

title: Saving Christmas in North Carolina, One Tree at a Time, After Hurricane Helene
description: Curve around the mountain on a cool, wet morning, and you’ll see them rising through the fog: row after row of silver-green trees, their layers of soft needles and branches primed to hold a string of lights, a glittering bauble or a child’s handmade ornament.

title: ​After Impeachment, South Korea Is Left With No Elected Leader
description: President Yoon Suk Yeol’s impeachment and suspension from office has left South Korea, one of the United States’ most important allies, without a strong​ elected leader to tackle challenges like a belligerent North Korea and a deepening political polarization at home.​

title: One Ski Resort’s Long-Shot Bet to Survive Low Snowfall and Devastating Wildfires
description: For much of its 85-year existence, the Mount Waterman resort has drawn skiers and outdoor enthusiasts from around Los Angeles for its no-fuss, no-frills experience.

title: The Rise of the Noodle Boys
description: He’s reedy like a long-distance runner; his flopsy curls tumble like overcooked fusilli. He’s attractive but in a way you can’t always put your finger on. He’s Hollywood’s white boy of the moment, and he has ambled into the movie industry to counter the broad and built look that the Marvel cinematic onslaught helped usher in during the 2000s.

title: Four Years Later, CrossFit’s Disgraced Guru Attempts a Comeback
description: In the summer of 2021, Josh Hunnicutt, a longtime personal trainer and the owner of the New Species CrossFit gym in Royal Oak, Mich., had a surprising opportunity: Greg Glassman, CrossFit’s contentious but charismatic co-founder, offered — more or less out of the blue — to pick him up in his private jet and fly him to a party in Ohio. The pitch was for the two of them to drink vodka sodas and rub elbows with other luminaries of the health and fitness industry.

title: It’s Hard to Be the Brother of a Genius Who Died Young
description: The lyricist Ira Gershwin once suggested his epitaph should be “Words Failed Me”: a joke tinged with ineffable sadness.

title: Weeks of Upheaval Have Paralyzed This South American Nation. Here’s Why.
description: Demonstrations have rocked Bolivia for more than two months. A longstanding political rivalry has boiled over, with supporters of the president and his chief opponent clashing in the streets. Protests have blocked the movement of goods, exacerbating fuel shortages. Some Bolivians lined up for days to buy gas.

title: The Alienation of Jaime Cachua
description: His wife was spiraling into insomnia, and his children were afraid to go to school, so Jaime Cachua sought out the person he trusted most in a crisis. He sat at his kitchen table in rural Georgia across from his father-in-law, Sky Atkins, the family patriarch. Jaime, 33, hadn’t seen his own father since he was 10 months old, when he left Mexico in a car seat bound for the United States. It was Sky, 45, who had stood by Jaime at his wedding, helped him move into his first house and stayed at the hospital overnight when one of Jaime’s children was sick with pneumonia.

title: The Connections Companion No. 554
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,276
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: For the Sake of 600,000 Children, Science Must Be Bold
description: Bold ideas in science research used to thrill us; now they seem pretty threatening. When I have written about the ethics of genetically engineered mosquitoes to combat malaria, many of my friends have expressed alarm. “What if it goes badly wrong?” they ask. What if there are unintended consequences that ripple across ecosystems? What if this is one of those technologies that cross the line from innovative to utterly world-destroying?

title: The Sunday Read: ‘What if A.I. Is Actually Good for Hollywood?’
description: “You couldn’t have made this movie three years ago,” said Robert Zemeckis, the director of “Here.”

title: The Trouble Began When #MeToo Became #ChurchToo
description: When did we know that the #MeToo moment was truly over?

title: Israel Strikes Military Sites in Syria, Monitor Says
description: Israel struck Syrian weapons depots and air defenses overnight, a group monitoring the conflict said Sunday, in what appeared to be part of an effort Israel says is aimed at depriving “extremists” of military assets after rebels seized power in Syria.

title: How Biden Should Spend His Final Weeks in Office
description: The days are dwindling to a precious few before President Biden relinquishes his tenancy at the White House to Donald Trump. Four years ago, in his Inaugural Address, Mr. Biden promised to “press forward with speed and urgency, for we have much to do in this winter of peril and possibility.” The peril remains, but so do the possibilities.

title: How Will the Rebels Rule Syria? Their Past Offers Clues.
description: Every fall, when farmers across the rolling, red dirt hills of Idlib Province in northern Syria harvest their olive crops, they routinely find at least one representative of the local tax authority stationed at any oil press.

title: A Trip to New York
description: It’s prime Yuletide in New York City.

title: Google’s Sundar Pichai on Antitrust, Trump and A.I.
description: Google got a head start in the artificial intelligence race, and at the DealBook Summit on Dec. 4, its chief executive, Sundar Pichai, snapped back at suggestions that it should be more competitive considering its vast resources.

title: My 500-Mile Journey Across Alaska’s Thawing Arctic
description: Flames were leaping out of the forest beneath the float plane taking us deep into the remote interior of northern Alaska. Our destination was the glacial Walker Lake, which stretches 14 miles through Gates of the Arctic National Park.

title: Don’t Cut an Agency So Vital to Our Health
description: To the Editor:

title: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Luigi Mangione Is Busting Out All Over
description: The 50th season of “Saturday Night Live” continues to provide the show with opportunities to revive many of its long-running characters. Last week, it was the Church Lady; this week, it was Nancy Grace, the TV personality and frequently outraged true-crime commentator, who has been frequently impersonated on “S.N.L.” over the years by cast members including Ana Gasteyer and Amy Poehler.

title: When ‘The Lord of the Rings’ Gets the Anime Treatment
description: When Warner Bros. approached the filmmaker Peter Jackson and his longtime screenwriting partner Philippa Boyens about making a new animated “Lord of the Rings,” Boyens at first had a hard time wrapping her head around the notion. But when studio executives suggested that the film could be told via Japanese anime — suddenly it clicked.

title: Israel’s Military Strikes Northern Gaza After Days of Deadly Bombardment
description: Israel’s military said it carried out strikes and raids in northern Gaza on Sunday after days of deadly bombardments across the territory.

title: Perfect Broiled Salmon, Beef Chow Fun and Mushroom Smash Burgers
description: Good morning. It’s list-making season. I’m cataloging gifts I want to give family and friends, tabulating all the work that needs to be done on the skiff before the fish return in the spring, putting basement chores on the docket, indexing every book I’ve read this year. I’m looking forward, looking back, taking stock and making plans.

title: Trump and His Picks Threaten More Lawsuits Over Critical Coverage
description: The legal threats have arrived in various forms. One aired on CNN. Another came over the phone. More arrived in letters or emails.

title: Israel Shutters Its Embassy in Ireland, Citing ‘Anti-Israel Policies’
description: Israel announced on Sunday that it was closing its embassy in Dublin in light of what it described as “the extreme anti-Israel policies of the Irish government.”

title: Grand Jury Said to Hear Evidence Against Chief Adviser to Mayor Adams
description: Manhattan prosecutors investigating corruption allegations against Ingrid Lewis-Martin, the chief adviser to Mayor Eric Adams, have presented evidence to a grand jury and could seek an indictment as soon as this week, people with knowledge of the matter said.

title: Graham Says Hegseth Plans to Release Accuser From Confidential Agreement
description: Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Defense Department, told Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina that he planned to release the woman who accused him of sexual assault from a confidential settlement agreement, Mr. Graham said on Sunday.

title: Jamie Foxx Recovering After Being Hit With a Glass in the Mouth
description: The Oscar-winning actor, singer and comedian Jamie Foxx was recovering after a physical altercation at a restaurant on Friday night in which someone from another table threw a glass that hit him in the mouth, a representative for the entertainer and the police said.

title: Read the email from Revere’s principal
description: The email the principal of Revere High School sent to parents about the June 2023 cafeteria fight.

title: Polly Mellen, Fashion’s Storied Cheerleader, Dies at 100
description: Polly Mellen, the irrepressible and indomitable fashion editor who was the last link to a long golden age when fashion editors were fearsome creatures who ruled by fiat, and a photograph in Vogue magazine, where Ms. Mellen worked for more than a quarter century, moved not just markets but the culture, died on Wednesday in Salisbury, Conn. She was 100 — an attractive round number, which Ms. Mellen, ever the perfectionist, surely appreciated.

title: Jury Awards Woman $34 Million for Wrongful Conviction
description: Kirstin Blaise Lobato, who spent nearly 16 years in prison for a murder she did not commit, was awarded more than $34 million by a federal jury in Nevada on Thursday.

title: See How Much NYC's Congestion Pricing Plan Would Cost You
description: A new toll on drivers hopes to reduce traffic in one of the world’s most congested cities. How would it work?

title: Monday Briefing: South Korea’s Power Vacuum
description: After South Korea’s National Assembly voted to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol on Saturday, people celebrated his removal from office, even as the country was left with a political vacuum at the top that could last for months.

title: Man Gets 100 Years in Prison for His Role in 2020 Shooting Spree
description: A Texas man has been sentenced to at least 100 years in prison for his part in a two-state shooting spree on Thanksgiving Day in 2020 that killed one person and wounded several others across Nevada and Arizona.

title: Lorraine O’Grady, Artist Who Defied Category, Is Dead at 90
description: Lorraine O’Grady, a conceptual artist who had careers as a research economist, literary translator and rock critic before producing her first art in her 40s, and who went on to influence a generation of younger Black artists, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90.

title: Expect Icy Roads in Parts of the Northeast on Monday Morning
description: Light snowfall and sleet overnight in parts of Connecticut, New Jersey, New York was expected to make roads icy for Monday morning commuters, forecasters said.

title: Two Alvin Ailey Productions Head for the Light
description: Dancers moving from being scorned to rocking their souls in the bosom of Abraham — this is the narrative arc of Alvin Ailey’s masterpiece, “Revelations.” And that redemptive passage into the light is the template that many choreographers for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater try to replicate.
