description: A New Jersey appellate court ruled Wednesday that the state’s attorney general, Matthew J. Platkin, had overstepped his authority when he seized control of the police department in Paterson, the state’s third-largest city.

title: Drug Charges Against Sean Combs Associate Are Dropped in Florida
description: An associate of Sean Combs who was arrested on drug possession charges in March amid the federal raids on Mr. Combs’s homes has had the case against him dropped after he completed a diversion program, his lawyer announced.

title: Read the decision
description: A court ruled that the New Jersey attorney general, Matthew J. Platkin, overstepped his authority by seizing control of the Paterson Police Department.

title: How to Read the Fed’s Projections Like a Pro
description: Federal Reserve officials are scheduled to release a fresh set of economic projections alongside their rate decision on Wednesday, forecasts that will offer a fresh glimpse of just how much and how quickly central bankers expect interest rates to come down.

title: What Fed Rate Moves Mean for Your Finances
description: The Federal Reserve is expected to lower its key rate by another quarter point on Wednesday, marking its third consecutive cut since September. In total, rates will have dropped by a full percentage point since then.

title: Prisoner’s Self-Portraits of C.I.A. Torture Surface From Sealed Court Record
description: Alone in his cell with only dark thoughts of desperate times, the prisoner put pencil to paper and drew detailed portraits of how American agents tortured him 20 years ago.

title: Central Bankers Around the Globe Gird Themselves for Another Trump Term
description: Just as central bankers around the world were growing more confident that inflation was coming back under control and growth stabilizing, a new economic threat looms: potentially hefty tariffs imposed by President-elect Donald J. Trump.

title: Aghast at a Move to Revoke the Polio Vaccine
description: To the Editor:

title: ‘Murder Hornet’ Has Been Eradicated From the U.S., Officials Say
description: The hunt for the “murder hornet” in the northwest corner of Washington State began like a criminal investigation, with bee carcasses creating a crime scene and the public being asked to send tips about the potential culprit’s whereabouts.

title: Miami Broker Turns Himself In to Face Sexual Battery Charge
description: Ohad Fisherman, who is accused along with the real estate agent Oren Alexander and his twin brother, Alon Alexander, of participating in an alleged sexual assault in 2016, surrendered to authorities in Miami on Wednesday. A judge said she would release Mr. Fisherman on bond after his family secured funds.

title: Senate Clears Defense Bill Denying Transgender Care to Minors
description: The Senate on Wednesday gave final approval to a defense policy bill directing $895 billion toward the Pentagon and other military activities, moving over the objections of some Democrats who opposed a provision added late in the negotiations that would deny coverage for transgender health procedures for minors.

title: Ivy League Agrees to Let Football Teams Compete in the Postseason Next Year
description: Among the tens of thousands of college athletes who compete for an N.C.A.A. championship, there is one subset who never get the chance: Ivy League football players.

title: Defense Bill Orders Military to Take New Action on Brain Injury
description: Congress passed a sweeping new set of mandates on brain safety in the military Wednesday, requiring the Pentagon to set new safety limits for troops’ blast exposure, track and report exposures throughout their careers, modify existing weapons to reduce the danger and, for the first time, take brain safety into account when designing new weapons.

title: They Fought for Assad in Syria. Now They’re Handing in Their Guns.
description: Across Syria, soldiers tied to the former Assad regime are surrendering their weapons to the interim government. The New York Times spoke to some of these men in Latakia, as they face a new and uncertain future as civilians.

title: What to Know About the Charges Against Luigi Mangione
description: Luigi Mangione, the man arrested in the Dec. 4 killing of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive, has been charged with crimes in both New York and Pennsylvania, including a terrorism count.

title: New York City to Pay $92.5 Million to Improperly Detained Immigrants
description: For years, federal immigration agents had a reliable place to find undocumented immigrants they wanted to deport: New York City jails.

title: Democrats, Don’t Forget the Atheists
description: Sometimes it feels like white Christians are the only religious voting bloc with true sway in America. Conservative evangelicals in particular have a great deal of power in the Republican Party, thanks to their tight embrace of Donald Trump. I often hear people talk about how Democrats can win back some white Christian support, as if that should be the party’s priority in the coming years.

title: Inside a Huge Spending Deal: Disaster Money, a Football Stadium and More
description: The stopgap spending bill congressional leaders agreed on this week began as a simple funding measure to keep government funds flowing past a Friday night deadline and into early next year, long after House Republicans elect a speaker and President-elect Donald J. Trump is sworn in.

title: White House Pushes to Find American Journalist Abducted in Syria
description: The White House has given the rebel group that toppled the Syrian government a list of former officials who might have knowledge about Austin Tice, an American journalist who was abducted in Damascus in 2012.

title: Can Anyone Make Sense of Luigi Mangione? Maybe His Favorite Writer.
description: Almost immediately after Luigi Mangione was arrested last week in connection with the killing of Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, you could go pretty deep into the rabbit hole of Mangione’s particular internet. At the top of his X feed, I noticed a reference to the work of Tim Urban, the popular blogger, essayist and author of the website Wait but Why and a 2023 book dilating on the problems of uncivil political discourse, called “What’s Our Problem?”

title: Justices to Hear Case on South Carolina’s Bid to Defund Planned Parenthood
description: The Supreme Court agreed on Wednesday to consider whether South Carolina may eliminate Medicaid funding for any medical services offered by Planned Parenthood because it performs abortions.

title: Under Pressure, Hyundai Supplier Ends Alabama Prison Labor Contract
description: After facing public scrutiny for the use of prison labor, a supplier to the South Korean automaker Hyundai said it had dismissed dozens of incarcerated men it had employed through the Alabama Department of Corrections and ended its inmate labor contract with the state.

title: Sir Lady Java, ’60s Drag Star Who Challenged the Law, Dies
description: At first, it was lonely being Sir Lady Java.

title: 2 Endangered Whales Found Entangled in Fishing Gear, With 1 Likely to Die
description: Two endangered whales have been found entangled in fishing gear off the coast of Massachusetts, and one of them is likely to die from his injuries, according to the federal agency that monitors the oceans.

title: California Declares an Emergency Over Bird Flu in Cattle
description: In a stark acknowledgment of the increasing seriousness of bird flu’s spread, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California declared on Wednesday that the outbreak of infections among the state’s dairy cattle constituted an emergency.

title: Megan Thee Stallion Seeks Restraining Order Against Tory Lanez
description: Megan Thee Stallion has asked a court in Los Angeles to issue a restraining order against the rapper Tory Lanez, who is currently in prison serving a 10-year sentence for shooting her in 2020. Her lawyers said he had been waging a “campaign of harassment” against her from behind bars.

title: For a Desperate Few, a Hectic Escape From Gaza
description: The war is nearly impossible to flee — except for a small number of sick and wounded who are offered a dramatic path to safety.

title: Man Who Ran Secret Police Office in New York Admits He Was Chinese Agent
description: A man pleaded guilty in federal court in Brooklyn on Wednesday to charges that he had worked as an unauthorized agent of the Chinese government, running a police outpost in Lower Manhattan as part of an effort to quash criticism of Beijing.

title: Florida Charges Man Suspected of Trump Assassination Plot
description: Florida officials filed charges on Wednesday against the man accused of trying to assassinate President-elect Donald J. Trump at his West Palm Beach golf course in September, defying federal prosecutors who had asked the state to suspend its investigation while their own moved forward.

title: $100,000 Loan for Porsche at Center of Charges Against Former Adams Aide
description: Ingrid Lewis-Martin, the former chief adviser to Mayor Eric Adams, is expected to surrender on Thursday on bribery charges involving two businessmen who gave her son a $100,000 loan to buy a Porsche, several people with knowledge of the matter said.

title: Wednesday Briefing: Russia Arrests a Suspected Assassin
description: The Russian authorities said yesterday that they had detained a suspect in the killing of a senior military officer, Lt. Gen. Igor Kirillov. The officer, who died in a bombing on Tuesday, was the target of the most prominent political assassination in Russia since the invasion.

title: Stocks Plunge as Fed Forecasts Fewer Rate Cuts Next Year
description: Stocks slumped, the dollar soared and the cost of borrowing money rose on Wednesday, as the Fed dialed down expectations for interest rate cuts next year given the continued strength of the U.S. economy.

title: The Wrath of Trump: House Republicans Map a Case Against Liz Cheney
description: For years, President-elect Donald J. Trump has made it known that people he believes to be his enemies should be prosecuted.

title: Senators Call for Investigation of Medicaid Work Requirement Program
description: A group of Democratic senators said on Wednesday that they had called for a federal watchdog investigation into a controversial Medicaid work requirement program in Georgia, accusing its administrators of churning through tens of millions of dollars in funding while enrolling a fraction of the low-income residents estimated to be eligible for it.

title: The Federal Reserve Cuts Interest Rates By a Quarter Percentage Point
description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, announced the central bank’s final interest rate cut for the year and suggested only two more reductions in 2025.

title: Bat Feces Used to Fertilize Cannabis Is Linked to 2 Deaths
description: Two men died after they contracted a rare fungal infection from exposure to bat feces, also known as guano, that they were using to grow cannabis plants, according to a report published in a medical journal.

title: Think You’re High Class? How Do You Feel About Twice-Baked Potatoes?
description: When, after you have cleaned out your sock drawer and stopped doomscrolling for sanity’s sake in the idle space between 3 and 4 a.m., sleep still refuses to come, there remains one option. There is the ubiquitous personality quiz.

title: Trump Criticizes Spending Deal, Pushing Congress Toward a Shutdown
description: A bipartisan spending deal to avert a shutdown was on life support on Wednesday after President-elect Donald J. Trump condemned it, leaving lawmakers without a strategy to fund the government past a Friday night deadline.

title: Trump Takes Credit for New Border Security Plan Outlined by Canada
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Wednesday took credit for a new border security plan — that was announced by Canada.

title: F.B.I. Searches Home of L.A. Deputy Mayor Suspected of Bomb Threat Against City Hall
description: F.B.I. agents searched the home of a Los Angeles deputy mayor this week as part of an investigation into a bomb threat that officials believe he made against City Hall earlier this year.

title: ‘Skibidi Toilet’ Has Come to Fortnite. What the Heck Is It?
description: Do you like video games? Have you ever wanted to control Indiana Jones as he faces off against a sentient banana, or to lay siege to Eminem’s underground lair? Then, dear player, Fortnite is up your alley.

title: The Fed Cut Rates and Signaled a Long Fight Against Inflation
description: Federal Reserve officials made their third and final rate cut of 2024 today, reducing borrowing costs by a quarter of a percentage point. They also shook up financial markets by forecasting notably higher inflation and two fewer rate cuts in 2025 than they had previously expected.

title: Youth Climate Activists Get Major Win in Montana Supreme Court
description: The Montana Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld a landmark victory for youth climate activists, affirming a decision by a lower court last year that the state’s energy policies violated their constitutional rights to a clean environment.

title: A Ten Commandments Tablet Sells for More Than $5 Million at Auction
description: A stone tablet that was described by Sotheby’s as the oldest in the world inscribed with the Ten Commandments sold on Wednesday for just over $5 million to an anonymous buyer who plans to donate it to an Israeli institution, the auction house said.

title: Education Dept. Reverses Itself and Reopens Two Loan Repayment Plans
description: The Education Department reopened enrollment on Friday in two student loan repayment plans it had sought to replace, allowing borrowers to transfer out of the alternative program it had proposed, which has been frozen by litigation since July.

title: Google Street View Captures a Man Loading a Bag Into a Trunk. Arrests Follow.
description: It was a routine image picked up by Google Street View: a man loading a white bag into the trunk of a car.

title: The New Politics
description: In the month since President-elect Donald Trump won the U.S. presidential election, there has been much debate over what led to his clear but narrow victory. At a task force session at the DealBook Summit, The Times’s senior political correspondent Maggie Haberman moderated a thoughtful, nuanced and sometimes contentious debate among political figures, advisers and journalists about what happened. Heres what they said.

title: The Rev. James Callan, Renegade Catholic Priest, Dies at 77
description: The Rev. James B. Callan, a renegade priest who was excommunicated in 1999 after he offered holy communion to non-Catholics, allowed women to celebrate Mass and blessed same-sex unions — and who then helped establish an independent Catholic church that is thriving a quarter-century later — died on Friday in Rochester, N.Y. He was 77.

title: How Worried Should We Be About Bird Flu?
description: California has declared a state of emergency over the outbreak of bird flu among dairy cows.

title: E.P.A. Allows California to Ban Sales of New Gas-Powered Cars by 2035
description: The Biden administration on Wednesday granted California and 11 other states permission to ban the sale of new gasoline-powered cars by 2035, one of the most ambitious climate policies in the United States and beyond.

title: Temporarily Disconnected From Politics? Feel No Guilt About It.
description: The Sunday after Election Day, Jamal Bryant, the senior pastor at the predominantly Black New Birth Missionary Baptist Church, a megachurch in Stonecrest, just east of Atlanta, issued an altar call for the Black women in attendance. Once they had come forward, the Rev. Karri Turner, Bryant’s fiancée at the time and now his wife, told them: “My words and my heart to you this morning is not to charge you to run to another fight, not to charge you to take on another issue. But my charge to you in this moment is to pause and to take a time of Sabbath.”

title: The Case for Throwing Stones From a Glass House
description: When she finally had the chance to confront her rapist in open court, she didn’t flinch. “What you did was bad,” she told the pastor. “Don’t do that to any other girl.”

title: An Election Draw Decided by a Straw
description: We know by now that America is a land of deep political division and heated red-on-blue, blue-on-red, red-on-red and blue-on-blue rancor.

title: Congestion Pricing Settlement Stalls Between New York and New Jersey
description: Negotiations between the feuding states of New York and New Jersey over the future of congestion pricing have stalled, possibly setting the stage for another last-minute suspension of the tolling plan that is scheduled to begin next month.

title: Corrections: Dec. 19, 2024
description: An article on Tuesday about New Jersey Gov. Philip D. Murphy commuting the prison sentences of three women who had been abused and were convicted of killing men close to them misstated the circumstances of the crimes committed. They were all convicted of killing men close to them. The victims were not all boyfriends of the women.

title: Suspect in Insurance C.E.O.’s Murder Is Said to Face Federal Charges
description: The suspect in the fatal shooting of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive on a Manhattan sidewalk this month will now face federal charges in addition to the state murder indictment brought against him, according to three people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Baby Bear
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Editors’ Note
New York City Approves New Contract for Specialized High School Test
description: A New York City education panel voted late Wednesday night to approve a new contract for a contentious testing system for admission into the city’s elite public high schools.

title: Quote of the Day: A Top van Gogh Is Out of View. The Hunt Is On.
description: “It is part of history, but it is also part of our lives now, and not knowing where it is is unbearable.”

title: Starbucks Has a Pumpkin Spice Latte Problem in China
description: Starbucks has a China problem: coffee and tea drinkers who want more for less.

title: G.M. Led in China for Years. Here’s How It Ended Up 16th in Sales.
description: General Motors was a pioneer in China, where for a quarter-century the company drew enormous profits and vied with Germany’s Volkswagen as the top seller of cars.

title: The Pelicot Trial: A Timeline
description: Dominique Pelicot, the ex-husband of Gisèle Pelicot, was convicted on Thursday of aggravated rape and other charges after admitting to drugging and raping Ms. Pelicot for almost a decade, and arranging for dozens of strangers he met online to abuse her unconscious body.

title: Europe Has a Leadership Vacuum. How Will It Handle Trump?
description: When President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine met European leaders for dinner in Brussels on Wednesday, the shadow of President-elect Donald J. Trump hung over the gathering. But it is not just Mr. Trump’s return to the White House that has scrambled Europe’s response to the war in Ukraine.

title: Thursday Briefing
description: Hundreds of soldiers and police officers who served under Bashar al-Assad heeded the call of Syria’s new rulers to formally relinquish their ties to his ousted regime.

title: Bibi Netanyahu Is Failing Ever Upward
description: In late November the International Criminal Court in The Hague issued an unusual set of arrest warrants: one for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, one for his former defense minister Yoav Gallant and one for the deceased Hamas military chief, Muhammad Deif. Each man was accused of crimes against humanity and war crimes related to the ongoing conflict in Gaza.

title: Chinese Spacewalk Apparently Breaks a Record (Barely)
description: Two Chinese astronauts aboard their country’s orbiting space station spent nine hours working outside in the cold vacuum of space, the longest recorded spacewalk, the Chinese space administration has said.

title: Chinese Astronauts Spend 9 Hours Outside Space Station
description: The spacewalk appears to be the longest in history, barely breaking a record set by American astronauts in 2001.

title: Word of the Day: combustion
description: The word combustion has appeared 97 times on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 7 in The New York Times Magazine article “One City’s Secret to Happiness: The Annual Burning of a 50-Foot Effigy” by Caity Weaver:

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

title: It Was a Haven for New York Families. Now They Can’t Afford to Stay.
description: Caroline Fermin is part of a close circle of friends with children in the Washington Heights neighborhood in Upper Manhattan. They push strollers along tree-shaded blocks and meet up for play dates and birthdays.

title: Holiday Hints From a Gift-Guide Maker
description: You probably have gifts on your mind right now. Mari Uyehara is thinking about them all year long.

title: 2024 in Pictures
description: In her introduction to “2024: The Year in Pictures,” Carolyn Ryan, a managing editor for The New York Times, writes:

title: They Thought It Was an Old Baseball. It Was a Mastodon Tooth.
description: A married couple arrived in Cory Harris’s office in late September, carrying a plain cardboard box about the size of a dictionary. They were excited to open it, and to show Dr. Harris the amazing things inside.

title: Late Night Continues to Drone On About Sightings in the Sky
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: The Face of Courage
description: Until Sept. 2, 2024, most of the world did not really know what Gisèle Pelicot looked like.

title: The Design Trend Taking Over Rural America
description: In the 1980s, the “barndominium” was designed with the horse owner in mind. A Connecticut developer came up with the name — a mash-up of “barn” and “condominium” — to refer to a lot and horse stall purchased together, in a subdivision where owners had a stake in a shared equestrian center.

title: ‘The Mark Leyner Reader’ Doesn’t Mean Mark Leyner Is Done Writing
description: Describe your ideal reading experience.

title: When a Barndominium Won’t Do, Try a Shouse
description: The world of real estate has no shortage of mash-ups — condops and dockominiums, starchitects and plyscrapers. One of the most recent additions to the lexicon is the shouse, which is not to be confused with the barndominium.

title: Maxed Out on L.A., He Chased His Hollywood Dream to Albuquerque
description: In March, Raul Riveros showed up for work on a Jonah Hill movie when he keeled over in pain and was promptly rushed to the emergency room. He had undergone several surgeries to repair hernias he suffered from lifting large carts containing monitors and computers, and now a mesh implant had become entangled with his intestines.

title: Biden, Headed to the Exit, Sets an Aggressive Climate Goal for the U.S.
description: President Biden on Thursday announced an aggressive new climate goal for the United States, saying that the country should seek to slash its greenhouse gas emissions by at least 61 percent below 2005 levels by 2035.

title: Weight Loss Drugs Changed Their Lives. Then They Lost Coverage.
description: The letter came in June. Mindy McCormick, 67, read that her insurer would soon stop covering the weight loss drug Wegovy, which she had been taking for more than two years.

title: How to Actually Sleep on an Airplane
description: What’s worse than being crammed in a too tight, too upright seat on an overnight flight? Being wide-awake the entire time. Short of receiving a golden ticket (i.e., an upgrade to a lie-flat pod), there are some strategies for making a long flight more restful so you won’t arrive feeling totally wrecked.

title: As China Seeks Influence, It Has a Cuddly Way Into City Hall: Pandas
description: After joining the Chinese leader Xi Jinping for dinner last year, Mayor London Breed of San Francisco accompanied him to the airport to bid him farewell. There, on the tarmac, she made her request: pandas.

title: Best TV Episodes of 2024
description: This list may not be as definitive as our best-of-the-year list — no human can watch every episode of TV made in a year — and it includes many less-than-famous titles. But for my money, it is always the most fun list to put together. What you learn, spending a year watching series after series that you may never end up writing about, is that greatness can pop up anywhere, sometimes where you would expect it, sometimes in an offbeat documentary or an off-the-radar streaming curio.

title: Digging Deep for Musical Gems: The Year in 18 Boxed Sets and Reissues
description: Every year, recording companies plunge deeper into their vaults, unveiling demos, outtakes, rough drafts, live recordings and more. The boxed sets that emerge from those excavations are reminders of all the options and decisions that go into every official album release. This year’s crop reveals artists at work, with plenty of opportunities to second-guess — or appreciate anew — their stray inspirations and forking paths. Here the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times discuss 18 of the year’s most notable boxed sets.

title: Cooper Hewitt’s Triennial Critiques American Power but Is Shy on Solutions
description: When the Cooper Hewitt introduced its triennial design series, in 2000, the goal was straightforward: to offer a snapshot of the field that reflected, typically with an optimistic gloss, the preoccupations and triumphs of American designers. Early editions were filled with consumer products in a range of streamlined, candy-colored styles; recent shows have added healthy portions of save-the-planet ingenuity. Toothbrushes and sneakers on 1. Biodegradable tires on 3.

title: Skiing’s Budget Secret: It Can Be Cheaper in Europe
description: This winter, if the bookings at Ski.com, North America’s largest ski-focused travel agency, are any indication, one of skiing’s biggest secrets is out: It can be cheaper to ski in Europe than at a U.S. mountain resort.

title: The Wedding Vendors Helping L.G.B.T.Q. Couples Marry Before Trump’s Next Term
description: Ashley Adams and Madeline Shelton didn’t have much time to pick out their wedding outfits, but they were both happy with what they wore to their Dec. 17 “microwedding,” as they called it, in Beaverton, Ore.

title: The Year in Micro News
description: Plenty of big news happened in 2024. A top presidential candidate dropped out of the race late; another survived two assassination attempts; and voters rejected the incumbent administration at the ballot box. This year also included conflicts abroad, the Summer Olympics and two (yes, two) Emmy Award ceremonies.

title: How to Dance Through the Holidays
description: The dancer and choreographer Angela Trimbur may qualify as New York’s most whimsical dance teacher, with more than 100,000 followers on Instagram alone watching her get silly and spin. Her classes and recitals draw dancers with little experience — and those burned out on the rigors of formal (read: judgmental) training. The ethos is that movement should be accessible and fun for everyone, no matter whether you can tell a box step from a pas de bourrée.

title: Obscene Prices, Declining Quality: Luxury Is in a Death Spiral
description: The holiday shopping season is hitting its apex. And do you know what I, a longtime fashion editor, will not be buying my loved ones this year? Big-name luxury fashion. I’d sooner set my eyebrows on fire.

title: The Year Country Went Everywhere, and Everyone Went Country
description: For a clear glimpse into the evolving soul of modern country music, you could have done far worse than to travel to Charleston, W.Va., this fall to catch a stop on Jelly Roll’s headlining arena tour.

title: Here Are 4 Reasons China Meddles in Local U.S. Politics
description: When a former aide to New York’s governor was charged this year with acting as a Chinese agent, the federal indictment suggested a surprising level of interest by Beijing in state-level governance in the United States.

title: Two Debut Games That Are Captivating and Strange
description: As we race to the end of 2024, the number of new video games has slowed to a trickle. Thankfully, those looking for grand, sweeping fare have Indiana Jones and the Great Circle to keep them busy. But for anyone looking for something more compact and under the radar, here are two recent debuts from tiny development studios that are noteworthy for their winning strangeness.

title: Even Mobile-Home Prices Keep Rising
description: The U.S. housing market is on track for its second straight year of historically sluggish sales, the result of scant inventory, high prices and stubborn interest rates. Many prospective buyers are sticking with the rental market, but even people considering more affordable options are facing headwinds: According to a study by LendingTree, the average price of new manufactured homes — also know as mobile homes — is rising faster than that of new single-family homes.

title: ‘The Count of Monte Cristo’ Review: Mission Impeccable
description: Adapting “The Count of Monte Cristo,” Alexandre Dumas’s voluminous adventure yarn, is not for the fainthearted. But the French filmmakers Matthieu Delaporte and Alexandre de la Patellière prove lacking in neither heart nor style: Refusing to pander to restless derrières, they’ve given this big, bounding, beautifully cinematic swashbuckler almost three hours to breathe. Yet their pacing is so frisky — and Celia Lafitedupont’s editing so elegant — your derrière is unlikely to complain.

title: ‘The Room Next Door’ Review: A Life Worth Leaving
description: At the end of James Joyce’s 1914 story “The Dead,” the main character is watching the snow fall on Dublin, late in the dark after a Twelfth Night dinner party. He’s just learned something profoundly affecting about his wife’s past, something he didn’t know until now, and it’s made him ruminative. Some day, every person he knows — even him — will be nothing more than memory. This thought is mortal, but not morbid. He finds it moving. “His soul swooned slowly,” Joyce writes, “as he heard the snow falling faintly through the universe and faintly falling, like the descent of their last end, upon all the living and the dead.”

title: ‘Mufasa: The Lion King’ Review: Squeaking, Not Roaring
description: The fur looks more silkily luxurious in “Mufasa: The Lion King,” the African landscapes bolder and brighter, but much remains the same in its horizonless empire. Just five years ago, in the photorealistic remake of the first “Lion King,” Mufasa — the big cool cat then voiced with imperial gravitas by James Earl Jones — was ruling his animated kingdom with the kind of benevolent authoritarianism that suggests Hollywood isn’t the progressive hotbed it’s reputed to be. By the end, villainy was vanquished, order restored and hereditary monarchy reconfirmed. The circle of life, as the song goes, remained reassuringly unbroken.

title: ‘Sonic the Hedgehog 3’ Review: Life Comes at You Fast
description: Sonic the Hedgehog has always been a star. When introduced in the early 1990s, the fuzzy blue speedball was the mascot and lead character for Sega’s home video game console, a potent rival to Nintendo’s plumber Mario, who originated in arcade games. Mario got a still-risible start in movies back in 1993, in “Super Mario Bros.,” a live-action picture starring Bob Hoskins and John Leguizamo that has since developed a cult following. He bounced back in 2023 with an animated adventure replete with eye-popping graphics but lacking a certain “it’s-a me” charm.

title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Staten Island
description: A two-bedroom, two-bath, 900-square-foot duplex condo with a private entrance, a kitchen with a vented range, an open living and dining area, an upper-level terrace, zoned electric heat, a vented washer/dryer and outdoor access to a patio and driveway, on the first two floors of a four-story walk-up with a super. Jeremy Kamm and Josue Gonzalez, Coldwell Banker Warburg, 212-439-4561; cbwarburg.com

title: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
description: A five-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath, 4,068-square-foot home from 1976 with hardwood floors, a living room with a large wood-burning fireplace, an open family room with a bay window that connects to an eat-in kitchen, an en suite primary bedroom with an oversized walk-in closet and a jetted tub, an office with a skylight, a laundry room, and a two-car attached garage, on 1.43 acres on a cul-de-sac. Beth Saunders, 203-913-2762, Berkshire Hathaway HomeServices, bhhsneproperties.com

title: In This Industrial Design Class, Students Eat Their Homework
description: From the first meeting of the industrial design class he took this fall, Zhiye Lin knew he was at a disadvantage. The other 10 students were experienced cooks. Mr. Lin was not.

title: ‘It’s a Beaut, Clark!’ What’s It Take to Light Up the Griswold House?
description: How much power does it take to light 25,000 imported Italian twinkle lights?

title: 10 Life Lessons for Grown-Ups From Children’s Classics
description: It’s easy to get sentimental about the joy children’s books bring to kids. But picture books must also be read by adults, who, depending on the text, may not be quite as charmed. (My sympathies to anyone worn out by the vast “Biscuit” oeuvre.)

title: Bodies in Repose? Not at This MoMA Show.
description: Any show about “the body” has the backhanded blessing of wide appeal. Everybody has one — so what? The thesis of “Vital Signs: Artists and the Body,” a survey of more than 65 modern and contemporary artists currently on view at the Museum of Modern Art, is more specific than its title suggests: It proposes that 20th-century artists used abstraction to explore the human body’s changeability, and press the limits of identity.

title: The Congresswoman Wore an F.D.N.Y. Jacket
description: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll find out why former Representative Carolyn Maloney wore a firefighter’s jacket for a just-unveiled portrait. We’ll also get details on the bribery investigation involving Mayor Eric Adams’s former chief adviser.

title: Luka Doncic Wants Young Players to Embrace ‘Mess and Joy’
description: Luka Doncic was 13 when he moved from his native Slovenia to Spain to play for Real Madrid. He didn’t know English or Spanish, but he could speak basketball fluently, and the expectations of a storied professional organization hung over him.

title: With al-Assad Gone, Syrians in Homs Assess the Destruction
description: Members of the family ducked under an empty doorway and stepped over the rubble from their home.

title: 36 Hours in Innsbruck, Austria
description: Futuristic architecture rubs shoulders with centuries-old opera houses in this picture-perfect Austrian ski town.

title: The Jewelry of the Moment Is Bigger and Bolder. And Silver!
description: In the 1980s and ’90s, Robert Lee Morris’s sculptural silver earrings, breastplates and cuffs earned him certain trappings of fashion stardom: a yearslong collaboration with Donna Karan, a friendship with Karl Lagerfeld, exporting his namesake jewelry brand to Japan.

title: Thomas Friedman on Syria, the U.S. and Trump
description: The New York Times Opinion columnist Thomas Friedman and the Opinion editor Daniel Wakin discuss how and why the United States should use its influence in Syria following the ousting of its longtime dictator Bashar al-Assad.

title: The Moments That Shaped 2024, in 17 Photos
description: The people, places and objects that held our collective attention in this election year.

title: Traveling for Christmas? Here’s Where Weather May Snarl Your Plans.
description: It’s time for holiday cheer around the fire, sweaters in the snow and cozy gatherings out of the winter wind.

title: Suspect in C.E.O. Killing Agrees to Be Extradited to New York
description: The 26-year-old man accused of murdering a health care executive in Manhattan agreed at a court hearing on Thursday to be extradited to New York, where he is facing a first-degree murder charge.

title: Where Does a ‘Remarkable’ U.S. Economy Go From Here?
description: The U.S. economy is pulling ahead of its global peers. Inflation is moderating, and the Federal Reserve is cutting interest rates.

title: How to Make the Drone Panic So Very Much Worse
description: In 1954, a few people in the town of Bellingham, Wash., reported seeing pits and dings on their windshields — perhaps the work of vandals. Roadblocks were quickly set up. This became front-page news in nearby Seattle, prompting people to rush to check their own windshields. Thousands then reported that they, too, had mysterious dings, in an ever-widening area from Seattle to Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: How Do You Feel About Winter?
description: Winter in the Northern Hemisphere officially begins on Dec. 21. Is this a season you look forward to each year? Or do you dread the onset of these dark, cold months?

title: A D.I.Y. ‘Messiah,’ Starring You and Yours as Choristers
description: The orchestra was done tuning. The soloists had taken their seats at the front of the stage and the conductor had ascended the podium. But there was one more item of business before Tuesday’s performance of Handel’s “Messiah” by the National Chorale at David Geffen Hall could begin. “You know what we need to do,” the conductor Everett McCorvey said, gesturing for audience members to rise from their seats. “We have to warm up.” Then he led the whole auditorium in a sequence of lip trills and scales.

title: The Queer Book Shops Opening Across the Country
description: When the stylist Beverly Nguyen opened her Manhattan home and gift store, Beverly’s, in April 2021, she kept thinking of her grandmother who ran what Nguyen calls an “everything shop” in Vietnam. It carried snacks, drinks, beauty products and even refrigerators. “She transformed the space depending on what people needed,” says Nguyen, “and that’s exactly my ethos with Beverly’s,” which sells objects ranging from handcrafted ceramics to bamboo steamers. Now, a new line of three-in-one home, fabric and body sprays draws on Nguyen’s family history and her own early years in Orange County, Calif. One of the three scents, Dawn, which has hints of lemon, orange blossom and musk, is designed to capture the magic of 5 a.m. trips to the beach to watch the sunrise. Joy Ride, which has notes of sandalwood, white vetiver and leather, was inspired by excursions in the family’s Mercedes convertible. “My dad would be driving and my mom was in the front seat,” both dressed for work, says Nguyen. “Me and my sisters [were] in the back seat, messy and in T-shirts with the wind in our hair.” The final fragrance, Wedding, mixes frankincense and cedar and is intended to conjure, says Nguyen, “the ritual of going to church together.” Decorating the handmade Italian glass bottle is a wedding photo of her parents. For Nguyen, the collection is about “sharing more of my world with people,” she says. $65, available in-store at Beverly’s and online at atmosfragrance.com.

title: Priced Out of New York, She Took Her $350,000 Budget to Philadelphia. Here’s What She Found.
description: After a near-death experience gave her a new lease on life, a writer ‘broke up with New York’ and headed south to find a one-bedroom or two-bedroom apartment.

title: Week 16 N.F.L. Playoff Picture: A Team-by-Team Guide
description: With three weeks to go in the N.F.L. season, these detailed tables and scenarios explain every team’s paths to the playoffs — and to better seeding.

title: There’s Still Time for the Senate to Support the First Amendment
description: Donald Trump’s private lawsuits against ABC News, CBS News and most recently The Des Moines Register are only the first phase of his promised battle to “straighten out the press.” Once he gets back in office next month, a far more troubling phase will begin: his promised effort to use government power to force reporters to reveal their sources for national security articles he doesn’t like.

title: Put Down the Laser Pointer, Please, and Then Let’s Chat
description: On Monday afternoon, the F.B.I. office in Newark posted one of the most bizarre official statements I’ve ever read. It warned the public “against pointing lasers at manned aircraft” or attempting to shoot down suspected drones.

title: Chaos Consumes Drive to Avoid Government Shutdown, With 2 Days to Go
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump denounced a bipartisan spending deal that would fund the government until mid-March, telling Republican lawmakers that it would be “suicidal” to vote for it. His intervention all but buried the agreement with government funding scheduled to lapse in less than two days.

title: Israel Launches Airstrikes Against Houthis in Yemen as Netanyahu Issues Warning
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the Israeli military struck Houthi targets in Yemen early Thursday in response to the militia’s attacks on Israel, and appeared to suggest that Israel might take further action in its campaign to weaken Iran-backed groups.

title: On a Flight With Gaza’s Rare Evacuees
description: The war in Gaza is one of the few conflicts most civilians can’t escape. But a small number of sick or critically injured people have been evacuated. The Times Magazine reporter Nicholas Casey went on a rare evacuation flight to try to understand what it takes to leave.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,280
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion No. 558
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Crypto’s Big Bet Is Paying Off
description: Since Donald J. Trump won the 2024 election, cryptocurrency has surged to its highest level ever.

title: 51 Men Found Guilty in France Rape Trial, and a U.S. Shutdown Looms
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: Electoral Wishcasting
description: The Democrats’ 2024 defeat had many causes, starting with inflation and immigration. In today’s newsletter, I’ll examine another item on the list: candidate quality.

title: Putin Glosses Over Russian Setbacks, Including Syria
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Thursday tried to paper over or shift the blame for recent setbacks at home and in the Middle East, while making a fresh appeal to Donald J. Trump that he was ready to talk to the U.S. president-elect “any time.”

title: ‘Homestead’ Review: A Home Away From Armageddon
description: It’s not often that a feature film ends with a teaser for a series that is already available to stream, but “Homestead,” released by Angel Studios, the distributor of “Sound of Freedom” and various Christian-themed projects, is less a self-contained movie than a pilot for a show that already exists. The quality of the acting can only improve.

title: ‘The Six Triple Eight’ Review: Tyler Perry Salutes the Greatest Generation
description: In Tyler Perry’s World War II drama, “The Six Triple Eight,” Oprah Winfrey appears as the humanitarian Mary McLeod Bethune. Susan Sarandon (wearing outsized choppers) arrives as Bethune’s friend Eleanor Roosevelt, the first lady of the United States. Together Roosevelt and Bethune convince President Franklin D. Roosevelt (Sam Waterston) to press a piqued general into using Black female soldiers to address the mountains of undelivered mail — to soldiers and from them — sitting in airplane hangars in Scotland.

title: Who Are the 51 Men Convicted in the Gisèle Pelicot Rape Trial?
description: All 51 defendants in the Gisèle Pelicot rape trial were found guilty on Thursday. Most of the accused received sentences of eight to 10 years, less than the 10- to 18-year terms that the public prosecutor had recommended.

title: Britain’s Economy Is ‘Bumbling’ Into the New Year
description: It’s a somber end to the year in Britain, dampened by a string of disappointing economic news. Inflation has jumped, the economy has stagnated and consumer confidence surveys are deeply downbeat.

title: Publishers Battle for the C-Suite
description: When the digital news start-up Semafor began in 2022, its founders talked about reaching a vast global audience of 200 million college-educated, English-speaking people.

title: Why the Specter of Trump Hangs Over the Fed, Congress and the Markets
description: For weeks, Jay Powell has been sending markets the message that the Fed is entering a more cautious phase, signaling that high borrowing costs would linger for longer.

title: Amazon Delivery Drivers at Seven Hubs Walk Out
description: Workers who deliver packages from seven Amazon facilities across the country went on strike Thursday morning, according to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the union that represents them.

title: Popular Arthritis Drug for Dogs May Have Severe Side Effects, F.D.A. Says
description: A popular drug for dogs with arthritis may be associated with a variety of potentially severe neurological effects, including seizures and a loss of muscle control, according to a recent review by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, which approved the drug last year. In some cases, dogs have died or have been euthanized after developing these symptoms, the agency noted.

title: Zelensky Raises Prospect of European Peacekeepers in Ukraine
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Thursday that he had discussed with European leaders the possibility of sending European peacekeeping forces to Ukraine as part of a cease-fire or peace deal, as the country’s allies consider options on how to help Kyiv end the fighting with Russia on favorable terms.

title: ‘We Just Want Mercy’: A Gaza Hospital Pleads for a Respite
description: The last functioning intensive care unit at a hospital in northern Gaza was severely damaged by Israeli shelling this week, according to medical staff at the facility who have been pleading for a respite from violence to bring in essential supplies.

title: This Corpse Has Had a Wild Journey. Its Next Stop? Broadway.
description: “Dead Outlaw,” a rambunctious musical that tells the hard-to-believe-it’s-true story of a bandit’s corpse that became a spectacle in early-20th-century America, will open on Broadway next spring.

title: If You Can See the Tree, There Is Room for More Decorations
description: If you’ve tired of sad beige holidays, with Christmas decorations stuck in muted neutral tones and minimalist greenery, it might be time to give maximalism a try.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Invisible-Ink Graffiti
description: Jim writes: We recently remodeled our kitchen, and my 10-year-old son wrote, “Are you eating cereal?” on the new countertop in invisible ink. We can’t see it unless we shine a UV light on the area. But I don’t think he should draw on any part of the house. He should also have additional cleaning chores for two weeks.

title: A Lottery Drawing Included Four Consecutive Numbers. What Are the Odds?
description: A total of 70 balls went into a drum for a lottery drawing. Five were pulled out: 56, 66, 67, 68 and 69.

title: A Famed Iowa Pollster’s Career Ends With a ‘Spectacular Miss’ and a Trump Lawsuit
description: The surveys of J. Ann Selzer once carried the hopes and fears of the men and women who sought to lead the nation, recording with uncanny accuracy the views of Iowa voters who exercised outsize influence in the choosing of American presidents.

title: F.A.A. Bans Drone Flights Near Key Sites in New York
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has temporarily banned drone flights over parts of New York State, including sections of New York City, Long Island and Yonkers.

title: Gisèle Pelicot Speaks After Rape Trial Verdict: ‘We Share the Same Struggle’
description: Gisèle Pelicot gave brief remarks to reporters outside the courthouse in Avignon, France, on Thursday after her ex-husband, Dominique, and 50 other men were convicted in a rape trial. Mr. Pelicot admitted to drugging and raping her over nearly a decade and inviting other men to participate.

title: After the House Delayed a Bill to Add Judges, a Biden Veto Looms
description: For decades, the wheels of the federal judiciary have been turning ever more slowly, as the number of federal judges has failed to keep pace with rising caseloads.

title: Appeals Court Disqualifies Fani Willis From Prosecuting Georgia Trump Case
description: Georgia’s Court of Appeals on Thursday disqualified the Atlanta prosecutor who brought an election interference case against President-elect Donald J. Trump and his allies, a surprise move that threw the entire case into disarray.

title: What It Looks Like on an Island Steamrolled by a Cyclone
description: The hillsides surrounding the harbor of the tiny French territory of Mayotte have been transformed into barren mounds of leafless, uprooted trees. Sailboats lie on their sides, consumed by the warm waters of the Indian Ocean.

title: Could This 20-Year-Old Be One of the Democrats’ Bro Whisperers?
description: In a YouTube video that was uploaded about a month before the election, a young, blond man in baggy jeans and a graphic T-shirt sits alone at the center of a circle of folding chairs.

title: Elon Musk Flexes His Political Strength as Government Shutdown Looms
description: When President-elect Donald J. Trump picked “the Great Elon Musk,” the world’s richest man, to slash government spending and waste, he mused that the effort might be “the Manhattan Project of our time.”

title: White Chicken Chili to Welcome Them Home
description: What’s your Welcome Home Meal? You know, the dish you use to greet someone after a long day of travel or a long time away? Do you tailor the Welcome Home Meal for each person based on favorites and preferences, or is there a time-honored go-to that guests can expect when they grace your doorstep?

title: Calls to the Media: Fight Trump’s Lawsuits
description: To the Editor:

title: The 73 Best Illustrations of 2024
description: The most memorable illustrations of the year, chosen by art directors at The New York Times.

title: Government Lurches Toward Shutdown After House Tanks Trump’s Spending Plan
description: The government lurched toward a shutdown after the House on Thursday rejected a hastily produced plan ordered up by President-elect Donald J. Trump to keep funding flowing, with dozens of Republicans defying his demand to pair the spending with a two-year suspension of the federal debt limit.

title: Trump Tossed a Debt Limit Grenade Into Spending Talks. Here’s Why.
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump injected debt limit politics into already-fraught congressional spending talks this week, urging lawmakers to lift the debt limit or abolish it entirely before he takes office next month.

title: Is the Tech Industry Already on the Cusp of an A.I. Slowdown?
description: Demis Hassabis, one of the most influential artificial intelligence experts in the world, has a warning for the rest of the tech industry: Don’t expect chatbots to continue to improve as quickly as they have over the last few years.

title: Nvidia’s Booming A.I. Business Collides With U.S.-Chinese Tensions
description: In early August, the king of Bhutan, Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck, traveled from the mountains of his landlocked Asian country to the headquarters of Nvidia, a maker of artificial intelligence chips in the flatlands of Silicon Valley.

title: Kylie Kelce Doesn’t Want to Talk About Besting Joe Rogan
description: When a podcast hosted by Kylie Kelce, a 32-year-old high school field hockey coach, unseated “The Joe Rogan Experience” as the top-ranked show in the United States this month, strong reactions followed.

title: All They Want for Christmas? This Mariah Carey Bar.
description: Even before the shiny red curtains opened at 5 p.m., a line of people, dressed head to toe in red-and-green sequins, formed outside Mariah Carey’s holiday bar, a new pop-up lounge inside the Virgin Hotels New York.

title: It’s a Mistake to Charge Luigi Mangione With Terrorism
description: The murder of the health care executive Brian Thompson on a Midtown Manhattan sidewalk was shocking, brazen and seemingly methodical, but it wasn’t all that sophisticated.

title: Giséle Pelicot’s Ex-Husband Found Guilty in Mass Rape Trial
description: A French court found the ex-husband of Ms. Pelicot, Dominique Pelicot, guilty and sentenced him to 20 years in jail. Fifty other men were also convicted in the mass rape trial.

title: What if Trump Doesn’t Need to Keep Any of His Promises?
description: Now, supposedly, Donald Trump must deliver.

title: Trump’s Return May Worsen Financial Woes for Global Health Institutions
description: The election of Donald J. Trump, with his mistrust of international institutions and his history of proposing deep cuts to foreign aid, has complicated a perilous landscape for global health organizations that were already in a frantic competition for sharply reduced funds.

title: Maps: See Israel’s Moves in Syria Since al-Assad Was Toppled
description: Since President Bashar al-Assad fled Syria, Israel has mounted a military offensive in the country unlike anything it has conducted there in decades, fearing  chaos that could spill across the border.

title: With Guilty Verdicts, Rape Victim’s Ordeal in France Becomes a Message of Hope
description: In a packed courtroom on Thursday in Avignon, France, the head judge asked each of the dozens of men accused of raping Gisèle Pelicot — while she was near-comatose and at the invitation of her husband of 50 years — to stand briefly. Then he pronounced their convictions swiftly, one after the other: all guilty.

title: Kennedy Returns to Capitol Hill With New ‘Make America Healthy Again’ Caucus in Senate
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice to run the Health and Human Services Department, visited Capitol Hill on Thursday for a fourth straight day of meetings with Senate Republicans, who have pressed him on his commitment to their anti-abortion agenda but so far offered little resistance to his candidacy.

title: U.S. Files Murder Charge Against Mangione That Could Bring Death Penalty
description: Federal prosecutors on Thursday unsealed a murder case against the suspect in the shooting of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive, holding out the possibility of the death penalty even after a trial on separate state charges.

title: Andrew Cuomo Plans to Sue Harassment Accuser for Defamation
description: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo submitted a notice Thursday that he intended to file a defamation lawsuit against one of the first women to accuse him of sexual harassment while he was in office.

title: 2024 Was the Year of Chickpea Anxiety
description: There are a few circumstances you can count on in the twilight of the year. Everyone will want to “circle back in January,” as out-of-office replies quickly outnumber incoming requests. The cookie swaps will reach their zenith. You’ll get a remarkably inopportune cold. And a blizzard of best-of lists will ask you to reflect on yet another whirl around the sun. (Remember the Olympics? “Brat”? Moo Deng?)

title: The Simplest Way to Make Creamy Scrambled Eggs for a Crowd
description: To make fluffy, creamy, dreamy scrambled eggs for more than a few people, you don’t need a fancy pan or a newfangled hack. You don’t need boundless time or attention, either. You don’t even need the coffee to kick in yet — in fact, you’ll be rewarded for moving slowly.

title: Read the Criminal Complaint Against Luigi Mangione
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have filed four charges against Luigi Mangione, the suspect in the fatal shooting of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive.

title: What Are ‘Healthy’ Foods? The F.D.A. Updates the Labeling Terms.
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday updated the definitions of the term “healthy” for labeling on foods, a move that reflected changes in nutrition and that tightened limits on saturated fat, sugar and salt in food that could be sold under that claim.

title: Hidden ‘Junk’ Fees Must Be Disclosed, F.T.C. Rule Says
description: It is a common scenario for anyone booking online: That affordable hotel room or concert ticket suddenly gets pricey at checkout, when service and other fees get tacked on.

title: ‘The Brutalist’ Review: Ambitions Unbound
description: “The Brutalist” is a bursting-at-the-seams saga of bold men and their equally outsized visions. Set across several decades in the aftermath of World War II, it is a grave, serious, visually sumptuous movie that puts a great many ideas into play, starting with the tension between art and commerce. It largely focuses on one man in one place, but its concerns are more expansive and touch on everything from utopia to barbarism, desire, death, form, content, immigration, assimilation and the promise and perils of modernity. Many movies offer up a slice of reality; true to the architectural aesthetic that its title invokes, this one offers a slab.

title: Adams Hosts Fox News at City Hall, as N.Y. Leaders Mute Trump Hostility
description: The setting, not to mention the event itself, was unusual: Eric Adams, the Democratic mayor of New York City, had invited Fox News into City Hall on Wednesday for a sit-down interview.

title: Avian Flu Has Hit Dairies So Hard That They’re Calling It ‘Covid for Cows’
description: A fast-growing outbreak of avian flu has upended California’s dairy industry, the nation’s largest producer of milk, infecting most of the state’s herds and putting thousands of farmworkers at risk for contracting the virus.

title: Billionaire Rivals Bezos and Musk Are Said to Have Dined With Trump at Mar-a-Lago
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump had dinner at his Mar-a-Lago resort on Wednesday with Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos, the world’s two richest men and longtime business rivals who have cultivated relationships with the president-elect, according to two people briefed on the get-together.

title: Ex-Top Aide to Mayor Adams and Her Son Are Charged in Corruption Case
description: Manhattan prosecutors on Thursday charged the former chief adviser to Mayor Eric Adams and her son with taking $100,000 in bribes from two businessmen in exchange for intervening with city regulators on the businessmen’s behalf.

title: France’s Horrifying Rape Trial Has Changed the Country
description: It is over. Dominique Pelicot has been found guilty of orchestrating and participating in the mass rape of his wife, Gisèle Pelicot, in their home in the quiet town of Mazan in the South of France. He has been given the maximum sentence of 20 years in prison. All of the co-defendants have been found guilty of sexual assault, attempted rape or rape.

title: William J. Hennessy Jr., Sketch Artist of Courtroom Drama, Dies at 67
description: William J. Hennessy Jr., a prominent courtroom artist whose sketches documented important chapters in history, including the impeachment trials of Presidents Bill Clinton and Donald J. Trump and the Supreme Court case that decided the 2000 presidential election, as well as thousands of scenes of quotidian courtroom drama, died in Key West, Fla., on Dec. 9, his 67th birthday.

title: Former Uvalde Schools Police Chief Fails in Bid to Avoid Prosecution
description: A judge on Thursday denied an effort to throw out charges against the former police chief of the school district in Uvalde, Texas, who faces blame for his role in the 77 minutes it took to end the rampage at Robb Elementary School on May 24, 2022.

title: How the Climate Crisis Became an Insurance Crisis
description: Spend enough time talking about climate change, and you’ll eventually get pulled toward this question: What would have to happen for global warming to strike most people as an urgent crisis?

title: ‘Laid’ Is Acerbic, Raunchy Fun
description: “Laid,” on Peacock, follows a party planner named Ruby (Stephanie Hsu) whose previous sexual partners start dying. At first it seems like unlucky coincidence, but the pattern quickly emerges, and suddenly the number of deaths in Ruby’s wake is getting pretty distressing. Her bestie and roommate, A.J. (Zosia Mamet), makes a crazy wall, labeled “Ruby’s Sex Timeline,” and a morbid, prickly “High Fidelity” is afoot.

title: Wisconsin School Shooter May Have Plotted With California Man
description: Law enforcement officials grew concerned this week that the Wisconsin school shooting on Monday may have been part of a broader plot that could have included an attack on a government building, according to a court document filed in California.

title: New York to Pay $10 Million in Woman’s Death After Abuse in Group Home
description: In 2019, New York agreed to pay $2 million each to the families of three developmentally disabled residents of a group home who had been beaten, smacked and humiliated by workers who called the facility the “Bronx Zoo.”

title: ‘Getting Your Pink Back:’ How Moms Felt Like Themselves Again After Having a Baby
description: With five young children, Linnea Chambery had found herself at one of her most challenging points as a mother.

title: Movie Shelved After Jonathan Majors’s Arrest Gets Release Date
description: “Magazine Dreams,” a bodybuilding drama that was considered an Oscar contender last year before it was shelved when its star, Jonathan Majors, was accused of assaulting his girlfriend, is now scheduled to reach theaters in March.

title: The First-Ever ‘Where to Eaties’ Awards
description: By now you’ve probably read through our distinguished critics’ list of the city’s best new restaurants and best new dishes, each selection carefully considered and thoughtfully discussed. But who but us could take stock of the aspects of New York City dining that don’t fit into neat categories of taste and quality. That’s where the first-ever “Where to Eat”  year-end awards come in, highlighting our most peculiar, confusing and delightful dining experiences in 2024.

title: Joanne Pierce Misko, Ex-Nun Who Made F.B.I. History, Dies at 83
description: Joanne Pierce Misko, a former Roman Catholic nun who in 1972 became one of the first two women sworn in as special agents for the F.B.I., breaking the bureau’s longstanding bar against women in frontline law-enforcement roles, died on Friday in Wheatfield, N.Y., east of Niagara Falls. She was 83.

title: Friday Briefing: 51 Men Convicted in French Rape Trial
description: Dominique Pelicot, who admitted to drugging and raping his wife, Gisèle, for almost a decade and inviting dozens of strangers to join him, was convicted yesterday in France and sentenced to the maximum 20 years in prison. The court also convicted the 50 other defendants, most of them on rape charges.

title: Spending Deal Debacle Threatens Johnson’s Tenuous Hold on His Job
description: Follow the latest updates on the looming government shutdown.

title: 5 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: The other day, listening to old-fashioned terrestrial radio while I was putting dishes away, I was struck by the transition from a Nirvana song to a Neil Young song with a similar guitar lick — just the sort of segue that makes you appreciate unartificial intelligence, by demonstrating knowledge and intention and a spirit of play on the part of the D.J. That’s the same mind-set we try to apply here each week, recommending books that may be as different as an ice-bound whaling novel and a comedian’s memoir; what unites them isn’t always clear (a rich grasp of historical vagaries, in this case), but we’re always sure you’ll find something you can groove to. Happy reading. — Gregory Cowles

title: SeaQuest, Interactive Aquarium Where Many Animals Died, Files for Bankruptcy
description: SeaQuest, a chain of interactive animal parks and aquariums across the country, filed for bankruptcy protection this month, after years in which many of its facilities drew scrutiny from federal and state regulators, and several shut down.

title: Rupert Murdoch’s Appeal to Alter Family Trust Faces Uphill Battle
description: Rupert Murdoch’s attempt to change his family trust to consolidate his son Lachlan’s leadership of his global media empire — and lock in its conservative editorial direction after his death — now depends on a long-shot move in the highly specialized Nevada probate court system.

title: American Airlines Settles Racial Discrimination Case
description: American Airlines said on Thursday that it had settled a racial discrimination lawsuit filed by three Black men who said they and several others had been wrongly and temporarily removed from a flight in January by the airline’s flight attendants.

title: Artificial Intelligence in 2030
description: Modern artificial intelligence is expected to be one of the most consequential technologies in history. But there is a big debate over what those consequences will be: Will the technology power an age of prosperity, in which humans work less? Will it be used to wipe out humanity?

title: Amazon Reaches Settlement to Resolve Federal Safety Accusations
description: Federal health and safety regulators announced a corporatewide settlement with Amazon on Thursday, bringing an end to cases involving accusations of safety violations at 10 warehouses in several states.

title: Why Silent Film Still Speaks Volumes
description: Recently I took my two daughters to see a silent film at Film Forum here in New York. “Kid Boots” was a hit romantic comedy of 1926, starring the stage comic Eddie Cantor (roughly the Martin Short of his era) and Clara Bow (think Britney Spears circa 2000).

title: More Than Twice as Many U.S. Troops Are in Syria as Previously Disclosed
description: The Pentagon said on Thursday that 2,000 American troops were in Syria, more than twice the number officials had cited for months.

title: Mayotte Residents Struggle With Cyclone Chido Aftermath
description: Residents of Mayotte began relief efforts after Cyclone Chido devastated the French territory. Emmanuel Macron, President of France, surveyed the damage and received a mixed welcome.

title: Oysters Sicken at Least 80 at Restaurant Event in Los Angeles, Officials Say
description: A norovirus outbreak linked to oysters sickened at least 80 people who attended an event celebrating The Los Angeles Times’s annual list of the 101 best restaurants in the city, local health officials said this week.

title: Assessing Elon Musk’s Criticisms of the Government Spending Deal
description: Follow the latest updates on the looming government shutdown.

title: Republicans Offered a Plan to Avoid a Government Shutdown
description: House Republicans put forward a new plan this afternoon in an attempt to avert a government shutdown. Their proposal, which would fund the federal government at its current levels through mid-March, was devised after Donald Trump stepped in yesterday to torpedo a spending deal that House Speaker Mike Johnson had struck with Democrats.

title: 2024 Faces Quiz: Politics
description: See how well you know the politicians of 2024 with The New York Times Faces Quiz.

title: 2024 Faces Quiz: Sports
description: See how well you know the athletes of 2024 with The New York Times Faces Quiz.

title: 2024 Faces Quiz: Culture
description: See how well you know the television, movie, music and literary figures of 2024 with The New York Times Faces Quiz.

title: 2024 Faces Quiz
description: See how well you know the defining personalities of 2024 with The New York Times Faces Quiz.

title: Rick Kaufmann, Impresario of Art Furniture, Dies at 77
description: Art et Industrie was not a typical SoHo gallery, even in its heyday, the raucous 1980s. And its proprietor, Rick Kaufmann, a lanky, underfunded autodidact from Detroit, was not a typical SoHo gallerist.

title: Philadelphia City Council Says Yes to New 76ers Arena Next to Chinatown
description: Despite vociferous community opposition, the Philadelphia City Council on Thursday approved a $1.3 billion plan to build a downtown basketball arena next to Chinatown for their hometown 76ers that had been championed by Mayor Cherelle Parker.

title: The Timeless Craft of the Courtroom Sketch Artist
description: Courtroom sketch artists serve as quiet chroniclers of history, recording the tension, drama and emotion of trials where cameras are not allowed.

title: Neil Cavuto, Longtime Fox News Host, Signs Off the Network
description: Neil Cavuto, a business journalist who hosted a weekday afternoon program on the Fox News Channel since the network began in 1996, signed off for the final time on Thursday.

title: 51 Men Guilty in Rape Trial That Horrified France
description: Dominique Pelicot, who admitted to drugging and raping his wife for almost a decade and to inviting dozens of strangers to join him, was convicted on Thursday of aggravated rape and other charges and was sentenced to the maximum 20 years in prison. The court also convicted the 50 other defendants, most of them on rape charges. Catherine Porter, a New York Times reporter, followed the four-month trial and reports from Avignon.

title: The Shock of Faith: It’s Nothing Like I Thought It Would Be
description: When I was an agnostic, I thought faith was primarily about belief. Being religious was about having a settled conviction that God existed and knowing that the stories in the Bible were true. I looked for books and arguments that would convince me that God was either real or not real.

title: Britain to Name Peter Mandelson as Ambassador to the U.S.
description: The British government is expected to appoint Peter Mandelson, a Labour Party elder, as ambassador to the United States, two senior British officials said on Thursday, putting an influential onetime aide to Tony Blair at the helm of a potentially fraught relationship with President-elect Donald J. Trump.

title: Its Syrian Bases in Doubt, Russia Sends Cargo Flights to Libya
description: With the fate of its military bases in Syria uncertain, Russia has been sending cargo planes in recent days to Libya, where it also maintains a military foothold in the Middle East, Libyan officers said.

title: How Each House Member Voted on the Bills to Avoid a Government Shutdown
description: The House passed a measure to fund the federal government for a few months, extend the farm bill and provide new disaster aid.

title: Here’s What Could Happen in a Government Shutdown
description: There have been more than 20 gaps in federal government funding since 1976, with varying levels of shutdowns that have affected agencies — and the public — in different ways. During Donald J. Trump’s first term as president, roughly 800,000 of the federal government’s more than two million employees were sidelined for over a month starting in December 2018. The economy took a major hit.

title: Many Videos That Purport to Show Drones in New Jersey Likely Show Planes, Visual Analysis Finds
description: Starting in mid-November, a mystery began to take hold in northern New Jersey, when residents of Morris County began posting videos that appeared to show brightly lit flying objects hovering or soaring across the night sky, in some cases above their homes.

title: Tisch Shakes Up N.Y.P.D. Staff and Orders 500 Officers Back to Key Roles
description: Jessica S. Tisch, New York City’s police commissioner, announced on Thursday that she was replacing the department’s combative head of communications, part of a shake-up of the department’s upper ranks and other moves that suggest she is trying to restore order to an agency reeling from chaos and dysfunction at the top.

title: Macau Is the Casino Capital of the World. For China, That’s Not Enough.
description: Macau, the world’s gambling capital, is becoming more intertwined with a Chinese neighbor — one person, train and building at a time.

title: Ex-Police Chief Who Sexually Assaulted 17-Year-Old Gets 25 Years in Prison
description: A former police chief in West Virginia was sentenced to 25 years in prison on Thursday for paying a woman $100 to twice sexually assault her 17-year-old stepdaughter and then trying to cover it up, federal prosecutors said.

title: Chinese National Charged in California After Aiding Local Candidate, Prosecutors Say
description: U.S. officials on Thursday arrested a Chinese man prosecutors say was at the center of an effort to influence local politics in California, charging him with acting as an illegal foreign agent over his role in getting a politician elected to a City Council position in the Los Angeles area.

title: Former Knicks Star Clashes With Dolan Lawyer Over Run-In at Garden
description: During his decade-long run as a star for the New York Knicks, Charles Oakley was known as a bruising player who embodied a hardnose style of basketball that endeared him to the fans at Madison Square Garden.

title: Dozens of House Republicans Defy Trump in Test of His Grip on G.O.P.
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s hammerlock on the Republican Party was shaken on Thursday night when 38 of his party’s lawmakers in the House voted to defy his command to support a spending and debt deal.

title: Move Like a Crab
description: Jump to: Tricky Clues

title: Starbucks Workers Begin a Strike in 3 Cities on Friday
description: A union representing Starbucks workers said that baristas in Los Angeles, Chicago and Seattle walked off the job Friday morning and that the strikes would spread to hundreds of stores by Tuesday, Christmas Eve, unless the company improved its wage offer in contract negotiations.

title: Quote of the Day: 51 MEN CONVICTED OF RAPE AT TRIAL
description: “I wanted, by opening the doors of this trial on Sept. 2, that society would take up the debates that have been launched.”

title: How to Make a D.I.Y. Menorah
description: This article was originally published on Dec. 30, 2022.

title: Love in a Time of War
description: Oleksiy Levchenko wasn’t worried when his fiancée Anastasia Savka fell off a galloping horse during a film shoot in Kyiv, Ukraine, this summer.

title: Looking for the Restless Soul of Nella Larsen in Copenhagen
description: When Helga Crane, the main character in Nella Larsen’s novel “Quicksand,” walked through the streets of Copenhagen, people were amazed. “Her dark, alien appearance was to most people an astonishment,” wrote Larsen, an acclaimed Harlem Renaissance author. “Some stared surreptitiously, some openly, and some stopped dead in front of her in order more fully to profit by their stares.”

title: To Make Him Less Nervous, She Kissed Him
description: Brianna Nicole Irene Brown and Kevin Russell Malinak shared their first kiss in January 2015 on the night they met — more than a year before their first official date.

title: Grief Makes Us Time Travelers
description: I am in my pajamas, watching a Netflix documentary about space telescopes when I begin to think about my mother.

title: A First Date She Nearly Called Off
description: Moments before Blair Julia Smith showed up to her umpteenth first date, this time at a bar in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, she nearly called it off.

title: A Union That Could Not Wait
description: It was a provocative sign about racism that Adrian James Burrus was carrying that first caught Quinn Dipboye Sames’s eye at a Black Lives Matter protest on June 11, 2020, in downtown Lexington, Ky. The protest was in response to the deaths of George Floyd in Minneapolis and Breonna Taylor in Louisville, Ky.

title: Review: In a Stripped-Down ‘Gypsy,’ Audra’s Gonna Show It to Ya
description: It’s only fitting that we pore over “Gypsy” as if it were holy writ. It was, after all, written by three of the holies: Jule Styne (music), Stephen Sondheim (lyrics) and Arthur Laurents (book).

title: Ukrainians Mourn the Loss of a Young Journalist and Her Stories
description: Viktoria Roshchyna reported from places most other Ukrainian journalists would not go. She was one of the last to report openly from the territory in Ukraine forcibly taken by Russian troops. And then she went further and entered Russia.

title: On Avignon’s Ancient Ramparts, Modern Messages Denounce ‘Rape Culture’
description: The buttery yellow ramparts encircling the center of Avignon stretch 2.6 miles and are notched with arrow slits and gaps for dumping boiling water or cooking oil on attackers below.

title: Friday Briefing
description: In a packed courtroom in Avignon, France, all 51 of the men accused of raping Gisèle Pelicot while she was unconscious were found guilty yesterday. The trial has convulsed France and transformed the woman at its center into a feminist icon for her bravery in allowing the case to be tried publicly.

title: A Mouse That Swims and Dozens More Species Are Discovered in a Peruvian Jungle
description: In the summer of 2022, researchers trudged into the jungles of the Alto Mayo region of Peru in search of undiscovered creatures. This remote yet populous region had experienced significant deforestation, so the team didn’t expect to find much.

title: Senior U.S. Diplomats Meet With Governing Militias in Syria
description: Senior American diplomats traveled through Damascus, the Syrian capital, on Friday to meet with militias controlling the country and with civil society groups, and to look for signs of the journalist Austin Tice and other missing U.S. citizens, the State Department said.

title: Trump Puts $4 Billion in Shares of His Media Company in a Trust
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump transferred all of his shares in the social media company that bears his name to a trust controlled by his eldest son, according to a regulatory filing on Thursday night.

title: Seth Meyers: Donald Trump Got ‘Cable Guy’-ed by Elon Musk
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Word of the Day: animatronics
description: The word animatronics has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 11 in “Farewell, Chuck E. Cheese Animatronic Band” by Jesus Jiménez. The excerpt below includes a quote by David McKillips, the chief executive of Chuck E. Cheese.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

title: What Broadway Gets Right and Wrong About Journalism
description: One can hardly blame people for believing journalists have questionable ethics.

title: Hochul Weighs Legislation Limiting A.I. and More Than 100 Other Bills
description: It is an end-of-year State Capitol tradition, a lawmaker’s parallel to the tree lighting at Rockefeller Center: a holiday checklist of scores of bills that await Gov. Kathy Hochul’s signature or veto before the new year.

title: Is New Jersey the New Area 51?
description: As you may have almost certainly heard, New Jersey has recently become the epicenter of aerial-object obsession, some might say panic.
