Mysterious drones, or planes, or maybe extraterrestrial spycraft depending on your view, seem to have been lighting up the night sky for the past month, and theories about their purposes and origins abound.

title: Googly Eyes
description: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this photo, or describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

title: Trump Is Threatening Europe With Tariffs. Is It Ready?
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threats of tariffs on allies and adversaries alike have unsettled companies and governments across Europe, setting off a scramble for what they fear could be a trans-Atlantic trade war.

title: At 23, Surviving Scandal to Take a Green Seat in the E.U. Parliament
description: Campaigning for a seat in the European Parliament this spring, Lena Schilling was already facing an uphill battle, with her Green Party expected to fare poorly in the election across the continent.

title: How Your Car Might Be Making Roads Safer
description: Darcy Bullock, a civil engineering professor at Purdue University, turns to his computer screen to get information about how fast cars are traveling on Interstate 65, which runs 887 miles from Lake Michigan to the Gulf of Mexico. It’s midafternoon on a Monday, and his screen is mostly filled with green dots indicating that traffic is moving along nicely. But near an exit on the outskirts of Indianapolis, an angry red streak shows that cars have stopped moving.

title: A Legacy of Essential Humanitarian Aid
description: Catholic Charities is the oldest beneficiary of The New York Times Communities Fund, and the need for its services has only grown over the decades. Though run by the Catholic Church, Catholic Charities serves people of all denominations and backgrounds. Its work ranges from running a pop-up food pantry in the Bronx to assisting undocumented immigrants expelled from Texas, arranging shelter for Ukrainian refugees after they were abandoned by their sponsor, or organizing a relief fund for victims of Hurricane Milton.

title: Your College Football Team, Now Brought to You by Whiskey
description: At SHI Stadium at Rutgers University, advertisements for Eric LeGrand Whiskey flashed across the Jumbotron and on digital billboards during football games this season as bartenders used it to whip up old-fashioned cocktails in premium seating areas.

title: Can Wall Street Pressure Ease Brutality in India’s Sugar Fields?
description: The New York City comptroller, who oversees hundreds of billions of dollars in pension investments, is pressuring some of the world’s major sugar buyers to stop profiting off child labor, debt bondage and coerced hysterectomies in western India.

title: Postmortems Are Bad at Predictions: Democrats May Just Need a ‘Change’ Election
description: There’s a lot about politics that’s hard to predict, but there’s something you can count on every four years: One party loses a presidential election, and the recriminations begin.

title: One of the Most Unpredictable Actresses of the ’70s Is Back From Exile
description: The actress Jessica Harper was first profiled in The Times on Aug. 19, 1977. The occasion was the release of the Italian horror film “Suspiria,” and much was made of the fact that she had turned down a small role in Woody Allen’s “Annie Hall.” She explained, “I would have loved to do ‘Annie Hall’ but this was a big role and it meant going to Rome. I couldn’t pass it up, but I don’t know if it was a wise choice.”

title: They Entered Treatment. Drugs, Overdoses and Deaths Followed.
description: Amanda Vlakos had been living for years in rat-infested abandoned buildings in Baltimore, fighting an addiction to opioids, when she learned of a possible escape: a drug-treatment program that offered patients free housing.

title: Staffers at The Times on the Books They Enjoyed in 2024
description: I don’t know why I picked up LOVED AND MISSED. It must have caught my eye through some sort of bookstore magic, because I had never seen it before and I didn’t recognize the author’s name. I had a professor in college who said novels remind us of what it means to be human. This is a book that does exactly that. It’s about a woman named Ruth who takes in her granddaughter because her daughter is hopelessly addicted to drugs. Actually, she doesn’t just take her in. Ruth hands over an envelope of cash to her addled daughter and backs away fast with the baby in her pram.

title: Packed Cubicles, Empty Corner Office: Remote Work Is Increasingly a Right of the Rich
description: When it comes to remote work, executives want workers to do as they say, not as they do.

title: Why It’s Hard to Control What Gets Taught in Public Schools
description: Oklahoma and Texas are among more than 20 states that have passed laws since 2021 seeking to control how race, gender and American history are discussed in schools.

title: For These Picture Book Heroes, Daydreams Are What Life Is Made Of
description: Children have a knack for finding the signs and wonders they need to feel at home in the world. They find them where and when they can. Resilient Madeline, in the Ludwig Bemelmans classic, spies a friendly rabbit crouching in the crack-lines of her orphanage dormitory ceiling. Maurice Sendak’s Max sees in the four plain bedposts of his own dreary room the first intimations of the untamed forest of his dreams.

title: Ten Years Later, a Political Exile Returns to a Syria in Transition
description: In 2014, Sawsan Abou Zainedin left Syria during a civil war, while Bashar al-Assad was in power. Now, with rebel militants in control, Ms. Abou Zainedin is working on the country’s delicate political transformation.

title: New Year’s Eve in New York: What to Do, See and Eat
description: New Year’s Eve is right around the corner, which means now is the time to start planning your day (and night and the next morning). From oddball classes to inspirational concerts, splashy parties to silent hikes, here are a few ways to ring in 2025 around New York City.

title: ‘It Will Be a More Robust Check on Trump Than the G.O.P. Congress’: Three Legal Experts on Trump 2.0
description: Kate Shaw, a contributing Opinion writer, hosted a written online conversation with Times Opinion columnist David French and Jack Goldsmith, a law professor at Harvard and a co-author of “After Trump: Reconstructing the Presidency,” to discuss some of the key legal questions likely to arise in the second Trump administration.

title: Yes, Biden’s Green Future Can Still Happen Under Trump
description: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.

title: Artists We Lost in 2024, in Their Words
description: Hands that gripped paintbrushes, pens and drum sticks; eyes that saw new meaning in the familiar; feet that leaped across stages, stood before microphones or tapped underneath desks as their resolute owners wrote. By expressing themselves, the many creative people who died this year helped us better understand ourselves. Here is a tribute to some of them, in their voices.

title: Meet the Director Who Reinvented the Act of Seeing
description: A year after RaMell Ross finished filming “Nickel Boys,” he learned to fly.

title: Table for 2 at Tatiana? There Used to Be a Bot for That.
description: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at a new state law that targets apps that make restaurant reservations available — for a price. We’ll also get details on entries in the notebook Luigi Mangione was carrying when he was apprehended in Pennsylvania.

title: Why Composers of Any (or No) Faith Are Drawn to Sacred Music
description: If you like Christmas music, “It’s the Most Wonderful Time of the Year” isn’t just the name of a song.

title: The Books Readers Loved in 2024
description: Every year the Book Review publishes lists of the best new books. But we know that’s not the full story.

title: The Great Drone Freak-Out Is Coming
description: The public has already been given the government’s best answers to the latest panic over mysterious lights in the sky over New Jersey. Many Americans simply don’t like a mundane answer — fixed-wing piloted aircraft, smaller planes, hobbyist drones — that implies they are rubes at best and paranoid at worst.

title: 7 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
description: Adrien Brody stars as László Tóth, an architect and survivor of the Holocaust who lands in America in this sprawling drama directed by Brady Corbet.

title: $1.5 Million Homes in Thessaloniki, Greece
description: Built on a hillside in the seaside village of Vourvourou, this four-bedroom, four-bathroom house is in the Settlement of Professors, a gated community built as a cooperative for academics from the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki in the 1960s. Now a development of about 150 homes, the area maintains its wide streets and treed landscapes. Professors still own most of its houses.

title: A Solstice of the Soul
description: As the day shrinks into its annual darkness, here’s what I know about the cosmos — so far.

title: How a Scrappy New Publisher Landed 25 Books on the Best-Seller List in a Year
description: A few years ago, Scarlett St. Clair was working as a librarian in Oklahoma, self-publishing romance novels on the side, when one of her books went viral on TikTok.

title: ‘Elton John: Never Too Late’ Burnishes a Career (but Charmingly)
description: When you’ve been as famous as Elton John for as long as Elton John — he’s been a solo professional for 55 years — it can be hard to find a new way to tell your story. The contours of his career are almost archetypal for a musician: early virtuosic success, a crash-and-burn moment, then redemption. In John’s case, that redemption story is tied up with both getting sober and meeting David Furnish, who later became his husband, in the early 1990s.

title: How Drug Overdose Deaths Have Plagued One Generation of Black Men for Decades
description: Young Black men in cities across America died of drug overdoses at high rates in the 1980s and 1990s. During the recent fentanyl crisis, older Black men in many cities have been dying at unusually high rates.

title: Are Amazon’s Drones Finally Ready for Prime Time?
description: Over the past few weeks, concerned New Jersey residents have craned their heads skyward to track the movements of what appeared to be mysterious drones overhead, formulate theories about their origins and strategize about how to get rid of them.

title: What’s Your Favorite Holiday Movie or TV Special?
description: It’s that time of the year again — not just for gift-giving but for cozying up with family and friends and watching holiday movies and television specials together. (Take a Times quiz to test your knowledge of the beloved seasonal classics.) What are some of your favorites? What lessons have you learned from them about the holidays or life in general?

title: The Surprising Sexual Politics of Nicole Kidman’s Kinky ‘Babygirl’
description: It has been a ghastly year for American women — at least those of us who are not looking forward to being ruled by a claque of cartoon chauvinists — but a pretty rich year for women in the movies.

title: Maurice Berger Held a Mirror to a Racist Art World
description: To hear Maurice Berger tell it, growing up among mostly Black and Puerto Rican families in a low-income housing project in New York City sharpened his lens on the layers and levels of discrimination in America. “As a gay man and as a Jew, I’ve experienced homophobia and antisemitism in my life,” he writes in RACE STORIES: Essays on the Power of Images (Aperture/The New York Times, $40). “But the racism the kids I grew up with experienced, in front of my eyes, left me realizing that nothing quite compared to that in terms of prejudice.”

title: The New York Times News Quiz, Dec. 20, 2024
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: How to Talk to a Loved One About Their Drinking
description: The holidays are a time of excess. Too much food. Too much drink. And sometimes an alcohol problem can masquerade as high spirits and good cheer.

title: Three Deals in 12 Days: How Australia Is Countering China in the Pacific
description: A bank. A rugby team. A larger police force.

title: Musk, Ring-Kissing and a Looming Shutdown
description: Andrew Ross Sorkin sits down with Michael Barbaro to discuss raising the debt ceiling and Elon Musk’s political impact.

title: Ring-Kissing, Defamation Lawsuits and a Looming Shutdown
description: On this week’s round table, Michael Barbaro sits down with Maggie Haberman, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Catie Edmondson to discuss the latest news in Donald J. Trump’s transition to power.

title: Ring-Kissing, Lawsuits and a Looming Shutdown
description: Weeks before his inauguration, President-elect Donald J. Trump is pushing the federal government toward a shutdown, corporate titans are flocking to Mar-a-Lago to gain his favor and a major media company has capitulated to Trump’s legal strategy of suing those who cross him.

title: The Connections Companion No. 559
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,281
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: What a Shutdown Could Look Like, and a ‘Healthy’ Food Fight
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: Romanian Court Blocks Andrew Tate’s Case From Heading to Trial
description: A trial in Romania for Andrew Tate, the online influencer who is facing criminal accusations involving human trafficking and sexual misconduct, will not go ahead, at least for now, after an appeals court sent an indictment back to prosecutors on Thursday.

title: When We Roll Back the Rules
description: Marijuana and sports gambling tell a story about American politics. Twenty years ago, both were largely illegal. Now, most people can partake in them legally.

title: Is Amazon’s Drone Delivery Finally Ready for Prime Time?
description: This week, we took a field trip to the Phoenix suburbs to see Amazon’s newest iteration of drone delivery service in action. We toured the facility where these drones are in operation, spoke with the vice president and general manager of Prime Air, David Carbon, and watched from a local backyard as our own order dropped from the sky.

title: Britannica Didn’t Just Survive. It’s an A.I. Company Now.
description: For nearly 250 years, the Encyclopaedia Britannica was a bookshelf-busting series of gilt-lettered tomes, often purchased to show that its owners cared about knowledge.

title: Who’s in Charge?
description: Washington is on the brink of crisis, as 38 House Republicans joined nearly all Democrats last night in rejecting a government funding plan backed by President-elect Donald Trump and Elon Musk. If a last-minute deal isn’t reached, the government will shut down at 12:01 a.m. Eastern.

title: Cyclone Chido Death Toll Nearly Doubles in Mozambique
description: The death toll from Cyclone Chido in Mozambique has risen to 75, the government said on Friday, nearly doubling the previously reported number.

title: The Fed’s Preferred Inflation Measure Sped Up in November
description: Federal Reserve officials are closely watching how inflation shapes up as they contemplate when and how much to cut interest rates in 2025, and the latest inflation data offers reasons for both wariness and hope.

title: Wall St. Is at It Again, Making Irrelevant Market Predictions
description: An annual ritual is underway at the major Wall Street investment houses: predicting exactly where the S&P 500 will finish the next calendar year.

title: How a New Year’s Resolution Can Set Up Your Financial Goals for Success
description: Thinking about making a New Year’s resolution to get your finances in order? You might have better luck sticking to it than you’d expect.

description: DealBook Summit includes conversations with business and policy leaders at the heart of today’s major stories, recorded live at the annual DealBook Summit event in New York City.

title: Corrections: Dec. 20, 2024
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about Syria’s first domestic flight since the fall of Bashar al-Assad’s government referred incorrectly to the territory held by the rebel alliance that ousted Mr. al-Assad. The alliance holds much of Syria’s northwest, not its northeast.

title: How Anti-Obesity Drugs are Redefining Pharma and Wellness
description: DealBook Summit includes conversations with business and policy leaders at the heart of today’s major stories, recorded live at the annual DealBook Summit event in New York City.

title: ‘The Tempest’ Review: A Weak Wind Blows for Sigourney Weaver
description: Sigourney Weaver has inhabited some unusual realms in the course of her storied film career. So it’s not overly surprising that the star of “Alien” and “Avatar” might choose to come to the West End in “The Tempest,” Shakespeare’s otherworldly play.

title: The Government Shutdown: What Travelers Need to Know
description: A government shutdown could snarl plans for tens of millions of Americans traveling for the December holidays if Congress fails on Friday to pass legislation to keep the government functioning. Nonessential federal operations would cease at 12:01 a.m. on Saturday.

title: Mushroom Bourguignon, Ginger Sesame Granola and Fried Eggplant Heroes
description: Good morning. One of the more satisfying wintertime weekend activities is the making of stock: beef, say, or chicken or vegetable. (Lobster if you’re fancy.) These come in handy when you want to make a risotto of uncommon flavor, amp up a soup or supercharge a gravy.

title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: What if a zombie apocalypse wasn’t even the scariest thing to happen to your family? Carlo Ledesma’s film takes place in the Filipino countryside, where Francis (Sid Lucero) and Iris (Beauty Gonzalez) have fled with their young sons, Lucas (Aiden Tyler Patdu) and Joshua (Marco Masa). They are looking for refuge in Francis’s isolated childhood home, which feels relatively safe from the marauding undead. This is, of course, a fairly common premise but Ledesma puts a dramatic twist on it by focusing on Francis’s unraveling. His relationship with Iris is already on the rocks when we meet them, and he crumbles further into jealousy, paranoia and violence as the pressure mounts.

title: ‘The Room Next Door’ | Anatomy of a Scene
description: Pedro Almodóvar narrates a sequence from his film starring Julianne Moore and Tilda Swinton.

title: This Classic Kwanzaa Cookbook Invites Improvisation
description: As 2024 was running out and a new year loomed, the prolific cookbook author and culinary historian Jessica B. Harris was thinking about Oxford’s word of the year: brain rot.

title: Watch Julianne Moore and Tilda Swinton Connect in ‘The Room Next Door’
description: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

title: Weather’s Impact on Your Wallet: See How Much You Know
description: Where do wildfires threaten the most homes? How much can an inch of floodwater in your house cost you? Take our quiz to find out.

title: Top Senate Democrats Want Epshteyn to Address Pay-to-Play Allegations
description: Three top Senate Democrats on Friday wrote to Boris Epshteyn, a top Trump lawyer, demanding answers to allegations that he solicited payments from potential Trump administration nominees.

title: Trump Wanted Shutdown to Happen on Biden’s Watch, Not His
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump, who derailed a bipartisan spending deal in Congress, tried on Friday to escape responsibility for the consequences, saying it would be better to let the government shut down under President Biden’s watch than to allow a politically damaging stalemate once he takes office next month.

title: More People Are Now Dying From the Cold
description: Deaths related to cold weather have risen steadily nationwide in recent decades, new research shows, underscoring the continued risks of cold exposure even as average temperatures continue to climb.

title: Musk Expresses Support for Far-Right Party in Germany’s Election
description: Elon Musk, the world’s richest man and a close adviser to President-elect Donald J. Trump, on Friday endorsed Germany’s far-right party, a group with ties to neo-Nazis whose youth wing has been classified as “confirmed extremist” by German domestic intelligence.

title: One of 2024’s Last Meteor Showers Is About to Reach Its Peak
description: The longest night in the Northern Hemisphere is upon us. And it will be accompanied by a holiday light show from the Ursids, the last major meteor shower of the year to peak.

title: The Story of Hong Kong’s Billionaire Dissident
description: On the morning of Aug. 10, 2020, scores of armed police arrived at the headquarters of Apple Daily, one of Hong Kong’s most prominent pro-democracy newspapers. They rifled through the offices, hunting for evidence of treason, and frog-marched the paper’s billionaire publisher, Jimmy Lai, through his own third-floor newsroom. Lai soon faced charges under a new security law of colluding with foreign powers. A few months later, Mark L. Clifford writes in “The Troublemaker,” a brisk account of Lai’s life and work, the gravity of his predicament began to set in, and Lai sent a laconic WhatsApp message to his associates: “Delete everything.”

title: The Fair Catch Free Kick, and 4 Other Obscure-but-Real N.F.L. Rules
description: The N.F.L. rule book is long.

title: Book Club: Let’s Talk About Claire Keegan’s ‘Small Things Like These’
description: Clare Keegan’s slim 2021 novella about one Irishman’s crisis of conscience during the Christmas season, which was shortlisted for the Booker Prize, has also been adapted into a film starring Cillian Murphy. In this week’s episode, MJ Franklin discusses the book with his colleagues Joumana Khatib, Lauren Christensen and Elisabeth Egan.

title: Regulators Sue 3 Big Banks Over Rampant Fraud on Zelle
description: The Biden administration brought new, sweeping accusations of fraud on Friday against three of the largest banks in the country — but President-elect Donald J. Trump’s administration will have the opportunity to drop the case as soon as next month.

title: Volkswagen Reaches Labor Deal, Avoiding Germany Plant Closures
description: Volkswagen, Germany’s largest automaker, reached an agreement with its union on Friday, ending a three-month standoff that had rattled the country and brought to light the extent of German industrial decline.

title: Why Britain Has So Many White Christmases (Technically)
description: It’s the fantasy festive image: snow on Christmas Day. Immortalized on countless holiday cards, inspired in the collective consciousness by Charles Dickens’s depictions of snow blanketing the cobbled, crowded streets of London in “A Christmas Carol.”

title: Markets Rally, Shaking Off Threat of Government Shutdown
description: Stock investors took their cue from data showing that inflation continued to slow in November, shrugging off the looming threat of a government shutdown.

title: Elon Musk’s Growing Political Influence
description: To the Editor:

title: Meet the 38 Republicans Who Defied Trump on the Spending and Debt Deal
description: The 38 House Republicans who refused to vote for the spending deal pushed by President-elect Donald J. Trump are largely limited-government fiscal hawks who believe they are impervious to a primary threat in their bids for re-election.

title: Are Weight-Loss Drugs Causing a Rift in Your Relationship? We Want to Hear About It.
Kelly Clarkson’s Christmas Love Song, and 12 More New Holiday Tunes
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

title: Would You Wear Jeans at the Gym?
description: As political plotlines go, this one is more sweaty than salacious.

title: 21 Movies, Books and Albums With a Theater Focus to Consume During the Holidays
description: Thanks to an abundance of film adaptations of stage productions, theater-centric books and a spate of newly released cast albums, there’s enough theater to go around from the comfort of home. (There’s also lot to see on and Off Broadway, and you can read our reviews here and additional theater coverage here.)

title: Virginia Student Accused of Plot to Attack Israeli Consulate in New York
description: A freshman at George Mason University in Virginia is accused of plotting an attack at the Israeli consulate general in New York. He faces a charge of distributing information relating to weapons of mass destruction, according to federal court documents.

title: E.P.A. Administrator Michael Regan to Depart at End of December
description: Michael S. Regan, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, will step down at the end of this month, before the formal end of the Biden administration, he announced in an email to employees Friday.

title: We Need a Great American Fantasy
description: Any cultural critic can complain, as I did in last weekend’s column, about the lack of creativity in American popular culture right now and the unmet “hunger for a certain kind of popular art” amid so much institutionalized unoriginality. It’s a bit harder to give writers or filmmakers specific marching orders. What exact kind of popular art are we missing? What specific achievement should American creators be aiming for?

title: Matteo Salvini Acquitted After Blocking Rescue of Migrant Boat in Italy
description: An Italian court acquitted Matteo Salvini, the country’s deputy prime minister and the leader of the anti-immigrant League party, after he was accused of illegally refusing to allow a boat carrying migrants to dock in Italy five years ago.

title: In Memoriam: The Musicians We Lost in 2024
description: As we look back at 2024, it’s important to honor the many great musicians we lost this year. Over the past 12 months, we’ve said goodbye to some towering legends of American song (Quincy Jones, Kris Kristofferson), beloved cult heroes of underground music (Steve Albini, the Can vocalist Damo Suzuki), and pop idols of different cultures and generations (the Shangri-Las’ Mary Weiss, One Direction’s Liam Payne and the French icon Françoise Hardy, to name just a few). On today’s playlist, all of their disparate sounds and styles will mingle as one long, eclectic musical memorial.

title: Trump Used Government Shutdowns as Leverage During His First Presidency
description: In 2018, during Donald J. Trump’s first presidency, he said he would be “proud” to shut down the government if a deal was not reached that included funding he wanted for his proposed wall along the southern U.S. border.

title: Five Books That Explain the Chaos of 2024
description: I like to use my last column of the year to wrap up the major developments of the previous 12 months. But the events of 2024 feel fundamentally un-wrappable: The news is just moving too rapidly.

title: Russia’s Abrupt Setback in Syria Creates Headaches for Putin
description: For decades, Russia has been trying to rebuild its influence in the Middle East. But after the rapid collapse of the Assad regime in Syria, the Kremlin is scrambling to salvage whatever it can.

title: French Court Convicts 8 People Tied to Events That Led to Teacher’s Killing
description: A Paris court on Friday convicted eight people for their roles in the events that led to the killing of Samuel Paty, a history teacher whose stabbing and decapitation by an Islamist terrorist in 2020 deeply shocked France.

title: Trump Moves to Replace Officials Whom New Presidents Traditionally Leave Alone
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has moved to install loyalists in jobs that Congress did not intend for new presidents to replace at the start of their terms, eroding a traditional constraint on executive power even before he takes office.

title: Indiana Man Sentenced to 130 Years for Killing 2 Teenage Girls
description: An Indiana judge has sentenced a man to 130 years in prison for the killings of two teenage girls in 2017 that became known among true-crime followers as the Delphi Murders. It was the maximum sentence for the charges he faced.

title: As RFK Jr. Pursues Bid for Health Secretary, Federal Authorities Begin Campaign for Childhood Vaccines
description: The Health and Human Services Department began a campaign on Friday to support childhood vaccinations that federal health officials said was intended to “cut through the noise of misinformation.”

title: Marisa Paredes, Acclaimed in Almodóvar Films, Is Dead at 78
description: Marisa Paredes, an award-winning actress who was considered one of the great divas of Spanish film, gaining international acclaim for her work with the renowned director Pedro Almodóvar, died on Tuesday in Madrid. She was 78.

title: The World Is Falling Apart. Should I Scrap My Plans to Have Kids?
description: I have a question about planning for the future in light of the recent presidential election and the prospect of potentially having a dictatorship in America. I’m a 33-year-old woman. For a long time I’ve wanted to start a family. I’m about to start investing substantial money into family planning. In view of climate change, overpopulation and now the result of the election, I’ve started to wonder if maybe it’s just not meant to be. There are so many wars going on, and with America turning isolationist, I fear for the world. It feels like everything is falling apart; there’s so much uncertainty, and it doesn’t feel safe anymore.

title: The Fate of This Federal Program Helps Explain Trump’s Win
description: I thank Paul Gottlieb, an economics professor at Rutgers University, for inspiring today’s newsletter. He wrote to me recently to point out “one of the least-covered stories in economics during the Biden administration.” Namely, that “in mid-2022, the 50-year-old federal program known as Trade Adjustment Assistance was allowed to expire,” leaving it to hobble on until its funding runs out or Congress intervenes.

title: Driver Rams Christmas Market in Germany, Killing at Least 2 in Suspected Attack
description: A driver plowed a vehicle into a Christmas market in the central German city of Magdeburg on Friday evening, killing an adult and a small child and injuring dozens of other people in what officials indicated was a targeted attack.

title: OpenAI Unveils New A.I. That Can ‘Reason’ Through Math and Science Problems
description: OpenAI on Friday unveiled a new artificial intelligence system, OpenAI o3, which is designed to “reason” through problems involving math, science and computer programming.

title: The Best Friends They Left Behind
description: The beloved pets of some of the notable people we lost this year.

title: 2024: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics.
description: Selected Times graphics, visualizations and multimedia stories published this year. All free to read for a limited time.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: Remembering some of the artists, innovators and thinkers we lost in the past year.

title: Key Ally Abandons Trudeau in Fresh Blow to His Government
description: As Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada tried to reverse his plunging fortunes on Friday by rearranging his cabinet, a key political ally called Mr. Trudeau a failed leader and vowed to bring down his government.

title: Gena Rowlands Refused to Play the Traditional Woman
description: She worried that marriage would ruin her acting career. Instead, it fueled one of the most dynamic partnerships in film history.

title: James Earl Jones Found His Voice Through Silence
description: After refusing to talk for most of his childhood, he discovered the power in performance.

title: Jerry West Was the N.B.A.’s Tortured Genius
description: One of the world’s greatest basketball players, he thought of himself as a loser.

title: She Turned in Her ‘Star Trek’ License Plates, but the Tickets Kept Coming
description: Beda Koorey, a retired legal secretary, returned her license plates stamped with “NCC 1701,” like the identifying tag of the U.S.S. Enterprise in the “Star Trek” series, to the Department of Motor Vehicles in New York in April 2020.

title: Frankie Beverly Created America’s No. 1 Cookout Song
description: How the R&B hit ‘Before I Let Go’ became an enduring anthem.

title: See Which Government Workers Would be Impacted if a Spending Bill Doesn’t Pass
description: A government shutdown would have significant consequences for more than two million federal employees. Some would be forced to report to work and the rest would be furloughed. None would be paid during the shutdown.

title: Mary Weiss Influenced Musicians From the Ramones to Amy Winehouse
description: Her singing career began and ended before she turned 20.

title: Michaela DePrince Danced as if She Were Sprinkled With Pixie Dust
description: As a professional ballerina, she inhabited the world of fairy tales. It’s tempting to read her real life as one too.

title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, Dec. 21, 2024
description: Can you sort 8 historical events?

title: When Willie Mays Was Banned From Baseball
description: The strange, sad period when the Hall of Famer was exiled from his sport.

title: How Edward Stone Resolved NASA’s Scientific Turf Wars
description: To run a scientific expedition that travels billions of miles, it takes more than great engineers — it takes a great manager as well.

title: Paul Auster’s Life and Work Were Marked by Death
description: He knew that tragedy comes for us all.

title: Shelley Duvall Made Her Mark Well Before ‘The Shining’
description: She redefined how an actress was supposed to be — and then she left Hollywood.

title: Eleanor Coppola’s Frustrated Ambitions
description: Her own filmmaking aspirations were thwarted by domestic life. Her daughter’s would not be.

title: Dr. Ruth and Phil Donahue Answered Life’s Big Questions
description: Together, they told us everything we wanted to know about sex.

title: The Rise and Fall of Ivan Boesky, Notorious Inside Trader
description: He was seen as greed incarnate — and never said otherwise.

title: Bob Newhart’s Comedy Left a Lot Unsaid
description: For him, comedy became a form of therapy.

title: Janice Burgess Combined High Culture With Childish Delight
description: In “The Backyardigans,” she created a world for kids as wildly sophisticated as her own.

title: Peter Buxtun Refused to Give Up
description: For years, he tried to expose the Tuskegee syphilis study – but no one would listen.

title: Hettie Jones Helped Kickstart New York’s Beat Scene
description: Despite her husband's betrayal, she recreated herself as the writer she always was.

title: Angela Bofill Sang What She Could Until the End
description: She was a musical virtuoso who never quite got her due.

title: Were Pete Rose’s Sins Ahead of His Time?
description: Banned from Major League Baseball, he turned his disgrace into a personal brand.

title: How Wally Amos Lost It All — and Found Something New in the Wreckage
description: He made his cookies — and himself — “famous.”

title: Wafa Al-Udaini Captured the Experiences of Palestinians From Within
description: As a journalist, she was determined to tell a story of Gaza that was full of life.

title: The Orphaned Sea Otter Who Became a Foster Mom to 15 Pups
description: Despite never having had offspring of her own, she was an instinctive caregiver.

title: Naomi Feil Developed a Radical Approach to Caring for Dementia Patients
description: She believed that people with dementia were desperate to connect.

title: Police Respond to Vehicle Ramming Attack at German Christmas Market
description: Emergency responders attended to an incident at a Christmas market in Magdeburg, Germany, on Friday.

title: Biden Withdraws Proposed Regulations on Student Loans and Trans Athletes
description: The Biden administration on Friday withdrew some of its main outstanding plans to enact significant federal student loan forgiveness and to set rules around the participation of transgender athletes on school sports teams.

title: Why Luigi Mangione Faces 2 Murder Cases Tied to One Killing
description: Federal and state prosecutors charged Luigi Mangione this week in the killing of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive in Manhattan, a two-pronged legal offensive that could complicate the high-profile case.

title: The Trinidadian Christmas Staple Worth the Yearlong Wait
description: Most condiments understand their role: uplift but never upstage. But in Trinidad and Tobago, the show can’t go on without chow chow, a citrine-colored, spice-laced and veggie-packed relish.

title: The Other Game
description: Once upon a time, athletes hoping to become superstars had to worry about doing one thing: dominate their sport, and it would attract brands bearing hugely lucrative sponsorship deals. That may have worked for Michael Jordan, but things have changed significantly since he retired in 2003.

title: The 10 Architectural Sites You Should See in São Paulo
description: Present-day São Paulo — a sprawl of concrete towers and asphalt laid like a quilt over Brazil’s interior hills — began to take shape at the end of the 19th century, growing alongside the coffee plantations that thrived in the region’s hinterlands. But it was over the course of the following century that its most influential architectural designs were constructed, dotting the city with some of the world’s most extraordinary Modernist buildings.

title: A Shutdown’s Economic Toll: Less Spending, More Uncertainty
description: A federal government shutdown probably wouldn’t be enough to derail the solid U.S. economy. But it could inject more uncertainty into an already murky economic outlook.

title: F.D.A. Approves Weight Loss Drug to Treat Obstructive Sleep Apnea
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved the weight loss drug Zepbound to treat obstructive sleep apnea. It is the first prescription medication approved to treat the common sleep disorder.

title: Michael Brewer, Whose ‘One Toke’ Was a Big Hit, Is Dead at 80
description: Michael Brewer, half of the folk-rock duo Brewer & Shipley, who scored an unlikely Top 10 hit in 1971 with “One Toke Over the Line” — one of the most overt pop odes to marijuana of the hippie era and presumably the only one to be performed on the squeaky-clean “Lawrence Welk Show” — died on Tuesday at his home near Branson, Mo. He was 80.

title: Biden Administration Weighs Putting Up Roadblocks to Trump’s Deportation Campaign
description: The Biden administration is considering extending protections for hundreds of thousands of immigrants whose status in the United States is set to expire in the first months of the Trump administration, according to U.S. officials and documents viewed by The New York Times.

title: Cathy Cade, Groundbreaking Lesbian Photographer, Dies at 82
description: Cathy Cade, an activist and pioneering photographer who chronicled same-sex female relationships, producing a 1987 book that was hailed by feminists and gay-rights advocates as a classic, died on Nov. 16 at her home in Berkeley, Calif. She was 82.

title: Driver Plows a Car Into a Christmas Market in Germany
description: At least two people were killed and dozens were wounded after a car rammed into a Christmas market in the city of Magdeburg in central Germany on Friday evening.

title: Why Have So Many Canadians Turned on Justin Trudeau?
description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada is under intense pressure to step down after the abrupt and acrimonious resignation of a key deputy on Monday highlighted his deep unpopularity after nearly a decade in power.

title: Jewish School in Toronto Is Targeted for a Third Time
description: Gunshots struck a Jewish elementary school in Toronto on Friday for the third time in seven months, the latest in a series of antisemitic attacks that prompted officials to announce a new push to address Canada’s rising hate crimes.

title: At Luigi Mangione’s Perp Walk, Mayor Eric Adams Appeared Stage Right
description: As perp walks go, few have been more cinematic: Luigi Mangione, handcuffed and wearing an orange jumpsuit, surrounded by a phalanx of armed law enforcement officers as they led him off a helipad.

title: G.O.P. Spending Hawks Defy Trump on the Debt Limit, Previewing More Clashes
description: Something unusual happened this week after President-elect Donald J. Trump ordered House Republicans to back legislation raising the debt limit: Dozens refused.

title: The Budget Fight and Trump’s Nihilistic Style
description: In about a month, the inauguration will complete a loop: Donald Trump will become president again, eight years after the initial event.

title: Missouri Governor Commutes Sentence of Detective Convicted in On-Duty Killing
description: Gov. Mike Parson of Missouri commuted the sentence on Friday of a former police detective who was convicted of manslaughter in a 2019 shooting, an extraordinary intervention in a rare case that sent a police officer to prison for an on-duty killing. The former detective, from the Kansas City, Mo., department, had been released from prison on parole by Friday evening, an official said.

title: Suspect in C.E.O. Killing to Be Arraigned on State Charges Monday
description: The 26-year-old man charged in the predawn killing of a health insurance executive on a Manhattan sidewalk this month is scheduled to make his first appearance in New York State Supreme Court on Monday, prosecutors said.

title: Troy Masters, Pioneering L.G.B.T.Q. Journalist, Dies at 63
description: Troy Masters, a journalistic champion of L.G.B.T.Q. causes in publications that he founded, published or edited since the early 1990s, most recently The Los Angeles Blade, died on Dec. 11 in his home in West Hollywood, Calif. He was 63.

title: How Many People Did Cyclone Chido Actually Kill on a French Island?
description: Nearly a week after a devastating cyclone, most streets have reopened in Mayotte, a tiny French island off the east coast of Africa.

title: The House Voted to Avert a Government Shutdown
description: The House approved legislation tonight to avert a government shutdown roughly six hours before it was set to begin. A majority of lawmakers in both parties voted to extend funding for the federal government into mid-March and approve disaster relief for parts of the nation still reeling from storms.

title: Ann Rockefeller Roberts, Champion of Native Americans, Dies at 90
description: Ann Rockefeller Roberts, a champion of the rights, welfare and culture of Native Americans and the eldest daughter of Nelson A. Rockefeller, the former vice president and governor of New York, died on Wednesday at her home in Bedford, N.Y. She was 90.

title: U.S. Prisons Flout Law by Keeping Inmates Past Release Date, A.C.L.U. Says
description: Vanessa Crowe, a 50-year-old grandmother serving a long federal prison term on drug charges, eagerly enrolled in programs to cut her time behind bars — and was told she was eligible for release in May under a landmark sentencing reform law passed in 2018.

title: In Late Push, Senate Democrats Narrowly Top Trump on Judicial Confirmations
description: The Senate confirmed on Friday the 235th lifetime federal judge nominated by President Biden, topping the four-year record set during the first Trump administration by a single judge in a drive that significantly reshaped the federal courts to be more ethnically and professionally diverse.

title: White Judge Who Threatened to Shoot Black Teens at Party Resigns
description: A New York judge who invoked her position and threatened to shoot Black teenagers at a party has resigned and dropped her monthslong fight to remain on the bench after a state commission recommended that she be forced to leave office.

title: Congress Approves Spending Extension, Ending Shutdown Crisis
description: The Senate approved a spending measure early Saturday to keep government money flowing through mid-March, sending it to President Biden for his signature and closing a chaotic endgame in Congress minutes after federal funding had lapsed.

title: The Best Movies About Politics (According to You)
description: As 2024 draws to a close, you might be tired of watching politicians act as if they are the stars of an epic film.

title: In Search of Loved Ones, Syrian Women Face Horror of Assad’s Regime
Guatemalan Officials Raid Compound of Jewish Sect and Remove Dozens of Minors
description: Guatemalan officials raided a compound on Friday belonging to Lev Tahor, an ultra-Orthodox Jewish sect with past links to child exploitation. Prosecutors said they had removed at least 160 children and teenagers from the site who they believed were the victims of human trafficking and other offenses.

title: Corrections: Dec. 21, 2024
description: An article on Friday about Elon Musk leading the charge to kill a bipartisan spending deal misspelled the surname of the representative from Georgia who wrote a social media post referring to Elon Musk. She is Marjorie Taylor Greene, not Green.

title: It’s a Little Shady
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is not an easy crossword, but it’s certainly a friendly one. The humor is kindhearted, and the trivia is pleasantly nostalgic. It’s the first collaboration between Barbara Lin and Lewis Rothlein, two terrific constructors. They’re both crafty and clever, and they harmonize beautifully.

title: Chicago Board of Education Votes to Fire Leader of City’s School System
description: After months of political turmoil, the Chicago Board of Education voted unanimously to fire the chief executive of the city’s public school system on Friday night. The move to oust the executive, Pedro Martinez, represented a show of force for the Chicago Teachers Union and for Mayor Brandon Johnson, a close ally and former employee of the union.

title: Google Proposes Fix to Solve Search Monopoly
description: Google said on Friday what it thought should change to address a ruling that it had illegally maintained a monopoly over online search: not much.

title: What’s Next for Google’s Search Monopoly
description: Google said on Friday that a federal judge needed to do very little to fix its search monopoly.

title: Houthi Missile Strikes Tel Aviv as Attacks Increase
description: Iranian-backed Houthi militants launched a missile from Yemen that landed in Tel Aviv early Saturday morning after air defenses failed to intercept it, the latest in an increasing barrage of Houthi attacks.

title: Quote of the Day: When Your $3 Million Cello Is Bumped From Your Flight
description: “We guard it like one of our kids. And we spend time with the cello more than with our wives and kids.”

title: The Winter Solstice Is Upon Us. Here Comes the Sun Bread.
description: When my oldest daughter started kindergarten, I signed up to be a classroom parent. The school was small, public and in ethnically diverse Jersey City, which meant my daughter shared crayons with kids whose families came from all over the world. When it came time to plan the holiday party, the principal requested that it celebrate the season, but without any specific religious or cultural overtones. No Santa. No menorahs. Just joy.

title: Terrorism Roars Back in Pakistan, 10 Years After a Campaign to End It
description: Ten years have passed since Ajoon Khan’s son died in a ghastly attack by the Pakistani Taliban that killed about 150 people, mostly children, at a military-run school in Peshawar, in northwestern Pakistan.

title: For Syria’s Economy, the Way Forward Starts With Sanctions Relief
description: Although the collapse of President Bashar al-Assad’s government in Syria was shockingly quick, rebuilding the devastated economy he left behind will be painfully slow.

title: Congress Approves Full Social Security Benefits for Public Sector Retirees
description: The Senate passed bipartisan legislation early Saturday that would give full Social Security benefits to a group of public sector retirees who currently receive them at a reduced level, sending the bill to President Biden.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

title: How the Founder of a Fruit Jelly Snack Company Spends Her Sundays
description: Growing up in Hong Kong and Singapore, Sophia Cheng delighted in snacks from across Asia, which were often made with ingredients like seaweed and dried seafood.

title: New York Is Putting Trash in Bins. Some People Have a Problem With That.
description: New Yorkers played central roles in developing such technological innovations as air-conditioning, toilet paper and the atomic bomb.

title: 3-Minute Christmas Market Rampage Shakes Germany
description: It took an attacker just three minutes to kill five people and wound hundreds by ramming an S.U.V. into a crowded holiday market on Friday night, stunning Germany and shattering the peace of its Christmas season.

title: Audiobooks to Cook (or Eat) To, From Ina Garten to David Chang
description: Take it from me: You don’t have to be a capable cook to appreciate stories about food. Nor do you need to hang around a hot stove or hold a physical book in your hands. I’ve recently discovered the pleasure — and the comfort — of strolling to the sound of cooking memoirs. Here are my favorites, read with honesty and gusto.

title: How to (Gently) Set Boundaries During the Holidays
description: Every Christmas, Gabriel Ronquillo dreads the inevitable questions from well-meaning relatives about when he’s getting married or having children.

title: He’s the Only 3-Michelin-Starred Chef in Seoul. Don’t Cross Him.
description: On an early episode of Netflix’s hit cooking show “Culinary Class Wars,” the chef Anh Sung-jae stood in a warehouse filled with makeshift cooking stations and considered the plate in front of him: a rainbow palette of handmade pastas, purées and delicately cooked seafood. On top was a smattering of flower petals.

title: What Do We Want From the Mall?
description: Recently, a retail mirage of sorts appeared just off the Hempstead Turnpike on the Queens-Long Island border, next to the Belmont horse racetrack and the UBS arena, home of the New York Islanders hockey team and the occasional Harry Styles concert.

title: Googie, a Futuristic Style of Architecture, Is Endangered
description: Googie architecture is a midcentury design style characterized by dramatic rooflines, pops of color, large glass windows and flashy signs. Anna Kodé, a reporter covering design and culture for the Real Estate section of The New York Times, describes the efforts by preservationists to save examples of the distinctive style.

title: Band-Aid Over a Bullet Wound
description: It felt as if someone were pressing a lit cigarette to my thigh. I knew that burn, thanks to my father’s drunken humor, but this was worse. I’d been shot.

title: The Fight to Save Googie, the Style of Postwar Optimism
description: In June, the Arby’s on Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles shut down. The news, announced on the restaurant’s marquee — “FAREWELL HOLLYWOOD TY FOR 55 GREAT YEARS” — didn’t seem surprising, with rents and labor costs on the rise. What was out of the ordinary was the public’s response to it.

title: After the Wedding Day, These Artifacts Remain
description: Wedding keepsakes can help preserve happy memories for a couple. They are infused with celebration, nostalgia, and, of course, love. But occasionally, one item can take center stage and, like a relationship, endures the test of time and grows in sentimental value. Some couples refer to these treasures as wedding artifacts.

title: How Will Ukraine Keep the Lights on This Winter?
description: With Russia intensifying airstrikes on Ukraine’s power grid over the past month, darkness once again engulfs Ukrainian cities at night. In Kyiv, residents rely on cellphone flashlights to navigate unlit streets. To walk their dogs, they use glow sticks doubling as makeshift collars.

title: The Black Blackface Performer Who History Tries to Forget
description: In the early 1890s a Black Bahamian immigrant named Bert Williams stepped on a California stage for the first time. He wore white gloves, a kinky-haired wig on his head and had burnt cork smeared on his face. This was his first show as part of a group called the Mastodon Minstrels, and it was his first time in blackface. Once onstage the usually charismatic Williams froze; he couldn’t remember his lines. He finally blurted out, “If I says anything, those folks’ll laugh at me” before running offstage, according to his biographer, Camille F. Forbes. The audience, thinking it was part of the show, responded with uproarious cheering. Williams was appalled; he swore off wearing blackface.

title: Death on the Night Shift at Frozen Pizza Factories in Chicago
description: On a brilliant day three years ago, a grieving crowd gathered on the South Side of Chicago to bury Adewale Ezekiel Ogunyemi.

title: Kyle Mooney on Divorced-Dad Music
description: For years, Kyle Mooney has had a low-key fixation on Y2K because as a 15-year-old he found it such a letdown.

title: Christmas vs. First Night of Hanukkah: What’s an Interfaith Family to Do?
description: The Dec. 25 menu is set for Denise Handlarski’s family: Turkey because it’s Christmas. Latkes because it’s Hanukkah.

title: A Restaurant Is More Than a Workplace for People Often Shunned by Employers
description: Nacho Fernández Suárez winces when he recalls the eight years he spent as an administrative assistant doing odd errands in Argentina’s Congress. He was part of an inclusion program for people with disabilities.

title: Is ‘People Pleasing’ Giving You Money Problems? Here’s How to Fix Things.
description: Hailey Magee often paid for drinks when she went out with friends, bought loved ones expensive dinners and picked up the tab on dates. During the holiday season, Ms. Magee purchased lavish gifts, even when she was on a tight budget.

title: The Gym in My Apartment Building Is SO LOUD! What Can I Do?
description: Q: I recently moved into an 11th-floor apartment on the Upper East Side. When I was shown the apartment, I wasn’t told that it was directly below the building’s gym, which is open to tenants 24 hours a day. The sound of heavy weights slamming into the ground shakes my apartment. This noise occurs overnight and in the early morning, preventing me from sleeping. There are two other available apartments with the same rent, but management is refusing to let me move. I have asked them to limit the gym hours, but the only response is a suggestion that I soundproof my ceiling. What can I do?

title: For Pedro Almodóvar’s Movies, the Poster Tells Its Own Story
description: Few filmmakers have as distinctive a visual style as the Spanish director Pedro Almodóvar. The palette for his work often includes ravaging reds, piquant pinks and bruising blues. And over four decades, Almodóvar’s aesthetic has reached far beyond the silver screen. Posters for his films adorn everything from T-shirts and tote bags to postcards and pins.

title: The Best Holiday Brunches Start With This Supermarket Ingredient
description: Amid all of the activity on Christmas morning — hosting family, prepping dinner, sharing gifts, tidying up and being present enough to truly experience the moment — it can be challenging to pick a dish that strikes the sweet spot between effortless and impressive, one that adds joy (but not stress) to the occasion.

title: What Is It About the Doechii Aesthetic?
description: It wasn’t long after Natasha Shrestha, a seventh-grade history teacher in New York City, saw the cover for Doechii’s latest mixtape that she decided to claim a piece of the Florida rapper’s aesthetic for herself.

title: From Liberal Icon to MAGA Joke: The Waning Fortunes of Justin Trudeau
description: Justin Trudeau’s career is the stuff of 21st-century political drama, with an arc that has taken him from glamorous liberal standard-bearer to the butt of jokes by President-elect Donald J. Trump and his acolytes.

title: Hitting Home for the Holidays: A Jump in Egg Prices
description: Americans stocking up on holiday cooking essentials may be greeted with an unwelcome surprise in the grocery aisles: higher prices for eggs, spurred by an intensifying bird flu outbreak.

title: In ‘Mrs. Stern’ and ‘Racecar,’ Humans Keep Repeating Their Worst Mistakes
description: Inside the jail cell, the police officer is registering his freshly arrested prisoner — a young Jewish woman suspected of political criminality. It is 1933 in Berlin, where determining who belongs and who doesn’t is of paramount concern to the government. So he inquires about her birthplace (Germany) and her parents’ (same). And her parents’ parents’.

title: Jonathan Roumie Plays Jesus to Millions. It Can Get Intense.
description: The star of “The Chosen” discusses his early struggles in Hollywood, fans who conflate him with his character and how his own faith informs his work.

title: Jonathan Roumie Plays Jesus to Millions. It Can Get Intense.
description: It’s common, maybe even natural, for audiences to conflate actors with the roles they play. To assume, for example, that an onscreen action hero is tough offscreen too, or that a rom-com star is a real-life charmer. That blurring of lines is probably a sign that an actor is doing something right, but it doesn’t make the dynamic any less strange or confusing. Especially if the character you’re famous for playing is Jesus Christ.

title: André 3000 Performs Surprise Concert in The NY Times Newsroom
description: André 3000 and the band behind “New Blue Sun” — featuring Surya Botofasina, Nate Mercereau, Carlos Niño and Deantoni Parks — perform in The Times’ newsroom.

title: After This Interview, André 3000 Performed in Our Newsroom
description: Two decades after André 3000, as one half of the rap duo Outkast, won the Grammy Award for album of the year for “Speakerboxxx/The Love Below,” he is again nominated in that category on quite different terms. At the show in February, he’s up as a solo artist, for “New Blue Sun,” an album of improvised music on which he plays a variety of wind instruments and speaks no words. It’s a sonic pivot, but maybe not a philosophical one for a musician who has rewritten his creative approach several times over a 30-year career.

title: André 3000 Performs in the New York Times Newsroom
description: After an interview on The Times’s Popcast podcast, André 3000 and the band behind “New Blue Sun” — featuring Surya Botofasina, Nate Mercereau, Carlos Niño and Deantoni Parks — performed an improvised piece in the newsroom.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,282
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion No. 560
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: In Top Minister’s Resignation, Shades of an Earlier Political Crisis for Trudeau
description: On Monday morning, I was on my way out to hole up with other reporters to take an advance look at the government’s fall economic statement, mostly to see what it said about border security. Then Chrystia Freeland put out her resignation letter.

title: Your Favorite Things
description: It’s that time of year when things wind down, when people start putting things off until after the holidays, until January, until next year. I find this comforting, like 2024 is full, we’re buttoning it up and packing it away. We couldn’t possibly squeeze in another project or plan. I’ve lost count of the number of conversations and lunch dates and meetings I’ve committed to “when we’re all back.” Can January even contain all the planning we’ve flung in its direction?

title: For Some, a Silver Lining in Alzheimer’s Caregiving
description: To the Editor:

title: Why I Would Never Donate Sperm in the United States
description: In 2019, after thorough deliberation, I made the most meaningful decision of my adult life to become a dad. And, while joyously successful — I now have three sons and two daughters — I’ve never met them. That’s because I donated sperm to a fertility clinic in New South Wales, Australia, where I live. At this stage, a better word for me is “donor.”

title: A Conversation About the Virgin Birth That Maybe Wasn’t
description: This is the latest in my occasional series of conversations about Christianity, aimed at bridging America’s God gulf. Previously, I’ve spoken with the Rev. Timothy Keller, President Jimmy Carter, the evangelical writer Beth Moore and others. Here I speak with Elaine Pagels, a prominent professor of religion at Princeton University and an expert on the early church. Our conversation has been edited for clarity and length.

title: Hollywood Is Desperate for Movie Stars. This Year, the Cavalry Arrived.
description: As you may have heard, Hollywood has hit a rough patch. The box office has been wobbly, A.I. is looming and this year’s biggest live-action hit, “Deadpool and Wolverine,” is a Marvel movie that cracks jokes about how lousy Marvel movies are these days.

title: Religion Has Been in Decline. This Christmas Seems Different.
description: In March, I drove with my family up from Rome into the mountains of southeastern Umbria, to reach the town of Norcia and the monastery — now an abbey; it’s been promoted since our visit — of St. Benedict on the Mountain, a community of Benedictine monks perched above a wide valley that was then just greening with the spring.

title: Justice Thomas Did Not Disclose Additional Trips, Democrats Say
description: Justice Clarence Thomas failed to disclose two additional trips from a billionaire patron that had not previously come to light, Senate Democrats revealed on Saturday after conducting a 20-month investigation into ethics practices at the Supreme Court.

title: Heroes in Their Twilight Years, and Still in the Spotlight
description: Dear readers,

title: From Inflation to Bitcoin, 9 Charts That Explain 2024
description: Despite a tumultuous U.S. presidential campaign and intensifying global conflicts, the economy is poised to end 2024 in a stable position. Inflation has come down substantially and economic growth remains relatively robust, particularly for the United States. But the outlook for 2025 remains murky, as President-elect Donald Trump’s policy changes could affect the economy in unpredictable ways.

title: As Drugstores Close, Older People Are Left in ‘Pharmacy Deserts’
description: In July, a notice appeared on the front door of The Drug Store, the only pharmacy in rural Kernville, Calif. After 45 years, the proprietor wrote regretfully, it would be closing in four days and transferring customers’ prescriptions to a Rite Aid about 12 miles away.

title: Pope Francis’ Christmas Message to His Top Advisers: Don’t Gossip
description: At end-of-year celebrations, some bosses give their employees gifts of appreciation and extend warm wishes. On Saturday, Pope Francis used his annual Christmas message to the leaders of the Vatican’s various departments to admonish them.

title: Top Uniformed N.Y.P.D. Officer Resigns After Abuse Allegations
description: New York City’s top uniformed police officer, the chief of department, abruptly resigned Friday night following allegations of sexual misconduct, setting off local and federal investigations and extending years of turmoil at the Police Department.

title: ‘We Can Bury Anyone’: Inside a Hollywood Smear Machine
description: Last summer, as the release of “It Ends With Us” approached, Justin Baldoni, the director and a star of the film, and Jamey Heath, the lead producer, hired a crisis public relations expert.

title: Read the Statement
description: Statement to The New York Times from Bryan Freedman, attorney for Justin Baldoni, Wayfarer Studios and all its representatives.

title: Read the Complaint
description: Blake Lively v. Wayfarer Studios LLC et al

title: Get Ready for Oohs and Aahs
description: I’ve never been to Stissing House, Clare de Boer’s restaurant in Pine Plains, N.Y., but reading her recipes makes the FOMO feverishly real. The holiday menu she created for New York Times Cooking reads like some sort of Christmas poem: spiced orange duck with ginger, thyme and anise. Leafy winter salad with a honeyed vinaigrette. And — be still, my fluttering, rice-loving heart — this rice and squash bombe encased in crisp pita and pebbly pine nuts.

title: Party City to Close All Stores by February, Company Says
description: Party City, the party supply store that has provided the glittering backdrops for generations of birthday celebrations, New Year’s Eve bashes and Super Bowl gatherings, announced just days before Christmas that it was closing its doors for good.

title: Amazon Warehouse Workers in New York City Join Protest
description: Signaling an escalation in a labor campaign that began at seven Amazon delivery hubs on Thursday, workers at the company’s largest Staten Island warehouse began a protest there at midnight on Saturday.

title: Biden Signs Spending Bill, Finalizing End to Shutdown Drama
description: President Biden on Saturday signed the spending package that allowed federal funds to keep flowing until mid-March, formally ending the week’s unexpected drama over the issue a few hours after the deadline for a shutdown had technically passed.

title: Donald Trump Is Vulnerable
description: The recurring theme of my writing the past few weeks is that Donald Trump is not invulnerable. His win did not upend the rules of American politics or render him immune to political misfortune. Like everything we experience, his victory was contingent — a function of specific people in specific circumstances making specific choices. To change any of these variables is to change the ultimate destination.

title: The Waging of an Alleged Smear Campaign Against Blake Lively
description: The movie “It Ends With Us” starring Blake Lively was a huge box office hit, even as rumors spread of turmoil behind the scenes. Private messages detail a campaign to tarnish Lively after she accused Justin Baldoni of misconduct on set. Megan Twohey, an investigative reporter at The New York Times, explains.

title: Germany Bulked Up Christmas Market Security. An Attack Still Happened.
description: For years, Germany has been strengthening security measures around Christmas markets in reaction to an attack in 2016 in which a man killed 12 people by driving a truck into a market in central Berlin.

title: Deception and Betrayal: Inside the Final Days of the Assad Regime
description: As rebels advanced toward the Syrian capital of Damascus on Dec. 7, the staff in the hilltop Presidential Palace prepared for a speech they hoped would lead to a peaceful end to the 13-year civil war.

title: Homeless Woman Going Into Labor Is Cited for Violating Camping Ban
description: A homeless woman said that she was going into labor in Louisville, Ky., when a police officer gave her a citation under a law that bans unauthorized public camping, according to her lawyer and body-camera footage released on Thursday.

title: Iran’s Energy Crisis Hits ‘Dire’ Point as Industries Are Forced to Shut Down
description: Government offices in Iran are closed or operating at reduced hours. Schools and colleges have moved to online only. Highways and shopping malls have descended into darkness, and industrial plants have been denied power, bringing manufacturing to a near halt.

title: Rickey Henderson, Baseball’s Flamboyant ‘Man of Steal,’ Dies at 65
description: Rickey Henderson, the thrilling and charismatic Hall of Fame outfielder who, with his signature crouched stance, blazing speed and unlikely home run power, was widely regarded as the greatest leadoff hitter in Major League Baseball history, died on Friday. He was 65.

title: Lee Edwards, Historian of the Conservative Movement, Dies at 92
description: Lee Edwards, a self-described “cradle conservative” who participated in key moments in the modern conservative movement and then became its all but official historian, writing flattering books about the Heritage Foundation, Ronald Reagan, William F. Buckley Jr. and other subjects, died on Dec. 12 at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 92.

title: ‘A Gift to Everyone’: A Wisconsin Community Mourns a School Shooting Victim
description: Just this past week, Rubi Patricia Vergara was at a craft fair with her family to support her best friend, who was selling handmade necklaces and keychains. Rubi, who loved arts and crafts, bought the most expensive item, and then skipped around the fair with her friend, Josie Hughes. At the end of the day, the two girls hugged goodbye, saying they would see each other soon.

title: Go With the Flow
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE — In his print introduction to this grid, Joel Fagliano writes: “Adrian Johnson, from Laramie, Wyo., is currently a substitute teacher in Knox County, Tenn., where he is affectionately known as ‘Mr. A.J.’ He sold his first crossword to The Times three years ago, when he was 21. This is his ninth puzzle for the paper — and the seventh one that is unthemed (his favorite type of crossword to make). Puzzles like this are built on the interlock of long, colorful answers throughout the grid. Many, like 1-, 27-, and 97-Across, are making their Times debut.”

title: Atmospheric Rivers Will Drench the West Coast
description: The Pacific Northwest and Northern California, especially Washington and Oregon, have had an onslaught of storms and the run of them is expected to continue over the next week.

title: Dropped From Spending Bill, Cancer Research and D.C. Stadium Measures Revived by Senate
description: After a tumultuous few days, President Biden on Saturday signed into law a spending bill that had been heavily trimmed down to 120 pages from 1,547. It had lost provisions targeting hidden fees on concert tickets and criminalizing the publication of some deepfake pornography.

title: Germany Mourns After Christmas Market Attack
description: Germans visited a memorial in Magdeburg, Germany, for the at least five people killed and more than 200 injured at a Christmas market, after an attacker drove a vehicle into a crowd.

title: Congress Approves Spending Package After Political Drama
description: President Biden signed the spending bill early on Saturday, ensuring that there would be no lapse in government funding.

title: University of California Resolves Civil Rights Complaints Over Gaza Protests
description: The University of California has resolved federal civil rights complaints from students who cited antisemitism and anti-Arab and anti-Muslim discrimination at U.C.L.A. and four other campuses following protests over the Israel-Hamas war, the Education Department announced Friday.

title: Trump Appoints ‘The Apprentice’ Producer as Special Envoy to Britain
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has tapped Mark Burnett, the producer who helped turn him into a household name with “The Apprentice,” as special envoy to Britain.

title: Police Fatally Shoot Man Who Drove Pickup Into Texas Mall, Injuring 5
description: Five people were injured on Saturday after a man drove his pickup truck through the glass doors of a J.C. Penney in a mall in Killeen, Texas, and continued to drive through the building before he was shot and killed by the police, the authorities said.

title: Corrections: Dec. 22, 2024
description: An article this weekend on page 7 about “S.N.L.’s” internet culture misstates the year “Lazy Sunday” was created. It was 2005, not 2008.

title: Quotation of the Day: Traditions Overlap as Christmas Meets Hanukkah
description: “Previously I thought Hanukkah couldn’t hold a candle to Christmas. Now I see, in the fullness of time, that it’s not a competition. It’s making room in your heart for all good things.”

title: The Art of the Gift: Jenny Lewis
description: A former child actress (“Troop Beverly Hills,” “The Wizard”), Jenny Lewis, 48, has spent more than two decades traveling the world as a member of the indie-pop bands Rilo Kiley and The Postal Service, the latter of which recently wrapped a two-year reunion tour. Her fifth solo album, “Joy’All,” was released in 2023. She lives in Los Angeles. This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.

title: After Military Took Power, Terrorist Attacks Only Got Worse
description: Attacks that killed dozens of civilians and soldiers in Niger this month have put a spotlight on the military’s failure to restore security in the West African nation, nearly 18 months after staging a coup.

title: A Cultural Casualty of the War in Ukraine: ‘The Nutcracker’
description: Unimpressed by the substitute for Tchaikovsky’s “Nutcracker,” the mother and her young daughter left at the intermission, a small protest over a decision by the opera house not to perform the Russian composer’s Christmas classic.

title: Memes, Jokes and Cats: South Koreans Use Parody for Political Protest
description: As South Koreans took to the streets this month demanding the ousting of their president, some found an unexpected outlet to express their fury.

title: U.S. Fighter Jet Shot Down Over Red Sea by Apparent Friendly Fire
description: A U.S. Navy ship mistakenly shot down an American fighter jet over the Red Sea early Sunday, the U.S. military said, highlighting the potential risks for international forces as they try to stop attacks on cargo ships by the Houthi militia in Yemen.

title: Things Are Terrible in Europe, and They’re Only Going to Get Worse
description: Early this year, France’s center-right Republicans decided to move to a new home. After a decade of demoralizing defeats, the party vacated its headquarters for one closer to France’s National Assembly, hoping the move would bring a change in fortune.

title: A 1,000-Year-Old Seed Grows in Israel
description: Camels laden with spices, gold and precious stones accompanied the Queen of Sheba on her biblical journey to Jerusalem in the 10th century B.C. A thousand years later, Flavius Josephus, the Jewish Roman historian, wrote that the haul had included the balm of Gilead, a fragrant, highly prized resin also known as Judean balsam, which served as the basis for perfumes, incense and medicinal remedies.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
